review_title: Be careful about technology jobs in the US and UK
employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time
employeer_pros: I met some nice people at DB
employeer_cons:
Technology positions in the US and UK are being moved to India. I would think it through carefully before accepting a technology job in the US or UK.

There is constant technology senior management change. Lack of clear strategy outside of constant layoffs and cost reductions.

No salary raise for many years. What you are hired at will be your salary for years to come. Only exception is if you are promoted and you are not at the high end of the role band.

Bonuses were reduced this year by 25% from 2019 which was a poor year.

Review benefits carefully to confirm they are on par to DB peers

review_title: Don't come here now, you will probably get let go in 6 months.
employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: Not much beyond the usual, people are generally ok to work with.
employeer_cons:
-They cut rollover vaca days (use them or lose them) 
-Takes 5 years to be fully vested 
-Comp tends to be on the low end and no salary transparency (person next to you with same title probably getting paid more than you) 
-Bonuses are a joke (the attitude from managers is be grateful you have a job) 
-Senior management leaving in droves, causing major disruptions
-Massive restructuring, morale is terrible as many colleagues are losing their jobs in the next few months
-Half the stuff that you will work on will never get implemented or used because there are no resources. 
Pretty much every one is looking for a job elsewhere.

employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: The people try very hard to make it work.  The community groups are good to get people engaged.  Overall the people create a good environment.  I learned a lot there.   Cloud adoption is a focus, so get in on the ground floor there for learning about this.   Not a bad place to get your feet wet and start a career. employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: The standard benefits are of course great, same as any big bank, generous vacation.  However, even though sick days are technically unlimited, they do count against you by some managers in AFC.
employeer_cons: Anti-Financial Crimes is a micromanaged hellscape.   The COO (or at least that is who everyone blames) has everyone on edge for the sake of “optics”.   Nothing gets done, it’s all style, no substance.  Even though you have unlimited sick days, they are counted against you.   Unlike other large banks, working from home is only in the case of emergencies and you have to give a limb for the privilege.  This is not how they advertise though - I was sold a false bill of goods when I interviewed.   Most good talent leaves in less than 2 years.  Turnover in AFC is insane and I just added to the numbers when I finally got the chance to leave for a much better opportunity at a bank with great corporate culture.  The department is falling apart and lacks cohesion like you wouldn’t believe.   Zero work-life balance.  Beware of the lies and charm some managers will lay on to get you to take the job - there are a reason most open positions have been open for more than 6 months.

We've paid over 17bln EUR in fines over the last 20 years.  We are in the process of letting go over 20,000 employees globally and shutting down businesses that shouldn't have failed.  The CEO and the management board are tone deaf and inept.

review_title: Definitely the worst place I have ever worked!
employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time
employeer_pros: There are generally nice people working at the Cary location.  The salary is higher than the average in my field compared to other companies. They have a lot of different clubs that you can join to mingle and network.  Unlimited sick days. Generous PTO.  Very diverse work force.
employeer_cons: 401k match at 4% vested 20% each year for 5 years.  I used to believe this was to retain workers, but now I am convinced it if 5 years to protect DB from paying out matching when they let people go.  The management here is atrocious.  It became pretty evident over time my peers and I were "used" by our former manager in order to justify her promotion (she didn't manage us at all).  Career development is also non-existent (poor management again) and this company has the feel of an IT sweatshop.  Management had no plan for career development and their promotion strategy is an absolute joke.  It isn't based on how you perform rather an interview with multiple employees you never worked with before? Training is almost non-existent as well except for regulatory . This is pretty ironic since this company is routinely in the news for it's share of fraudulent and unlawful behavior (fine after fine).   DB is part of a bad Germany history that we all know about yet they are all about inclusion (which is good, but strange given that history).   Too many H1B visa workers.  The on boarding process is nonexistent here so you have to struggle mightily when you first start.   When I first started, I was told I would get a guaranteed percentage bonus (never got what I was promised).   Annual salary increases were a joke since the bank was doing so poorly.  Overall 3 years of little to no bonus and little to no salary increase.  Morale is low when the bank stinks from year to year.

Very political process in getting promoted... more about who you know and who you can get to recognize you than what you accomplish.  Lots of middle managers more focused on how things are perceived to upper management rather than getting things done.  I saw deliveries that were ready to go being held back so that upper management wouldn't be expecting fast deliveries all the time or to keep from someone higher up the chain from looking good... as I said, very political.

employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 10 years
employeer_pros: Working in Operations at Deutsche Bank for over 20 years has been an experience.  Operations teams always completed the work with pride and integrity, be it in Trade Finance, Global Markets or Transaction Banking and through the years I worked with many great people and had several good managers.
employeer_cons:
Over the years there were many senior executives that led Deutsche Bank, providing a strategic direction which never seemed to change - reduce expenses again and again.  Getting raises, bonuses and promotions was always difficult.  This direction led to moving U.S. dollar processing and account balances to servers in Germany, outsourcing work to vendors and lower cost areas in India, accompanied by a loss of qualified experienced staff in the U.S.  The results - complaints by clients, increased risks and scrutiny by regulators.  Eventually, clients left and regulators questioned the lapses in controls, which lead numerous fines including $630 million for Laundering Russian Money, $2.5 billion for the U.S. and U.K. plus €725 million for Libor Interest Rate Scam, $258 million for Violation of US Economic Sanctions, $7.2 billion for the Sale of Toxic Securities Leading up to the Financial Crisis and $205 million for Violations of New York Banking Laws stemming from Foreign Exchange Trading Business.  The value of the stock declined from $150 in 2007 to the $8.00 neighborhood today.

When people ask me about The Big Short (2015) in reference to Deutsche Bank, I reply Independence Day (1996) is a more appropriate representation, where aliens came to take all available resources and wreak havoc before they move on to the next target.

employeer_pros:
Coworkers and local managers are wonderful and supportive (ignoring the location head who has since left)

Great work/life balance, especially for new parents

Amazing 401(k) program and match

Development environments are slowly becoming better in most ways.

Decent compensation for the area.
employeer_cons:
Generally awful vendors for supporting technology infrastructure.

Inflexible black boxed promotion process.

Many projects that struggle with technical debt and lack buy-in from the business to fix these issues.

Still cannot access the public Bitbucket website internally.

No incentive to truly reward high performers in junior and mid-level positions, as compensation is tied to overall bank performance for those roles. Occasionally you may be able to get a (<10%) bonus on top of that.

Truly abysmal stock purchase plan: extraordinarily high fees (It cost me 7% of my balance to sell), very low match, high minimum investment relative to stock price.

Upper management and compliance make a lot of talk about money laundering and regulations with no visibility into why the bank is still hiring corrupt individuals. It is frustrating being told to not do X, Y, and Z and continually seeing headlines about people doing those exact, obvious things.

employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time
employeer_pros: Generous vacation time and paid parental leave, unlimited sick time, nice modern facilities, competitive pay if you come in with experience (not if you start your career here)
employeer_cons: Where to start?  I worked in Business Finance so I can’t speak for other areas, but it was far and away the most toxic, unprofessional work environment I have ever been a part of. Most people who work in the department look and act miserable day in and day out. People openly yell and use profanity in frustration all day long in a very open concept workspace (and the frustration is understandable). Data quality and IT infrastructure are a complete joke. A huge part of your job in Finance is attempting to resolve millions of dollars worth of system breaks. And by system breaks, I mean variances between subsystems and the ledger that you can’t figure out because it’s next to impossible to research. I’m not entirely sure how this place passes audit to be honest. It’s a very unstable job because they’re always trying to cut costs and headcount. There were numerous times in my time there where entire teams were done away with or the roles were offshored to India. In fact, since I’ve left I’ve heard the Business Finance function as a whole is migrating to India. And then they expect you to go over there for months to train the people taking your job. Turnover is extremely high, with entire teams including managers turning over within a year or 2. Many people left to go to the other investment bank downtown. If you decide to leave, it’s likely you will get the cold shoulder (and sometimes open hostility) from your manager and directors the rest of your time there. If you try to move to another team, your current manager will often block you moving no matter how unhappy you are so you can’t take another role. I saw people I worked with quit without a job lined up yet because they couldn’t take it anymore.  Promotions are hard to get because of how political the process is and how much it relies on you having significant interaction with NY. To top it all off, management will read feedback like this and then honestly question why employee morale is so low and why the environment is so negative. I wouldn’t recommend this job to anyone and I wouldn’t go back for double my salary.

review_title: Surrounded by talent but compensation structure not great
employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros:
-Filled with talent and ambitious people that get things done, learned so much in my time there
-Management recognizes performance, and will identify you and put you on the fast track to a promotion, so you can earn your way up there if you're young and not worry about being behind someone that's been there longer but not a high performer like you are, it's definitely more merit based
-On the forefront of addressing/solving the most cutting edge/emerging issues/problems/etc. in banking
employeer_cons:
-Comp structure for AVP and below is just a base, then quarterly recognition bonus of 5% (eligible to get this quarterly, up to 2 quarters in a year, so 10% max a year), and then a 5% variable bonus, so if you're not recognized as a high performer, you might only get your base + the 5% variable
-Once you get VP and above, you'll get base + a variable bonus again (20%+ depending on your role and level), but internal promotion raises are not great (9-15% raises)
-Lots of bad press directed at DB right now, so reputation might be down, but bank is not going anywhere, anytime soon

employeer_cons: Limited authority to do your job as everything is driven from Frankfurt. Too many people in Germany who are not producing (too heavily staffed there) but are kept on the payroll due to labor laws. Instead, people are being laid off in other countries without a clear plan as to what's coming next. Migrating jobs in India is done to cut cost, but just like other companies have realized, it ain't gonna work for very long.  The goal is to move talent out of high cost areas, but really, where is the talent? Not in some godforsaken locations. So many issues have not been resolved for years that cutting costs just for the sake of cutting costs is going to exacerbate the situation with customers and regulators.

employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros:
Pros at DB include great work-life balance. The people are great; during my three year tenure I forged lifelong friendships with people I'll be in touch with for the rest of my life. Vacation days for those at the analyst/associate level can go up to 28 days for the full year, include rollover days, which is awesome! Fairly lax management who allows you to take the reigns without too much micromanagement. This obviously depends on the team, but I was on three different teams in three years and found that I was able to have free reign without too much pushback under the management I had to deal with.

Being able to have full access to the cafeteria in the basement as well as good La Colombe coffee across the street is also a nice perk. Everything you need is essentially within an arm's reach in FiDi.
employeer_cons:
Cons: pay is WELL below market value across front, back and middle office functions. People are generally jaded due to low P&L generation as well as less deal flow due to DB's recent reputation on the Street. Because of the aforementioned factors, DB is losing out on young talent rapidly because they are unable to compete with comparable offers other investment banks are giving to those who have decided to jump ship. Moreover, recruiters are actively reaching out to and poaching Deutsche employees due to the current state of the place. It's sad because in its hey-day, DB was probably one of the top European investment banks to work for and now everyone talks about it as though its a modern day Titanic. 

Senior managers are also being pushed out due to being too expensive. Even those higher-ups who do generate P&L have been let go because Deutsche simply cannot afford to keep them on payroll. Cost-cutting is the name of the game and it has sadly made for a very angry and frustrating work environment.

Lastly, Deutsche's infrastructure is so broken and bureaucratic it makes it virtually impossible for front office to generate new business. If a counterparty wants to set up a subaccount to trade a certain product with DB, the process takes weeks when it should only take 10 minutes. If an entirely new client wants to trade with us, forget it... that process can take months. Sometimes, by the time an account gets up and running to trade, the client is so disenchanted with our disorganized onboarding process that they decide the hassle isn't worth it.

Overall, I gained a lot of knowledge during my three years at DB. It was honestly an awesome place to start a career and build a decent nest egg, but if you're looking for A-grade comp at an uber competitive investment bank, look elsewhere as DB will only provide you with enough to get by and the place itself isn't terribly competitive because they can't afford to be.

review_title: Some glimmers of light, though Cary leadership leave little to be desired.
employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time for less than a year
employeer_pros:
Contrary to the doom and gloom the media conveys about Deutsche Bank, the wider bank (external of the Cary office) is surprisingly interesting and there are a few nuggets of optimism.  With the recent senior management changes at board level, there are some glimmers of sense as the much needed rationalisation has happened in abundance - hopefully the target will soon be on the local Cary Director "leadership" as there is plenty of dead wood to strip there.

The working area is ok.  Somewhat like a call center instead of a development environment, which is kinda ok as not a huge amount of real development happens here.  Elbow room is in short supply, but this is compensated by the comedy of the center wide town halls which are a real hoot!
Deutsche Bank benefits are great.  Free holiday, pension, health-care and the work-life-balance of what is essentially an easy life make this an opportunity that is hard to overlook for anyone.  Second jobbing is entirely possible.
Bonuses went the way of the dodo a few years back and this resulted in a brain drain that made us a popular invite for any quiz-based social.  Gallows humor is common-place, which is a real positive, especially with the yearly cycle of musical chairs where we are often dumb-founded by the same near-misses year after year.
In the absence of old-style banking compensation, the balance of few promotions has swung to "promote anyone" this is good for the long-termers as there must be some corrections to be made, however it's a "Con" too (I'll describe below).
employeer_cons:
The nuggets of good I referred to as a positive are sadly not evident in Cary.  There are nuggets, just a different type, and this would nicely describe the local directorship.  The ego amongst the non-contributor population is often breathtaking.  Lots of references to "my guys", but little loyalty come compensation distribution and standing up to their higher achieving counterparts in the Financial Centers.
In reference to the "promote anyone" mentality, the quality requirement bar has dropped significantly.    Being a senior leader at Deutsche Bank use to really mean something with the MDs and Directors being some of the best in the game, now I would suggest they are operating at a minus one, as-in, MDs are the old Directors, Directors -> VPs and so-on.  Self awarding titles such as "President" for technology management with no apparent technology capability is demotivating for anyone with a technology aspiration.

employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
Opportunity to learn many applications and technologies
401k
Healthcare
employeer_cons:
An ubsurd amount of managers. 1:2 ratio (mgmt/staff). None of which, bother to schedule resources, offten resulting in team conflicts.

Local manager does so much micromanaging, most projects end up disorganized and delayed.

Manager calls morning, noon, night, weekends.

Global team is treated differently when weekend work is needed.

APAC is offered comp days, UK is offered comp days or weekend pay, while the US team is offered no comp days no weekend pay. Both APAC and UK are insensitive to the fact.

We are asked to work the weekend with 1-2 days notice. This happens on a regular basis. Every request is due to priority or emergency.

Sheduled to work 14 day straight (M-F,S-Sun,M-F) and was asked to work the upcoming weekend last minute.

Job role and expectations changed 1year after being hired.

No yearly salary increase.
No opportunities to move up.

Total disregard of employee work/balance.

New processes are created regularly by internal and external teams, often inefficient and growing complexity.  

Most requests often throw process to the wind and are expected asap due to senior management focus.

Referrals are generous, if they do not cheat you out of the cash by hiring your referral as a contractor.

You are instructed to freeze your personal investment accounts and must verify all trading activities through request.

employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank
employeer_pros:
Insurance was alright
PTO (you’re going to want it) and sick leave is generous 
WFH at times
People are generally nice as individuals 
Could pretty much wear what you wanted
employeer_cons:
Where to begin...
Most teams are very political, raises and promotions are promised but not always given. People that are obvious underachievers are promoted to very senior positions. It’s all about who you know, and it’s every man for himself. 
Most managers micromanage. Employees work the best when a manager is not breathing down their neck. 
There are way too few bathrooms. Be prepared to walk to another building at times. No joke. 
The on-site cafe is expensive for what you get. 
Some teams are worked like slaves, especially people here on visas. 
Lots of work is driven from non-Cary sites by program directors who have no idea what they’re doing or how things in Cary are ran. 
They don’t tell you this before you start but personal investment trading is heavily restricted and is so much so that it’s pretty much impossible to actively invest or have any say in your own personal trades. 
Layoffs and talk of restructuring have become daily discussion topics among employees.
Grad program is a total joke. The London experience may be nice but you’ll always be “a grad” to everyone and that isn’t a great title to have years after the program has ended. 
Do yourself a favor and stay far away from DB Cary.

I was hired by a team and was told not to worry and just chill while the projects will get budgeted. Left for another employer and felt alive again. I realized I learned very little at this Bank.

employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: They lure candidates in with good pay and benefits
employeer_cons: Where to begin, you could quite seriously write a dissertation on the poor career quality at this place. I have been in the Jacksonville office for 4 years and have seen countless scenarios of amazing performers being turned down for the ONCE A YEAR promotion process (no you cannot be promoted outside of this annual process) to Associate/AVP etc due to politics and department caps, yet absolute garbage employees being hired for Associate/AVP externally. Your entire job here is soul sucking because you spend all day every day fixing "breaks" between systems that the company is too cheap to properly implement. There is no IT here, only clerks in India with a poorly written manual and a manager demanding they close out the work ticket. Constant reorgs trying to figure out how to fix the myriad of issues yet they only serve to give certain people promotions while the others suffer and are left confused as to who they report to. At the end of the day you just have MORE bosses. Toxic work environment where the managers won't even talk to you or acknowledge your existence unless you quit, then they get upset because once again they have to go through the painful round of hiring a candidate which due to company bureaucracy takes between 3-4 months. If you are applying here don't give notice until just before your start date or you could go without a paycheck for months. A lot of people just quit the department to go to a competitor in town BEFORE bonuses were even paid out, that speaks for the desperation to leave and the sub par quality of bonuses. There is zero recognition for hard/above and beyond work because either your manager will take credit or simply no one cares. Once again only those favorites will get a promotion. Complete mismatch between companies stated values and actual quality of work. The department also makes the foolish mistake of only having one person trained on a unique role so that if you decide to move internally you will be stuck training your replacement for months on end, or if you quit they beg you to train your external replacement, who won't start for months.....Maybe other departments are okay to work for but certainly not product control or whatever they decided to name themselves today. If you are a manager elsewhere looking to hire a DB employee don't look down on the fact that someone here hasn't been promoted, chances are they deserved to be many times over, DB just doesn't promote promotions.... You can't even begin to explain how poor the work environment is here, you just have to witness it. Or maybe ask around.....

employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time for less than a year

Regular firing at least twice per year, no matter what you are doing. Worst place for H1s.

employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: The people are generally nice to work with and work life balance for the most part is really good.  Most of the Center Management is good.
employeer_cons:
The Total Compensation (TC) speech you get when you join is a true load of BS, especially now that the largest part of that TC component is the bonus and that was cut last year and is well below the discussed TC was 3 years ago when there was a salary assessment and promises were made. The bonus is not really in the plans any longer for IT.  New management is of the opinion if you are just a cost center then you should not get a bonus.  Those in Germany are lucky as they are protected by the German Workers Council and get the bonus they we promised in the TC discussions.
Some Directors on site have no clue and generally don't care as long as they don't have to really do anything or talk to you, then everything is just fine. Dealing with some of the Managing Directors around the company is like dealing with spoiled children.  They don't really care either, only care about their bonus and stay out of their way.

review_title: Not a place for tech guys
employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: Vacation days and people are being friendlyhere are the only thing I can come up from head.
employeer_cons:
Clearly from the pros, if a company's pro is just the vacation days and people being friendly, then it must be something wrong. 

Green card policy is a promising policy that dose not like to happen. There are some people does start their green card application process, but there are more people that have never been given a clear answer, no matter from HR or manager.

Too many excellent people left and left a bunch of mediocre people or someone just doing social or reading news all day. This is a perfect example for "Dead sea effect". Google Dead Sea effect software you will know the meaning. 

Promotion is a fun part if you really consider about it. Social with people and let everyone know you is the key part instead of working hard. 

Technology stack here is terrible and the same to guys who is operating it. You can see technology was no longer used more than 15 years ago. Platform is not reliable . Even your daily service like Jira , bitbucket will also have daily access issue. 

People being friendly does not mean that they have the qualified skills for the job.  Then it will be your turn to suffer it. Bad code,  awkward tool developed,  bad story description. And then it's your fault that you are being so slow.

review_title: Cary  Location is just a begging bowl to NY and London  - A cess pool of H1B's
employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros:
Acceptable salaries but still below it's industry.
Flexible Work 
Good Benefits
employeer_cons:
Too many to list. Here are few...
You will dread  getting up in the morning and coming to work

Projects are mostly concentrated at strategic locations like NY / LON.  Cary will have leftovers menial work !!

Political cesspool - your advancement is pretty much at the mercy of someone in NY.
If you can be a good boot-licker and do whatever is been told to do like a good dog you have a life here !!

Jobs are not based on your experience , but on the needs of short term projects.

Funds are squandered elsewhere , Penny wise Pound foolish !!

Pretty much you just have to pimp yourself   every day to NY or London 

Manager's care less about your growth, and want their cut at the end of their year safe-guarded. 
Performance measurement is based on whims and fancy of someone in NY / LON. it's PMS for you on a daily basis.

Projects have horrible track records and you will just be thrown in to pool of sharks who are protecting their own interests.
Cary upper management   will conveniently  stay out of the picture and will show up to capitalize on your fruits at the end of the year.  If things have failed, you will all be set to be the  goat / sheep ready for execution.

Layer and Layer's  of VP positions  with no real Business or technical Knowledge to support the team. In fact, VP's  are  meeting facilitator and nothing more.  Front desk Admin can do the same job. Setup meetings !!

review_title: Avoid or at least get a contract
employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 8 years
employeer_pros:
There are a lot of good, smart people working at DB.
Interesting deals and structures being done.
Still a great name to have on your resume.
employeer_cons:
There is an overall culture of bowing down to senior management, like they're kings and queens.  Nobody is willing to push back.  
The ranks of senior management change constantly, and with each change comes a new host of friends and cronies from other financial institutions, each one with their own visions and ideas.  
No single restructuring or idea is given enough time to gestate to see if it will even right the ship.  Before long, the person behind it leaves or is fired / laid off, and then the process starts again.  
Compensation is a nightmare - get a multi-year guarantee or be prepared to get zeroed out when the bank determines it needs cash more than you do.

review_title: Go elsewhere if you want a good job in Finance
employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: Pays you a lot for relatively easy work; not too much competition/pressure from other coworkers
employeer_cons: Subpar deal flow; culture focused on retention/they are unsupportive of anyone doing anything else

employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
You can gain valuable experience very quickly, if you end up on the right project and have some amount of chutzpah.

There are definitely still a few smart people left in the technology division. If you are fortunate enough to work with them, you can learn a lot.

Excellent benefits, including 20 days of PTO and bank holidays.

Recruiters will smell blood and constantly try to poach you on LinkedIn.

As people get fired/laid off/quit, you can take on their responsibilities and grow quickly (although you shouldn't expect a title change or raise).

Work/life balance is. . . acceptable. . .  mostly. . .
employeer_cons:
Few, if any, opportunities for upward mobility. You become eligible for promotion every two years. Because of stack ranking, you are unlikely to get a promotion, even if you have performed well. Performance reviews are based more on the visibility of the project you have been assigned and other useless optics, meaning that it often doesn't even matter if you go above-and-beyond and deliver a high quality solution.

A little more weekend work than I'm comfortable with. All too often, poorly written and difficult to maintain code. Lack of operations automation leads to time consuming manual processes, badly damaging your productivity.

Your compensation does not stay in sync with your market value. Your market value as a junior developer will grow exponentially, while your compensation at the Bank will remain at a standstill. This is true even for people who receive the highest performance ratings. By the time you are eligible for promotion AND get adequate performance reviews for it, your market value has likely increased 100%, but your raise has been capped at 25% at best.

employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros:
People!  People, People!
In my two and a half decade long career I've come across many huge companies as a consultant, of course, and would never choose to join.  This on is different.  The people here, each and every one, are just down to the ground decent human beings.
The company takes care of it own.  
This is one of those families one normally never leaves.
employeer_cons:
A long, hard, unforgiving stream of bad luck, fines and repetitional damage.  And for our industry reputation is everything.
Also, despite the fact that all of us are great people we tend to collectively cause each-other unnecessary grief.
The upper management has a clear understanding and viable vision to what needs to be done to right the ship.
The contributing mice are all experts in their respective domains.
Nevertheless, top to bottom, the message is often lost or distorted in transaction or propagation.
The overall culture is healthy but the middle-tier mentality is archaic.
The core values campaign in well put together and slowly produces results - keyword is slowly.

employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: Getting a biweekly Paycheck is the only pro.
employeer_cons: As a risk management professional at DB , I've recently seen a mass exodus of talent due to several reasons, forgo of bonus compensation, authoritive management that are making  key  decisions that ensure a non collobrative working environment, artificial layers of management that add zero value, inexperienced management that don't know or understand risk processes that they are leading, using top tier consulting to design processes and then once they are gone going back to inefficiencies, hiring friends to do risk management with zero experience, inability to execute risk management. I can go on and on.... In terms of values this  is the only place that allows a manager with multiple HR complaints on treatment of women, making antisemetic comments, gay comments, demoralizing and  treating staff unprofessionally, spending millions on the top consulting firm,  works 9-5 and adds zero value, hiring resources that only work 200 - 400 hours a year. Only at DB can someone get away with this.  I guess DB allows people that are connected to the top to get away.

review_title: don't relocate with them as a voluntary expat
employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 10 years
employeer_pros:
work life balance is amazing, especially if you work in Frankfurt. Even in NYC work life balance is better than in London
They tend to get good talent so you will frequently work with bright people and it's a great way to grow.
employeer_cons:
Your career is tied to how well your manager likes you. if he packs and leaves, will be hard to advance
biggest downside is that HR isn't honest about important topics when relocating and offer zero assistance to acclimate for dependents. They also tell you that they don't offer full or half expat packages, only voluntary expats at AVP level which is not true
another big downside is their tech stack. They hire a bunch of incompetent cheap indian labor at support which means if you are a developer or business analyst, you will bang your head against the wall alot
indian managers in tech hire indians, despite if candidate is competent or not and have no problem spending thousands sponsoring green cards, it's pretty bad

review_title: Depressing !! Needs serious and urgent revamp.
employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: Competitive compensation, Brand name, Global presence
employeer_cons:
Depressing is the only word that comes to mind while sharing my more than 6 years of experience with this company. Despite being a high performer, there is no scope for growth. DB (especially Cary location) is a big NO NO for people with talent. In fact, they are the most unsuited species for its culture. Most of the power controls are in London and NY and they have vested interests in not letting Cary grow. Someone with good potential is targeted, mistreated, given worthless work and eventually forced to quit by exercising their political might. Most of the management (Directors & VPs) are undeserving loyalist who are only rubber stamps, taking orders from their bosses in NY or London and in return they survive the job (and even get promoted). This is helped by the HB2 hiring freeze and the bank's cost cutting measures which limited the growth in Cary. The technical architects (most of them controlling from London & NY) are highly incapable to even designing basic systems but are given a free hand because of their proximity to those who matter at the cost of quality. You can even find vendors architects & managers dominating and mistreating FTEs only because of support they hold from the powerful. Most of the applications in the bank are outdated and badly designed to handle today's needs. The HR and the senior management is well aware of this but has done nothing except for mentioning it in a couple of town halls & interact sessions. On the contrary, starting last year, even the authority of deciding the recognition award & promotion candidates in Cary was given to London & NY panels. This was a final nail in the coffin for Cary's sovereignty to retain good talent and do what is good for them.
To conclude, the overall atmosphere in the bank is highly political and counterproductive where talented new joiners will only add to a mass of frustrated zombies found everywhere throughout the centre now-a-days.

review_title: Good firm but can be better
employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 10 years
employeer_pros: Great pay and work is challenging if you land the right role
employeer_cons: No work life balance.  Limited internal mobility where its not encouraged. Have too many systems where you spend too much of your time on administrative tasks.  Prime example of patching a problem versus designing a solution.

employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: It can be a means to an end, but not to the level of other bulge bracket investment banking platforms
employeer_cons:
The franchise is completely unstable, and has degraded over the last few years.  You will not even get a meaningful investment banking experience due to senior turnover in the last few years in core verticals (Healthcare / TMT), ongoing litigation concerns, and an inability to compete or attract talent.  Your seat is absolutely not guaranteed.

You WILL be expected to work investment banking hours with an investment banking attitude.  You will work for unambitious, incompetent managers that have no genuine care for your development (or sanity).  The stock's not undervalued; it's just actually that crappy of a platform.  I wish you the best of luck if you commit to DB, because you will certainly need it.    

Cons (bulleted):
- Bureaucracy and face time
- Horrible hours that are detrimental to mental and physical health
- Incompetence and lack of leadership at mid level (Associate & VP) 
- No meaningful deal flow or professional development
- Massive turnover and layoffs at all levels (incl. junior levels)

employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: Thank goodness for my coworkers.  I would've gone crazy a long time ago.  An atmosphere like this allows the malcontents to find each other.
employeer_cons: This company is so big that EAs are just used to manage calendars, book meetings and submit expense reports.  Before the ban on travel (due to cost cutting measures) I used to get to do that too but no mas as of the past year.  Information is disseminated via gossip, not discussions with managers.  So many long term employees are just milking the teat - "working" from home, hiring consultants to do their job, not being held accountable for little, yet important things, like not responding to emails.  The IT Helpdesk is a disaster because no one actually wants to follow through with anything.  All of the in-house systems are counter intuitive so much so that I think they were designed to eff with people.  The offices are run down and borderline gross - there is always a light bulb out somewhere - and the people in the Jersey City office do not dress professionally (to say the least).  Any office non-EU is treated like a red-headed stepchild and there is an air of superiority wafted over from The Fatherland.

employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
Base salary, benefits, and 401k are top tier in the local market. Great location on Weston, solid cafe and gym on site, near greenway that connects with lots of trails. Bonus calculation was overhauled this year, last years was decent even in a rough patch for the bank. 

Software dev tooling greatly improving YoY, catching up (but not there yet) with modern practices. Moving faster than most SIFIs I would imagine.

Lots of thorny problems to solve with code, and the average caliber around you is quite high. Site represents many business lines and infrastructure functions.
employeer_cons: Paperwork during onboarding and paperwork getting a project started. Paperwork at deployment time. Paperwork getting your machine configured.

review_title: Staff Augmentation!  Come here to be bored.
employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: There's a free fitness center.  There's a cafe.  You get lots of vacation.  In some teams, you can do absolutely nothing, work 5 hours a day and go home.   If you are a mediocre developer, if you can get onto a team on the second floor, you might have a long career there.  Bonuses used to be good.  Salaries are good.  Insurance is good.  If you can put up with it working here, you'll have a good chance to be poached by a different company.
employeer_cons:
The office in Cary is filled with incompetent senior managers.  The least competent is at the top, followed by the management team.  Why?  Because they're cast-offs, or imports from elsewhere.  The ones in banking don't understand software development, and the ones in software are the people fired from middle management of other companies.  

This is honestly a dead-end if you want a career.  They talk about "expert path" for technical people which doesn't exist, at least not in Cary.  You will have no autonomy as all the decisions are made in London and NY.  Your senior manager is put in place by those same teams nervous about hiring outside of the hubs, so his job is just to work you until you quit and not to make any noise such as picking good software or practices.  Your failure provides them cover to not transfer jobs from their location.  They have never promoted anyone in Cary to a senior position- the last three directors weren't even from other Deutsche Bank locations; they went outside the company instead of promote one of the more than 100 existing managers or senior developers.  There is a serious flight of talent- other companies are easily able to poach people who are competent, able to work under pressure, and worth every penny of their salary.  Speaking of which, you used to get a bonus for all the downsides mentioned above.  No more.   It depends on the performance of the company  to get a maximum of 4%.  Take a look at the stock and you'll see how unlikely that is.    Diversity is overdone- protected groups can't be fired, and no one cares to take the time to hire good talent, they just want to have bodies to fill their hiring quotas.  The center head stood up in front of the employees at a town hall and said he's going to hire 50% women. What happened to equal opportunity hiring?   Oh and the fitness center and cafe mentioned as "pro" are just 'meh', but I had to say something nice to fill in that box.  Which is what you'll do for several hours a week- mandatory training classes for financial stuff which you'll never use as a developer but bureaucracy rules.  The HR team is horrible- they live in a little private area, through a card-key door, so you can't interact with them.  If you ask them a question, they'll reply with "call the hotline'.  Everyone desk is a 'trading desk', meaning they've crammed people into huge open areas with the same double-monitor and phone on the side of the desks with employees 5-wide and back to back.  Even call centers have more room.  They've got 800+ people in one building that other residents of the office park have closer to 300 in theirs.  If you need time to concentrate on working out a difficult debugging or clever software solution: give up.  The noise level doesn't allow it (*See working late or weekends comment).  This sardine-like setup also has an unfortunate characteristic of if someone skips a shower, everyone knows it.

review_title: Not Terrible, but Not So Good Either
employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank
employeer_pros: Right now the only thing that keeps me there is the benefits. I mean, who wouldn't love 5 weeks vacation? Good location in Lower Manhattan. The company is interesting and it is working hard to get out of its difficulties.
employeer_cons: While it's a plus that the company is working to get out of its difficulties, one of the cons is that the culture is what will ultimately keep the company from getting out of its problems. There is an incredible mix of cynicism and arrogance within the company along with a great deal of inefficient processes. Everything functions way too slowly at Deutsche, from the hiring, the on-boarding process, and just getting people to respond to emails. There are also way too many people with their tacky headsets listening in on conference calls. Well, it has been my experience that meetings and conference calls are perhaps the worst use of time. Meetings have a time and place, but they should not be excessive and should not replace actual productivity.

The so called architects or managers do not have idea about the current technologies and are not open to any new idea/suggestion and feel threatened, Most of the managers in NY really treat really bad, yes this is true. The same goes with their preferred vendor who's not ready to share knowledge and would treat you like an enemy...
 The recruiters may promise you many things like green card processing/perks/work from home etc and after joining the company you'd get a shock !.. most of the recruiters are contractors who use companies email id and give you impression that he/she is from HR, do not fall for it.
I know at least 4-5 people who left the company in first 3-6 months that speak about the culture and environment which is very political.

review_title: An enjoyable experience in Cary NC

employeer_pros:
Trying very hard to cultivate an environment and culture that was friendly and exciting to software developers.
Diverse workforce.  There were people from all parts of the world working there, and covering the age and gender spectrum.  Made for a very interesting and fun work environment.
Front line managers were supportive.
Lots of projects, and mobility within the Cary location was encouraged.
Competitive salaries, bonuses and benefits.
employeer_cons: In my short time there, it seemed to me as if the software center in Cary was growing quite rapidly, that is, experiencing growing pains.  In the time since I left, I have heard that the culture has changed.  That the banking people have lost a little patience with the process of creating an effective software center, which may have been a result of rapid expansion I witnessed.

employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: If there are pros for the firm,  it's few and far between.   The best thing about the New York office is a small pocket of employees who are new to the firm that actually try to make a difference.   While they are a small force,  the frustration increases day by day.   It is a common to say "we're up a creek without a paddle".
employeer_cons: Two words can pretty much summarize the firm -  accountability and fragmentation.  The culture,  at least in the NYC office,  is one of political finger pointing which lead to a lack of accountability by mid-level and senior managers.   This lack of accountability even for simple concepts such as  "best practices" is affected by this culture.   This also leads to fragmentation - everyone out for themselves instead of helping to improve the culture and the current state of the firm.

review_title: Lot's of chances to fix items which is a good thing!
employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank  for more than 8 years
employeer_pros:
- Great people
- Work life balance is recognised
- Local engagement is open and management are eager to show visibility.
employeer_cons:
- Global dynamic can be discouraging.

employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: There are a lot of opportunities to stand out, and there is much redundancy and bad code code to fix in this industry, as well as a surprising amount of manual Excel-drivel processes to convert into software applications. Good place to improve your skills at things like backend Java.
employeer_cons:
Horribly bureaucratic place to work. You are told when to come in, how to dress, how to conduct your meetings. You spend an obscene amount of your day obtaining approvals to deliver your code from people you will never meet. You are surrounded by people who afraid to speak up because they are on Visas. 

It is apparent that kissing up to superiors is common. If you actually accomplish something good, your managers acts as if it's no big whoop; if you are slightly late, they are all over you. They think that pointing out faults is "mentoring and coaching". You see managers telling their employees exactly how to do something, even though they are professionals who can figure it out. I'm one more than one occasion, I was upset that my manager was talking to me like I was a little kid.

On some teams, work from home is discouraged so there's less flexibility than at other places. There are no offices or cubicles, though the workspace is nice and resembles that of a startup.

Although some people are happy because they got started on a good team, your experience will vary with what team you end up on. 

If you come from a technology company proper, you may not like it here (unless the work you did there was boring). Bonuses have traditionally been good, but now this will change due to recent moves by the company.

employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time

employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank  for more than a year
employeer_pros:
Great flexibility in work-life balance. Working hours tend to be flexible, and employees are very accommodating to non-work commitments and activities. 

Great benefits. Health, dental, and vision plans are excellent. For a company in the US, there are lots of vacation days (over 4 weeks). 

Very good networking opportunities. There is a wealth of groups which do all kinds of fun activities. Groups meet regularly and it's an excellent way to get to know coworkers and make office connections.

The location. The Research Triangle Park area of North Carolina is a great area to live in.
employeer_cons:
Frustrating experience dealing with work computers and tech programs/tools. The computers are really locked down and it's often difficult to find the right tools for the job that aren't years out of date (I've seen this process improving, but slowly). There is little flexibility in choosing your tools for any particular technical task (it's not an option to install what you like). GitHub is blocked for most people.

Abundance of middle management. I've been on a team consisting of half managers and half workers. Certainly not every team is like this, and it's probably a result of being a large place.

There is a severe lack of technical knowledge among large amounts of employees (working in a software development environment). Many people aren't skilled enough to do their jobs well. One example: a manager on my team doesn't trust automated regression testing (they are not technically knowledgable about the development process) so even though we have a fully automated regression testing suite, people are required to *manually* test everything in releases before managers will approve the release, soaking up large amounts of time and resources. Knowledge of the basics should be expected, as it's a software development center. As a developer, is can be extremely frustrating to deal with so many people who don't know a thing about coding or development or computers at all, but are still supposed to work in a technical job.

Recognition and compensation is often largely tied to who you know, and less about how much of a difference you make. Of course, many people received what they deserved or even more, but for every person I know has been compensated/promoted fairly, I know another who was not at all compensated what they should have been. Which position you find yourself in isn't predictable.

employeer_pros: Obtained a lot of good knowledge. Great exposure to markets, products, and large corporate firms. I also made a lot of great life long contacts.
employeer_cons: Great if you're in the front office, terrible for the rest of the firm. Technology was terrible. Everything outsourced. The employees in India had no idea what they were doing and we spent half the time cleaning up messes they created with big clients due to communication problems,etc. I worked 60 + hours a week. I was promoted and took a pay cut to $53,000 annually since I was no longer eligible for overtime. I asked for a $2,000 raise and was told no, but they'd give me a corporate phone (which made no sense). Left the firm shortly thereafter.

employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: Only big firm in Jacksonville in IB. Great place to start and looks good on your resume. Short commutes to work, which is rare because most big banks are in big cities. Plenty of networking events to meet colleagues whether it is sports teams or happy hour socials (HH not paid for by DB, don't get your hopes up).
employeer_cons: (From the back office prospective) Managers will block you from moving to different groups because they don't want to have to replace you. You are not eligible to be promoted unless you receive 2 "Very Good" ratings in a row but senior management tells managers not to rate anyone above "good" unless they are years over due for a promotion. They know they have a monopoly on the industry in Jax so they are not too worried if you leave unless you run a team. VPs provide no help with Career advancement but are shocked when you leave (they assume no one has anywhere else to go in Jax). If you have series license prior to working at DB they will not sponsor you unless it is required for your job. The "paying for your MBA" line is a scam. They won't. Every young person in the BO is trying to make it to the FO. Very slim chance as they have a pipeline to Vanderbilt to fill all entry level jobs in FO.

Everybody is president , vice presidents and managers.. too less people who really work.. so of course work pressure... That's what managers are for right? Make tech slave labor work. or how else managers will get big bonuses?

Their new policy is to lure tech guys from other countries or other states to leave their good jobs dreaming big bonuses and peaceful life , come to this remote location of Cary...then make them work like slaves. Hire one senior tech guy and then hire four beginners so that this experienced guy will actually teach the beginners everything and even DO their job... as they are "no-vice".. so make sure you are not that "experienced guy"

This is not a bank. It's a bank's IT development center. So basically we develop applications for bank. So it works like a IT shop with all the crap that comes with it....

Every body ready to cut your throat to get anybody out of his bonus way. Everybody looks like in pressure and panic state.
If you are looking for great work atmosphere and peaceful life where you can work and do some innovative work then DON'T come to this Cary Development Center.
Only join this center , if you just want good pay and bonuses...but you should be ready to take this much stress, panic , and ready to be micro managed by omnipresent managers.

employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros:
Pay was better than any other place in the area.

Benefits were really great.
employeer_cons:
Senior management is playing the politics game and you are not a part of it. They tell you one thing to your face and turn around and mumble the opposite into their headsets.

Your reviews are also politics-driven and don't have anything to do with your actual performance. Get a bad review, you can't advance for another 2 years.

Work/life balance means zilch if you aren't management. Your managers will happily work from home 3 days a week and take whatever days off they please, but you are out of luck and get talked out of taking off.

DB's"Values" are just its way of making itself feel good, they mean nothing in daily practice.

My specific team's managers lied to us about holiday compensation, in order to cut costs and deceive us into taking less money on holidays we were required to work. 

DB is a sinking ship, don't bother.

employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank  for more than a year

This company offers good benefits as well as a month of pay vacations plus 10 holidays. 
The bank is going through a transformation in which it is investing in technology to digitize the bank. As a developer is a very interesting moment to be in this company if you want to learn new technologies and get involved in green field projects.
employeer_cons:
The demand for new applications and tools is bigger than the people they have available at this point which ends up with heavy workloads for employees.
It is not easy to grow here, the policies to grow are very restrictive, also there are no increments in salary unless you move to the next  band.

employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 8 years
employeer_pros: The people were great, but we were all stressed recently. Lots of options to move internally if you are proactive and work hard. Like any large organization, understanding how to get things done and knowing who is who is a major element of success. I had several great bosses and colleagues, we made it through many challenges as a team. I consider them great friends, period.
employeer_cons: The company itself is going through major changes still remaining from the 2007-2008 financial crisis. Some business units and departments will thrive, and others will shrink. Do you own homework to evaluate the opportunity for yourself.

employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time for less than a year
employeer_pros: Their benefits are amazing. Excellent vacation time off, sick time, medical and additional benefit most companies do not offer. You will be amazed. Pay is excellent for cost of living in Jacksonville, FL.
employeer_cons: No work life balance period. You receive a lot of time off but you can not use it because you will alway be at work except for manatory time off. You mostly be a slave to this company with extremely long hours year around with no breaks. Training is provides but you so much to learn in a short period of time so take extremely good notes because after that you are on your own. Mainly because everyone is busy trying to get their work done and cover themselves.  Management is no help they are too busy themselves to help you or on vacation. If you decide to go to finance reporting don't unless you have no life or family and you love extreme stress. New York make all the calls for Jacksonville. Every thing is manual. Much time is use to manipulate several reports to get a result. The left hand does not know what the right hand is doing but are held responsible for some one you have no idea had their hand in the process. IT is no help also you are responsible if you computer is not working or if you don't have the correct program to do your job regardless of how many time you try to contact IT. Even if you have years of experience this is not like any other job. Before you take this job ask good questions. As certain departments are better then others. If you don't ask they will not tell you.

employee_role: Former Employee - Manager- Midlevel (Associate to Assistant Vice President)
employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 8 years
employeer_pros: New CEO hopefully can turn things around.
employeer_cons: Poor management structure. Upper management is not close to the ground. Review process is obsolete and can be bias at times. Matrix management set-up is inefficient, upper management is more concerned about the bottom line than people (e.g. push back on a 1K increase for new hire). Many promises to deliver change but limited to no tangible results. Senior managers lack people development skills and are largely SME's promoted to positions based upon task knowledge and not key leadership attributes. During the review process, managers miss the big picture and tend to focus on 1-2 small mistakes instead of the year at hand all while overlooking their lack of leadership and involvement.

employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than a year

employeer_cons: Administrative and Executive assistants are treated as "old school" secretaries instead of ASSISTANTS.  A Bachelor's Degree in Business means nothing to the executives who you work for.  As far as they are concerned you are there to pour their coffee and order/pick up their lunch, aside from standard administrative duties.  They give the assistants way too many people to assist.  I for one was assisting two department heads and all their staff (about 14 people.)  They gave me a million reasons why I didn't qualify for their tuition reimbursement.

The company has no glass ceilings and growth to many different career paths.

employeer_cons: My only complaint is about the organizational chart.  DB is a global organization but management is not always local - seeing the people you work with and work for would be really helpful.

employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: Diverse, brilliant talent pool, charitable donation matching, lots of vacation days and sick days. Work life balance is OK depending on your department. Lots of extracurricular activities and programs, lots of diversity and employee resource groups. Can be a fun atmosphere, depending on department/colleagues.
employeer_cons: Recruitment process is misleading. They promise 20% bonuses to get you to relocate to Jacksonville, then you are given 2% during bonus season. Unacceptable. Promotions are given to those who brown-nose and not necessarily the most competent. No collaboration between departments, people can be very arrogant and unhelpful, forgetting we are all on the same team. Management is quick to point the finger at the peons when things go wrong. The vacation days are great in theory, but they are of no use if you never get approved to take the time off because of the workload. Some departments have no direction or clear vision/strategy. No career path in Jacksonville because most of the roles are operational.

employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank

employeer_cons: Everything - was hired and told my job was going to be completely different than what I was doing. When I got there, they had nothing for me to do. For months I sat there not learning anything. The ONE responsibility I was given could have been done by an intern yet Senior Management wouldn't let you control it. They are overly involved in EVERY THING yet don't get anything accomplished because too many people are involved in one thing and no one can agree on it. They are only worried about their annual reviews. ALSO no promotions for 3  years. Dumbest rule I've ever heard.

review_title: They take care of you, but its a slow moving mammoth
employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 3 years

employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
It was said that you don't have to love your company but most people do leave the work because of the management.
Well in this company that is very fundamental that you may or may not enjoy the work you get but 50% of management has bad attitude. Most original people was brought in and still there because they were hired without any experience in IT/Finance/ or project management just to fill seats.
Many people got pink slips in past because they raise voices, asked for better work, and if they don't able to fire them then provide a bad review so employee need to leave the company. Unfortunately, even when user tries to find another job within the VPs will not provide good review and will not bother to help you.
employeer_cons:
This is the place you will learn how to play politics staying among people who are not capable of running the groups but by chance they got VP and director titles. You will have to do lot of buttering to VPs in order to survive in this place otherwise just doing your job good will not take you anywhere.
VPs are not able to share or i should say they are not capable of providing the team goal, what value proposition they want to do deliver each year.
Uneducated VPs who came from old school like nortel and some brought from London do not share good feedback and make one of their assistant from the team, praise them only and keep other members under them. These VPs are not able to run self organize teams, they don't know how to motivate teams, how to find impediments and remove them, very ego rustic people work in this location. If i have option i will work elsewhere

employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time for less than a year
employeer_pros: Excellent pay and benefits.  Local center has a lot of fun activities (provided you have enough time in your schedule to participate) and supports diversity.
employeer_cons: I walked into a mess.  Senior leadership seems support unproductive and unprofessional behavior among the D ranks which is felt downwards throughout the organization.  This has been a career low.  I am thoroughly disappointed in the lack of maturity and unproductive atmosphere.  Shakeup in the senior ranks leave them scrambling to find sacrificial lambs.  This is not a direct reflection of the local leadership, but rather leadership in reporting lines sitting in other offices.

employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time
employeer_pros: Great home/work life balance. Work with some talented individuals who are pleasure to work with. Enormous amount of intellectual ability resident in this company. Convenient locations in NY and NJ. Great global atmosphere with teams cooperating across the globe.
employeer_cons: Pay is medium compared to other investment banks in the metro area. Bad morale based on all the changes/issues the bank is undergoing. Constant feeling of job being under threat due to constant reorganizing

employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank  for less than a year

employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: Atmosphere is very nice and everyone is very helpful. Lots of benefits that you get right on your start date, no 30 or 60 day waiting period for benefits. Training is abundant. Lots of cultural diversity and nice people to work with.
employeer_cons: To be promoted, you must obtain two consecutive years of "Very Good" or better rating. Sometimes, this is not dependent upon your performance, and is decided upon by way upper management on if raises are able to be given or not. You can only try to "transfer" laterally to a position with the same "title" as you, after you have been with the company for a year.

employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time

employeer_cons: Does not perform all of the same functions as the main NY office, which is a point of tension whenever brought up.

employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 5 years

employeer_cons: Lots of chaos. Outdated technology and policies. Cut-throat at senior levels and promotion process is painful. Less accountability and hard to get decisions made. The one thing constant is change! Salary is hard to get increased without a promotion anymore.

employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than a year

employeer_cons: Poor hiring practices. Deadlines are everywhere due to regulations. London calls all the shots.  If you're not from London, growth potential is limited. US offices are shadowed greatly by the larger hub offices. Employees don't stay long.

employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank  for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: Brilliant group of people, strong culture and diversity. Mostly everyone had an mba, phD, licenses. Lots of intellectual capital there. 20 vacation days. Small relocation bonus. Some opportunity for working remotely.
employeer_cons:
What good are all those days if you can never take them?
They promise 20% bonuses to entice you to relocate there, since there is next to NO talent in Jacksonville.  Then you get a 3% bonus. Don't fall for it.
Disorganized management at the upper levels. No opportunity for advancement. Bosses are indifferent to your efforts. No adequate direction in how to do your job so your efforts are wasted when you do your job and bosses make you start all over due to a new rule. Lots of politics and some annoyingly nosy team members. LOTS of turnover be it doesn't take long for the smarter people to realize morale sucks and leave.

employee_role: Current Employee - Assistant Vice President, Applications Developer
employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time
employeer_pros: Awesome benefits! Great pay! The Cary location is really investing in creating a community. There are employee engagement groups that work hard to make this a great place to work! I am working in cutting edge technologies and the company seems to want to invest in their employees and in employee retention. The office space is very nice including an onsite cafe and gym.
employeer_cons: There is less flexibility than in most tech companies I have worked for. At the Cary location, you can work from home on occasion, when necessary, but most people are in the office most days. It is a bank. As should be expected, there are security and process requirements that can impede your job efficiency.

employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time
employeer_pros: Mid-level professionals are quite talented and amicable.  Generally a stable place to work.  New management in Germany seems to be aware of many issues that have hurt the company in the past 5-6 years and may address some of the cons below.
employeer_cons: Poorly integrated IT systems.  US management is not given bottom line accountability and poor managers are rarely fired.  Heavy bureaucracy in Germany sometimes prevents things from moving forward elsewhere.  All this has resulted in missed opportunities.  Mid-level employees receive critiques from above and colleagues, but those above do not always receive feed back. Strong focus on fixed income could impact profitability.

employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time
employeer_pros: Deutsche Bank is a very international bank with colleagues from all over the world.  People are good to work with.  The bank provides good career mobility opportunities.
employeer_cons: Base salary is not competitive compared with other banks.  Benefits are not competitive compared with other banks.  Not much funding or budget for corporate perks

employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
Regardless of your level of experience in excel your skills will dramatically improve.

Endless coffee
employeer_cons:
Beware of any  positions with Reporting in the description or title.  These are old school "sweat shop" positions.

They will tell you that you may have to work more then 40 hours a week in the interview, but in reality you will be expected to work 60-to 80 hours a week including weekends.

You will most likely not be able to take a vacation because we were told that we would need three back-ups for our processes before an approval would be considered.  The turn-over is so high there is no chance of training three back ups. Zero family life balance.

Work is 99% excel driven data mining and data entry.  

If you can see your self sitting behind a computer doing data entry for 10 to 12 hours a day, never seeing the daylight and not being able to take a vacation - this jobs for you.

It is rumored that other departments are better - you will not be able to post for them for at least 2 years (If nothing has changed)

employeer_cons: With HQ in Germany, and the US HQ in NYC, the team environment was lacking.  This also resulted in limited visibility into corporate initiatives.  Top heavy org.

review_title: A cult of management dabbling in IT
employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank
employeer_pros: Higher bonuses than most competitors and good overall compensation.  Lots of vacation time.  Some really good talent and some good technologies to work with.
employeer_cons: The revolving door of senior managers coming and going is destroying any chance of delivering quality software.  Whenever stability in a project is approached, there is a re-org either within Cary or higher up globally, and everyone changes around.  New managers are brought in and given huge amounts of responsibility, but no accountability or clear goals.  They quickly realize they are unable to change anything and the normal response to this is to obsess about which tools will give them the best reports about which developers are slacking off.  A conversation about Jira vs HP ALM vs RTC ... AGAIN ... really??  But a conversation about Java 5 vs Java 8 is impossible for them.

review_title: It would be funny - if I did not work here. :(
employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
Pay is pretty good.  Certainly better than many of the staff deserve.
Plenty of vacation.
Private health care
A lot of jolly nice people. 
Some comical characters - faux new jersey gangsters adding a different dynamic to what you expect in a technology office.
employeer_cons:
In two words - Low Calibre.
Ineptitude runs rampant.
Low quality hiring low quality in abundance.
Center management woefully out of the depth and seem to be clueless about what we do.
Computers and kit last decade.  
Desktop support is laughably bad - usually resort to getting under the desk to fix ourselves.
"Agile" means something very different here: Lots of standing around whiteboards with posties.  Ceremony over intended purpose.
Town halls are a drag.  No relevance and must serve only the ego of the center management who's apparent understanding of technology is utterly tangental to anyone developing software this century.  Lots of side-way glances as we sigh WTF in unison.
Project delivery is shambolic.  Wins are rare as failure is accepted with a shrug.
Long-termers stay as they are payed above market rate.
Traditional relationship between low cost offshore and rich masters.  Unfortunately we are the former so are regarded as a call center in a third world country.
Lots of jolly nice people who should not be working in a technology office, but have created niches as "transition project managers"
Lots of gossip about the next (then the next) round of redundancies.  Apparently lots of people have more lives than cats.
Promotion seems to be linked to age.
% of staff are fired every year.  Candidates are selected through comical darwinism.  Secret meetings are called, their desks are cleared whilst they are in the "meeting", asta la vista.  Then another meeting is called by management to say firings have stopped, consider yourself lucky and get back to work fast.  They try to make this seem compassionate, but everyone is just pleased the wheel of (mis) fortune didn't stop with them.
Lots of back stabbing amongst senior management - all fighting to ensure nobody discovers how little work THEY do.  Usually the wrong person is whacked.
All of the above would make a great comedy show and that would be funny.  Living it is another story.

review_title: Decent place if you can navigate the red-tape, restructuring and politics
employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros:
Global bank with strong presence in USA, UK, Germany, Singapore. 

Depends on your team but you can achieve a good work-life balance. This place is ideal for middle-aged people who have families and want to go home at a reasonable hour. 

The technology division is very lenient regarding working from home and many really take advantage of this. 

The pay is decent but make sure you negotiate upfront because salary rarely increases unless you are promoted. Unlimited sick days. 
3-4 weeks vacation.  

With mounting regulatory pressures and tough competition, the bank is trying to reduce costs and increase returns for shareholders.
employeer_cons:
Total compensation (salary + bonus) has remained flat or even gone down for some. 

Promotions, even at the lowest levels, are becoming more difficult to obtain each year. 

Over the past few years, the Bank has implemented many cost cutting measures almost to an extreme (they do not even provide paper cups at the water fountain or coffee machine). 

Healthcare costs have steadily increased unless you go for a high deductible plan. 

Don't bother making business cards since the bank is constantly reorganizing and restructuring. Even though my job description hasn't changed much, my team has been renamed about 6 times in the past 4 years. 

Top talent has left for other banks leaving less intelligent workers behind.
