review_title: Easy on career, better work-life balance
employee_role: Former Employee - Assistant Vice President - Technology
employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
DBGT has great benefits packages, reasonable pay packages. 
The team I worked with in Cary was great.

Work hours were relatively manageable.
employeer_cons:
There are not enough resources for self learning. Very few CBTs available.
Relatively few trainings held in classroom as well, other than the ones pushed down from management.
DBGT is a separate legal entity - meant for software development for the bank. Downside, it got disconnected from the business and employees lack exposure to business knowledge and requirements, yet the organisation as a whole is just as regulated as the business, coz its still a bank. Makes it extremely hard to actually work and get ahead in your career. I have tried networking extremely well across the organisation, but DBGT has too many strategic issues, leading to a lot of internal politics to fight against, to get anything done.

review_title: It's a CURSE' to work at Deutsche Bank in Cary, NC (RUN AWAY)
employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
Global Financial business experience
Decent salary
Decent benefits
employeer_cons:
This DB location in Cary is like an offshore center within US. It's run and controlled by The management in London and New York who care less for people in Cary. Too much blame game, extremely unprofessional and chaotic work environment. They work you like a dog for not that great money. Very very unrealistic expectation. Too much drama to put up with. Extremely high bureaucracy and micro management. They have an Agile process for every project which is extremely stressful. Multiple meetings. Most of them are a waste of time. Too much of process which can get annoying at times. Most people here do not dress well. Doesn't feel like you're working for a big bank. It has a startup feel to it. Some people come to work in jeans, shorts, flip flops on all days.

Even if you have to take a vacation, it's not easy to get out as most projects are regulatory and they have to meet the timelines. 

Very poor middle management. Instead of pumping your Morale higher, some Managers bring your morale down. The Managers make sure that you don't even have a single minute of free time.

I've never seen such a stressful and bad work environment ever in my life. Some people are too rude and direct to work with. This is the worst company that I have ever worked with in my life. 

NEVER NEVER NEVER join this bank in Cary, NC.

review_title: Take the last train to Jacksonville
employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
The new facilities are quite nice and becoming increasingly spacious as people leave.
401k is ok compared to working for the government - though "real" technology companies are better.
Very slow pace may suit many.
Easy to hide if you are lazy.
employeer_cons:
Constant state of flux: Several high-profile departures this year leaving a vacuum for indecision and power broking.
No support for the center in wider DB - we are the butt of all jokes from our uk counterparts such as "Cary Cracker Jar", "Cary Creche", "Cary Asylum", "Pulled pork-heads", "DB-Rednecks".  This might be funny to you but we live here
No clear strategy - we answer to the newest whip in town.  The new whip is in Jacksonville so I guess this is where our jobs are going.
Low grade senior management team and dishonest/incompetent HR dept.
Town halls are rubbish - no charisma, no honesty and no action.
Tooling is poor and you cannot use anything not considered standard.

employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 3 years

review_title: Toxic Environment wouldn't go back even as last resort
employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: Not  one pro to list ...wish I could convert this into more space for cons
employeer_cons:
Everything about DB is a con

Management is absolutely horrible and they do not know the process flows or their employees roles and tasks. Reminds me of a sweat shop, they work you till the point of feeling sick. Minimum 60 hour weeks. Jacksonville location likes to bring VP's in from London and eliminate advancement. They come over here and all they care about is production at your expense.  They don't care that you have a life or a family.  

AVPs are under qualified and can not help or do anything. In transaction accounting if you ask the management something be ready to get a political I have no idea answer or a wrong answer that you will pay for dearly later. 

Managers like to whisper and gossip about employees and even mock and talk badly about them in front of team members. And if someone quits then they trash talk that person continuously. They blame you for leaving and say it's your fault but yet 80% turn over rate in 12 months tells you there is a problem. Human resources is completely useless they know the issues and do nothing. 

I could go a week and AVPs and VP's that you sit within 10 feet up and they don't acknowledge you or speak to you unless they need or want something. 

Be prepared to do 3-4 person workloads even workloads of higher ranks and not be compensated. I was given a role a pay scale higher with a title change and much more benefits and they told me your getting the job but we can't "promote you" you haven't been here long enough, prove yourself and in 2 years well"promote" you for the role you've been doing. 

This place is toxic and they do not care if you quit they trash you and replace you with someone less qualified. 

If you think your going to get trained your wrong. You will be given broken procedures if you get any and be expected to self train and be expected to make the procedure 100%

Was told you are aloud to ask questions but you can only ask a specific question one time. If you ask It again your faulted. 

My mid year review was to be done by a deadline in person but they ignored it and texted me at home at 8 pm saying please log in and except your review. I can't leave for vacation until you do. VP's don't even right the reviews they let under qualified AVPs do them with no clue as what to write. I could go on for days but I think you get the picture

review_title: Employer of last resort. Consider another industry.
employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: Exposure to many smart people. Fast computer. Good work from home flexibility. The time off policy, if you can use it, is generous. The resume line is nice too, for now. Very smart people are attracted to the DB brand so you get to work with them for a few months or a year or two before they leave, or until you do.
employeer_cons: Soft compensation. Tough industry. Unsustainable employment strategy. Lack of strategic direction. Ineffective HR. Lack of expertise: blind leading the blind. Confrontational behaviors, occasional bullying due to competitive rating system. (quiet people with alot of talent but who aren't aggressive don't really get much justice out of the bell curve rating scale) Promotions get held up due to HR not knowing what they are doing. Good people getting burned up. Napoleonic politics. Weak training. Long arbitrary hours and not due to actual needs, but usually due to bureaucracy and inefficiency. Weak technology implementation and SDLC.

review_title: Do Your Research on this Place!!!!
employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: I can't think of any......
employeer_cons:
I'm not sure if this is enough space but here it goes.  

This was the worst position I've ever had in my life!! It gets me worked up just thinking about it again.   For starters let's recap the whole experience. When I began I spent about 2 weeks on the phone with tech support trying to get my computer working with all the necessary programs with no help from managers or colleagues. 

I was given the work of 3 people and when I spoke to management about reducing the load due to stress I was told to manage my time better. This comment sent me through the roof. Others on my team always got their one hour lunch and left right at 5. However, I was there many nights after 8p.m. with none of my colleagues around. When determining who should do what on the team someone made a comment about my salary that I was making "Big Bucks" and more senior people than me were overlooked in being assigned certain tasks.

The salary wasn't much higher than my previous employer and I was actually making more money at my previous employer, but thought this would be a better opportunity but I was completely wrong. I felt like a fish out of water from day one and when I started getting the hang of things my tasks were increased substantially to make me fail.

review_title: A company with lots of opportunities, yet a hot mess to work at
employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros:
A world-class brand. Some great people. Truly a global bank offering lots of opportunity to work in various continents. Deutsche has beautiful buildings and good looking staff. Everyone is well dressed and professional. It offers world-class finance and banking operations. Opportunity to have exposure to people from all over the world.

Deutsche bank has a great social responsibility initiatives and is a leader in green energy buildings.
employeer_cons:
Technology is a hot mess, having grown through numerous acquisitions. Systems are outdated and dysfunctional. As a user, basic day to day tasks such as email, calendar, expenses and time off are a hassle to complete. As someone with administrative responsibilities, it is an extremely difficult environment to get anything done.

The management structure is a mess, with dotted lines all over the place. All decisions have to be approved by numerous people. It's clear that senior management distrusts lower level management to make appropriate decisions. The issue is made worse by the frequency with which new management is hired from the outside, who lack the necessary background / knowledge to make the appropriate decisions. The result is a complete inability to get anything done.

The place is a revolving door, at least in the regions.

It is extraordinarily political and almost impossible to get ahead by just quietly doing your job.  You have to promote yourself constantly which can be uncomfortable for introverts.

Lack of consistancy in process 
Lack of process
No real knowledge management to speak of.  You are told to look at the code and figure out what you need to know.
Heavy bureaucracy means it takes a long time to do anything.  The hiring process takes months.

review_title: The Good , The Bad and The Ugly
employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 8 years
employeer_pros: When I first joined Deutsche Bank  I enjoyed working for a firm that valued its people and the value that they added. Had some great colleagues while I was there.  I was able to move to a new position in just over 14 months and excelled in my new role.
employeer_cons: Was approached by a different department to take on a global role and after many discussions my manager and I agreed this would be a good opportunity, so I took the new position. I was in my new role about 1 month and I was immediately informed that they didn't want me to do the governance role that they approached me for. They wanted me to do things their way and disregard policy. Of course I didn't follow their request. Then when the annual reviews were given I was given a poor review. I approached HR and asked why my former managers review wasn't take into account especially since I was still in my former role for the first half of the year. I was told that only the new mgr review counts. So I then asked doesn't HR wonder how someone who has always been a top performer drop in 6 months to a poor performer.  They said they don't.  The writing was on the wall. In Sept 2012 I was informed that my role was being eliminated.

employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time

employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros:
If you're on the right team, everything is great. Mobility opportunities, advancement opportunities are plentiful as well - on the right team. Very easy to network with colleagues in other locations to build a personal network that is global. For a strong willed person, it is very easy to flourish.

On the right team, work life balance is perfect. You could not ask for better.

Compensation is great as well for the market, although it will need to be adjusted upwards over the next few years to account for new competitors.

Smart, talented people are the norm.

Very strongly defined set of company values.
employeer_cons:
Customer-centricity is the new push as a corporate value, but is little more than lip service on the ground. No KPIs have trickled down from the ExCo as to how this should be measured.

The organization as a whole is too top heavy. Constant emails from different ExCos about people we have no interaction with changing job roles and taking over responsibilities that aren't even obliquely related. This happens almost monthly, to no real benefit.

Constant re-orgs allow incompetent employees to hide and maintain their status. Little to no accountability for teams that manage vendors - the vendors always fail to deliver, and the teams managing them get away with it because of the constant re-orgs.

Tech projects are almost always top heavy. Too many people with no idea about what it takes to build a product involved in the process giving invalid opinions, trying to be the smartest person in the room. Too many meetings, too much design by committee. Projects run over budget and under deliver as a result. Business partners aren't held accountable for the failure and move on to new projects to continue the cycle of ruination.

Obstructionism by teams in other locations doing similar work is common. Land grabs for projects and people occur constantly with the re-orgs, allowing empires to be built. Middle management seems to solely be concerned with owning projects instead of delivering value.

employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 5 years

employeer_cons: The reason they are in Jacksonville is because they can get quality work at a lower price than in NY and Jersey and it's average financial services pay. It's very much a grind and long hours and can get quite confrontational.

Bonus caps, underpayment relative to other banks, and outrageous deferral structures means that DB will not be able to compete for talent.

DB is the only bank which has failed to make any effort to improve lifestyle for employees or even acknowledge the issue.

Summary: You will get paid more at all levels at any other major bank. Business is declining precipitously and morale is extremely low.

review_title: The axe continues to swing and we remain leaderless
employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
A few intelligent people
high comparable salaries
employeer_cons:
The center is in a constant state of flux of hire and mostly fire.  In the past year almost the entire leadership team has either been fired or departed and what is left is almost constant haggling amongst middle management to own teams and step into dead mens shoes, regardless of being qualified.

The bank has chosen a SAS import who is completely uninterested in what we are doing and creates authority through fear leaving most quaking and the rest kissing it.  Most of us are unclear how this guy does as we take all of our direction from the London domain leads.  I'm sure he is as nervous about his own position as we are so he is kissing his respected asses and not delivering utility down to us.  Then we have a hired a Chief Development Officer - what Development is this role responsible for and where is the proven calibre?

Our recent town hall said it all: we want to "reverse the pyramid" which means our management are fixated in adhering to organizational shape over finding the right people then incentivizing the good people to stay.  

This week a further 15 heads were culled, which followed similar exercises over the past 5 months leaving many scared about their future.  Why not take a look at why these people didn't achieve success and question whether the organization provides an environment where success is achievable without politics and back-stabbing??

I do not believe Deutsche Bank understands the locality or the technology profession.  Let's say it possibly did at one time, now this is in full reverse.  We started with a message of work/life balance, a table tennis table and a relaxed dress code and now the latter being recently stripped so we look nice for our new New York matrix managers who have no clue about what makes technology people tick.  North Carolina is not about double-breasted suits, politics and "greed is good" - if we wanted this we would get paid a lot more to live in New York.  

There are so many other technology companies to work for in Raleigh.  My entire team is talking aloud about interviewing elsewhere which means this place is heading south.

employee_role: Current Employee - Assistant Vice President - Middle Office

employeer_cons: The Cary location is largely considered a cost lowering place compared to the UK and New York offices. Hence, all the directions come from largely the UK with some from New York. Positions of authority are also reserved from folks who come from the UK with some for people here in the US. If you move from the UK, then you are in good shape, else you need to be part of a clique. It is not important to deliver results if you are in a clique. Politics and nepotism rule the day. Projects and management can change in a hurry. Most of the projects are maintenance projects with the technologies being rather ancient. The word "scrum" is used a a panacea without really understanding how to execute on it.

review_title: Started hopeful.  Good in parts.  Mostly disorganized, unsettled and political
employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
Being a bulge bracket investment bank in an area evolved for technology and pharm companies means it pays far more than the local area.  There has been some progress where certain applications are now led from the center, but the majority is still "augmentation" with NYC and London calling the shots.  

If you like constant change, then this is the place for you.  Frequent reshuffles and changes in leadership happen, so you could see this as an opportunity if you can stick it out.   Deutsche Bank is undergoing a large scale refactoring akin to the Final Solution, jobs are being created in low-cost centers like Cary, so this creates opportunity.  Promotion is possible - Keep your eyes open and turn up then you will get promoted and receive a fat bonus

It is undergoing some changes to the building, the environment is spacious with lots of walls to put post-it notes on.  There is now more meeting rooms than people - which is good.

Lots of communication from senior managers at the beginning and end of year.

A great choice of food trucks for lunch.
employeer_cons:
Cary does "BAU" and stuff that is either not difficult or interesting enough for London to want it.  It is not a "Technology Center" or a "center of excellence" it's just cheaper than working in London and we get the work when London is downsized.

The CTC, as it is now known, underwent significant growth in 2013, then is retracting again in 2014 with a hire-freeze and mass firing.  As the other reviewer mention its is a flailing investment bank and it has recently woke up and realized it has too many people and it is not making enough money to keep them.  Don't worry though, if you can code it will be a long way to get to you.

Little communication from senior managers outside of the beginning and end of year.

Forced ranking.

The hiring process is bad... and you wondered why you stuck it out.  The recruitment team were often to blame but the HR team must accept the majority.  Escalate and make enough noise, then HR wakes up - but why then?  Most of us need jobs for our families.  Make sure you are financially stable and able to take the time out to be on boarded otherwise you will find it V. STRESSFUL.

Agile adoption has become comical.  Even if we wanted it; the external bank thinks it is developer jumbo that can be overridden if they shout loud enough.  They let the agile coaches go, so our walls are full of stagnant yellow notes, toolboxes of avatars and broken dreams.  The place is awash with QA engineers, Scrum Masters and Technical Program Managers.  Lots of managers.  Pretty much everyone apart from coders.

Our town halls are always long and contains announcements about tools.  We have never seen the tools.

Did I mention the politics?  It is sickening.  No matter how much they pay the sugar I still have a bad taste.

When everyone's head is down the Bank will not make money.    All infrastructure functions have become dysfunctional due to budget cuts and outsourcing.

review_title: The worst place I have ever worked
employee_history: I worked at Deutsche Bank full-time for less than a year
employeer_pros:
Pay competitive.  Decent banking benefits.  401k, vacation, bonus.
Some decent people
employeer_cons:
The opportunity was to work as part of a "start-up" building exciting technology which will transform the bank.   The reality is completely different.  The "work" is mundane, soul destroying GWT development of payment systems within an oversized team with far too many managers who walk around like they own the place.

The technology stack is so far out of date - yet we are wedded to it because somebody, somewhere decided it was the right thing.  It is too 2005 and this is 2014.  Wake up!!! Suggesting anything else is pointless as our managers do not own the decisions or are scared to challenge anything.  

I stupidly moved from a real technology company where we had a purpose and the environment was pleasant.  I moved for the change in money and the oversold prospects..  I regretted every day since to the point I found another job.

The craziest thing is that everyone moans about how bad the political situation is and they put up with it for the money only.  This explains why the majority of staff are uninspired and lacking passion for the work.  The senior team are has-beens and are in no way visionary, even if they like to proclaim they are.  

Any interaction with London or New York feels unpleasant and they control the life-line by giving us just enough or hold a carrot by promising us new work, but only after they have chewed it out and moved onto the next thing.

The facilities are very poor.  The toilets are always smelly, the meeting rooms are scrappy and you have to drive to get food or a coffee.  

Zero training.  Agile in a day was pathetic and meaningless when the only work we do is death-marched.  

If we are singularly focused on metrics - take the metric for how many people are happy.

review_title: Be careful which division and team you choose to apply for.
employee_history: I have been working at Deutsche Bank full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: The bank is decent at recognizing high performers and promoting based on merit.  Depending on the group that you are in, work/life balance is achievable, however, if you are not working overtime you will not be seen as working hard enough.
employeer_cons: There is no singular corporate culture.  While this wouldn't necessarily be a bad thing, it results in vast inconsistencies in experience depending on which team, division, or even building you work in.  Unfortunately, if you find that you would like to transfer within the bank, management is able to prevent you from transferring for up to six months.

Good pay and benefits.  Good people on staff.  
Good pay and benefits.  Good people on staff.

Management in Cary is under pressure to show that they can do things quicker and better than has been done in the past, but this is at odds with the rest of the bank in the rest of the world, which works at its own speed. employeer_cons:
- Highly political environment: pick mentor(s) who are well-regarded and know their way around the organization
- Highly bureaucratic environment: need to go through a lot of hoops to get things done/approved; only gotten worse with onset of external regulatory forces (a lot tougher to get things done)
- Sharp elbows among colleagues: at the end of the day, everyone is out for themselves and wanting to maximize their comp at year-end.
(I should note that the above all all pretty common to most, if not all, investment banks)

Essentially the problem is a lot of Vertical Managers who should be in HR but are making decisions that they do not understand.
To move up in the organization, it becomes important to be on their good side, rather than do good work.

review_title: Coming to work here was the best decision ever.
employee_history: I have been working at Wells Fargo full-time for less than a year
employeer_pros:
The culture here is phenomenal. The message is all about how the people make the difference and the company is very focused on developing employees. 

The routines set in place to reinforce the behaviors are phenomenal. Resources available to leaders for improving coaching style are endless! They have even taken external leadership theories and incorporated those into the resources and training available. 

Highly engaged and talented people work here, making it a great place to network and grow.
employeer_cons:
Some systems are a bit antiquated, but to be honest I’d prefer that over flashy stuff that glitches out all the time. 

Time off is not very competitive, and it doesn’t increase with positions that have more responsibility, it only increases with years worked at the company. 

No fully comprehensive health plan, but they do offer a company funded HSA with one of the plans.

employee_history: I worked at Wells Fargo part-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: WF has great benefits. They're very helpful when setting up your benefits when you're a new hire. They value diversity--so if you're bilingual, your chances of getting hired increases. Their 2-weeks training program is exceptional. When I was first hired and told there was a mandatory 2-week full time training, I thought it was too much, but it really prepared me in the best way before they put me in a drawer by myself. Because WF was just under heat because of the scandal when I was hired, in my year and a half there I got two raises without asking for it because they increased the base-pay for everyone. Now, it's much higher than when I worked there.
employeer_cons: Unfortunately, your direct manager will have to tell you to do things that they might not agree with, because the person above their manager and so on told them about the changes. It's a huge corporation and you have to remember you are the bottom of the barrel. However, even though you're the bottom, you are expected to provide 100% excellent customer service because you are the face of Wells Fargo.

employeer_pros: Great benefits, especially for veterans or reservists
employeer_cons: I’ve found that few people, at least on my team, ever progress to higher roles. The few that have progressed were in their roles for 10+ years, and promotions seemed based on seniority rather than merit. There were many outside hires for higher level positions. When I requested consideration for a transfer to another role with higher pay in another department, my manager refused to give me her blessing, stating that my role on my current team was too important for me to leave, and that the team would struggle to replace me.

employee_history: I worked at Wells Fargo full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: Excellent benefits / prices for benefits ; in my location, there was room to advance - saw many people promoted from within; the underwriting software had some positive attributes in that it did a great job of dropping correct automated conditions with less editing than I do in Encompass ; pay was fair ; ability to work remotely a few days a week; regularly held underwriting meetings to keep abreast of policy changes. Decent PTO and holidays. Management generally let's you work flex time - I am not a morning person and generally didn't get to work before 9am. My manager never gave me a hard time about it as long as I got 40 hours in. Bonus was about 10% of my base as long as quality was good. Also I felt that quality control was generally pretty fair in their reviews, although others disagree with me on that. Overall I was appreciative to have this job.
employeer_cons: Not able to get your DE unless you worked in a particular physical office in 2 states only; lots of regulation impact on employees - such as, not allowed to use excel (seriously, and if you were caught using excel worksheets you were in trouble), random mid-year in-person interviews by internal auditors; training was rough - not enough access to help when needed and the corporate trainor didn't even know how to use the lending software - sent us back totally unprepared ; they use a program called "core" for underwriting and it is glitchy (for example, when the last condition is cleared the loan will automatically CTC itself. So let's say you cleared all uw conditions, but the title and appraisal were not in file yet. Those come in later and get cleared by the collateral review team. Without any warning, your loan issues it's own clear to close status. This causes you to miss anything new added to the loan before the loan gets audited by QC. Also, once a loan is in CTC status it can never be moved back. So if the loan suddenly isn't ctc anymore (let's say documents expired), it will stay in CTC status, making it hard to manage your pipeline/be aware of the true status of a loan.  Also- the system "recommends" a document to be attached to a condition and people overseas will attach conditions at 2am. (Processors don't really process here, they just resubmit loans when they see that the system recommended a document to a condition). No control at all over what processors do. Underwriter essentially becomes the processor much of the time. Finally, exceptions to credit policy were painstaking to request. Long turn time to get a reply and the system would lock you from making any changes, including canceling the request! This was very annoying.

employee_history: I worked at Wells Fargo part-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: PTO, flexible schedule for part-timers, tuition reimbursement. You get the opportunity to meet cool customers every once in a while. It's a foot in the door to the financial services industry.
employeer_cons: (Pre-Covid) This role was very stressful for what little you are compensated. You're on your feet all day and have to juggle multiple responsibilities at once to succeed . Extreme micromanagement adds to the stress of giving good customer service while following risk and compliance procedures. Management is obsessed with getting perfect customer survey scores and will always find something to criticize you over. Although the infamous "sales goals" were technically abolished, you are still expected to sell products and refer customers to bankers. High turnover, most people simply move on from burnout or because management prefers to promote people with long tenure over education at the retail level. Post-Covid was a nightmare that made all of the problems above 2x worse.

review_title: Toxic micro-managers and disengaged, arrogant CEO
employee_history: I have been working at Wells Fargo full-time for more than 8 years
employeer_pros: Pay is above average for role.
employeer_cons: Benefits are terrible, toxic management that micro-manages everything. A totally disengaged CEO that re-labeled 'Team Members' to 'Employees'. This was not just how he addressed people. Any documentation that referred to 'Team Members' was changed to 'Employees'. He rarely communicates with his employees, and has shown that he is not capable of doing anything except condescend (see recent remarks regarding black executives) and cut jobs. WF is also moving all their risk, compliance and technology off-shore to India. Already 3,000 American jobs gone.

review_title: Not what it used to be
employee_history: I have been working at Wells Fargo full-time for more than 10 years
employeer_pros: Employment with reasonable benefits and PTO
employeer_cons: With the terrible management policies in the last decade the chickens have come home to roost. The key imitative of Scharf and his management team is to get Wells out from under the asset cap and return Wells to the black. This means endless hours of work and cost cutting. This has made it very difficult as an employee, but don't believe there are any 'better' options. I'd not recommend working at Wells Fargo until the asset cap is removed and they are back to a regular dividend.

review_title: Finance Opportunities at Wells Fargo in SF: Few and Far In Between
employee_history: I have been working at Wells Fargo full-time
employeer_pros: I feel I am compensated fairly, and the people I have worked with at Wells Fargo are extremely helpful.
employeer_cons: They are replacing almost all the upper management in the bank and there is a lot of change in the organization. It is hard to keep up with and I have been working longer hours recently. In addition, Wells is hiring non-customer facing finance positions in cheaper cities, so there aren't many finance opportunities in SF. If I want to stay at the bank and have opportunities to move up, I'd probably have to move.

employee_history: I worked at Wells Fargo full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: At the time of hire, there was structure to the analyst training program. You would fly out to San Francisco, Minneapolis, or Charlotte (depending on your office location) once a year for training. At the end of your third year, if you had successfully completed the analyst training program, you were able to go through “CMTP”, which was also an in person training program designed to mold analysts into relationship managers or portfolio managers. This has since changed to virtual courses to cut costs (this all occurred pre-COVID), where you’re essentially paid an analyst’s salary to take online classes... looking back on things, there are better training programs (or entry level positions out there.
employeer_cons:
Constantly changing management hierarchy (commercial banking).
Lack of company culture and vision.
Pay

review_title: Worst HR I have ever experienced. MUST be able to take blatant verbal and physical abuse.
employee_history: I have been working at Wells Fargo full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:

Mental Abuse Prepares You For Intense Wall Street Environment
employeer_cons:

You Must Be Able To Take Blatant Abuse in NY Midtown District
CEO Says Insensitive Racist Remarks (but the Mgrs say worse)

employee_history: I worked at Wells Fargo full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros:
big company benefits that are expected
my biggest pro was that the location I worked at was extremely convenient for me
only real reason I stayed
employeer_cons:
Big company problems. From lower to higher management the entire company is CORRUPT. Work abuse, favoritism, intimidation, bias/racism... you name it

They mask it all very well by providing every employee with bogus corporate training and videos that make you believe you're in a safe work environment but you're not. They try to give you the time to take them all but no one ever does because they'd rather use that time to do other activities that help them either keep their job or keep from getting written up. The way they approach development and issues with your work is patronizing. Every meeting is just a series of questions that lead to another question that eventually lead to an explanation of how you're incompetent as an employee. They didn't say it, you say it, so its an HR friendly of telling you you suck, work harder. When you do get something right they pat you on the back and say nice but how come you didn't do this ALSO. The fear of lower level employees drives the lowkey intimidation all of management know they have. Everyone is SCARED to speak up in fear of retaliation. Then the company falls back on the most bogus no retaliation policy that comes way of those useless trainings and videos I mentioned before. So you speak up on the fact retaliation is still happening despite the policy and then the company hides behind an HR department that's suppose to protect you. HR is an absolute joke. Opened several claims to HR even in groups involving half the team members to no avail. Every answer back from them was a professional and corporate friendly way of saying, "we understand and empathize with your problem but we don't agree, deal with it." or "we understand we're going to talk to upper management" then upper management sides with the people you have a problem with because they're buddies. 

Ridiculous work expectations and performance that's globally expected due to the intimidation factor and complete lack of confidence and support. You will feel overworked and absolutely dread or fear coming to work 

Don't make any last minute or even 1-2 week plans in advance you have to ask for vacation 4 weeks in advance and still hope it doesn't interfere with anyone else's schedule

Sunday off but 2nd day off is completely random 

Don't even get me started on the WORST commission structure of all time. especially now that they're apologizing for opening fake accounts. And whatever commission you make gets paid 3 months later, what a joke. 

Lastly depending on your location a certain ethnic group will most likely dominate the work place even up to higher management so you'll experience racism/favoritism to some guaranteed degree if you're not part of that group. But remember they'll mask that too and keep it under wraps with those same bogus policies and a PHENOMENAL HR team. Sarcasm implied*

employee_history: I worked at Wells Fargo full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: Wells Fargo treats employees very well with benefits and salary. Minimum wage has been raised significantly in recent years and has greatly improved customer relations after the sales quotas were removed. Further, they have been very proactive at keeping both customers and employees safe with the COVID-19 outbreak.
employeer_cons: The reputation of Wells Fargo is still stained and many customers hate the stigma. While many policy revisions have attempted to stymie this reputation, nonetheless the reputation lingers which makes it difficult to admit working there. Further, with reduced focus on sales, instead Wells Fargo is making many small cuts and revisions to reduce the loss of income. Many such revisions frustrate customers, such as not allowing cash deposits to other people's personal accounts.

employeer_pros: Interacting with different customers was always fun, and finding a customer who really needed help with money management felt rewarding. The kind of people that Wells Fargo hire makes me feel as if they don't deserve them because they are some awesome people.
employeer_cons: At the time that I worked there, Wells Fargo was extremely passive aggressive. It was all about reaching a goal so each interaction with customers mattered and if you didn't get something from the customer (new account, credit card, loan etc.) Management felt like it was a wasted interaction and that you should be getting something out of a customer everytime.

employee_history: I have been working at Wells Fargo full-time for more than 8 years
employeer_pros: Generally friendly co-workers, great opportunities for non-WF new hires (external hiring appears to be the focus), many opportunities for people who like to fix things, new leadership sees that significant changes are needed.
employeer_cons: Leadership driven changes are not practical in the timeframes laid out. Current systems, data and lack of widespread automation do not allow cross linkage of information. Large investment in data infrastructure and connectivity between systems and hierarchies/taxonomies is desperately needed to support desired changes. Work arounds are being created in Excel to meet leadership direction rather than robust solutions such as connected databases and reporting tools (Tableau).

employee_history: I have been working at Wells Fargo full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: Great benefits, decent salary. Great training, it's a good place to get started in finance, especially if you are willing to learn.
employeer_cons: Getting things done is a bureaucratic nightmare. Everything has to be approved by many different groups or people. If something goes wrong you can't just fix it. Often different departments in the company have no idea what's going on. Also they they try to make it sound like upward mobility is easy and can happen quickly. I've found half of that to be true. The jobs aren't difficult but they do have minimum time in job expectations that make it really difficult to move on in some instances, most aren't policy related either. Just a company culture expectation managers have an attitude of "well I wasn't able to move on for three years so that's what I expect out of people in that position." It can be very frustrating at times.

employee_history: I worked at Wells Fargo full-time for less than a year
employeer_pros: Starting pay is ok for never doing that type of work. Treats for doing a good job. Christmas party.
employeer_cons: Never had enough people at one time to do all the work. Never had enough supplies to do the job. Management sucked. Worked weekends and only allowed so many days off. Apparently calling in 4 times because of different health issues means you need to talk to someone about it, for example...woke up and couldn't move my neck one morning, another time I woke up covered in hives from an allergic reaction to something, etc.

review_title: Dishonest,  Incompetent and Out of Touch  Direct management
employee_history: I have been working at Wells Fargo full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: Benefits, PTO, Insurance, Ability to Transfer to another team
employeer_cons:
The most ineffective, dishonest, un-empathetic, direct management I have ever the displeasure of working with, who would rather cause workers thrice the time to do something, then provide them with full information or the tools they need to do the job. Or they "command" them in a way that causes direct harm to already built stakeholder relationships. "Because I say so," went out in the 1980s. This guy does not like men or women, but it is obvious that he favors women even less than his male direct reports.

Out of touch with reality or flexibility as the firm undergoes an enterprise wide Agile Transformation.

Thank goodness I was able to transfer to another department. 
My new manager respects their all their staff, freely sharing information, encouraging, empathetic.

review_title: Is not a good moment to join Wells.
employee_history: I have been working at Wells Fargo full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: It is a good company with good benefits as any large organization. A lot of your daily work life depends on what type of manager you have. In my case this is the only reason I’m there.
employeer_cons: At this moment WF is going thru changes and higher leadership doesn’t look like they have an established course of action. They tell you one day “this is what we’ll do” next day is all different and they act like the previous order didn’t even existed. Also the district manager is a complete idiot. Not sure where did they find this guy but he had to be friends with someone because no one knows how he got there. At this time I would wait to join. Maybe in a year or so. A lot of decisions seems to come from people not really involved with implementation. Seems that they are paying lots of money for “projects managers” that don’t have a clue of the projects they’re managing.

review_title: Great culture, little guidance. I’m still committed!
employee_history: I have been working at Wells Fargo full-time for more than 8 years
employeer_pros:
-Wells Fargo loves being a part of the community they’re in through volunteering and free financial education outside of the branch.
-They still have traditional bank services and features like actual tellers with the option of digital for customers based on preferences.
-Changes are made off of customer and team member feedback vs. company goals. 
-You are able to be the best version of yourself as Wells Fargo allows diversity in backgrounds,thoughts, and ideas which supports our diverse customer base.
-If you consistently work hard, you will be noticed and rewarded no matter how incompetent your manager is!
-Benefits are good, and there are many options available.  New team members start with 12 or 13 days of PTO, 2 personal holidays, and 2 community service days in addition to regular bank holidays.
-The top priority managers teach their team is to focus on the customers need through understanding what’s most important to them and not the bank.
employeer_cons:
-Middle management is a joke and half.  My District Manager stays at home 4/5 days a week and managed by emailing reports. I think I may see them once every other month which is not supportive of my career development. Unfortunately, this a trend from market to market. I’m not sure what happens when someone becomes a DM... someone need to look at that.
-As a Branch Manager, it can be difficult to complete your responsibilities due to staffing issues that never end. It’s hard to be upset, because most of them move to different areas or get promoted. It’s just really hard to get a posting for a new position. 
-Our teller and banker systems are outdated. They have errors and delay customer interactions on a daily basis.
-There is no sales incentive for doing well. More times than not, a branch that has large volumes of customer traffic will always receive higher payout than smaller branches.  The customers literally come to those branches to apply for accounts. They way the incentive is made, branch balance totals are adjusted so frequently that you never understand if your branch is actually growing!  This makes it difficult for a manager to motivate their team to exceed customer expectations each day. I see where they’re coming from.. why work harder when they’re going to pay you incentive for just coming to work LOL.
-The pay structure is silly. Like May companies, they make salary decisions based on how easy or difficult is will be to retain you.  So if I live in an area with less jobs equal to mine at other companies, they have a lower risk of me leaving and pay me less. If I live in an area with a lot of competition for my skills, they pay more. This causes team members to get paid less for the same job someone is doing in another area regardless of their work ethic. Raises? 1% if you perform, 2% if you exceed, 3% if you do some type of sexual favor for your boss if you can find them after they give you keys to the branch. I’m kidding about the 3%. That’s too generous for them. 
-The training has become the worst I’ve ever seen at a company of this size. When I first began in 2012, they taught more in-depth material that allowed you to come into the branch with a basic idea of what you’re doing. Now, my team members come in the branch with two weeks of questions to ask. Unfortunately, the manager has to then choose to do their tasks or support the team member by actually training them. Of course I choose my team members development which leads to extra hours in the Branch for myself after close for everything else. 
-I feel appreciated by upper management, but it’s lip service most of the time. I think they expect my direct manager to do the leg work to make me feel valued and that’s missing completely. After numerous positive customer reviews, the recognition I receive is only based on me teaching other people how to achieve the same business results. Can I at least get a breakfast muffin? Or even an empty bag with an imaginary muffin? Ok, well let’s start with a thank you and go from there  :)
-Geez look at the time - by now you may be thinking I’m a disgruntled employee, but I’m not. I just feel the bank could support areas better than they are and meet the commitments they strive to meet with their team members like they attempt to do with customers.

review_title: Quality of experience is positively correlated with quality of your manager
employee_history: I have been working at Wells Fargo full-time for less than a year
employeer_pros:
Culture of genuinely supportive coworkers
People truly want to do the right thing and build a better Wells 
Good pay and benefits
Friendly and collaborative
Feels smaller than it is
employeer_cons:
Chaos at times
Often no one has the full picture of critical systems or processes
Often feels like you’re putting together a puzzle or looking for a needle in a haystack just to make marginal progress
Bleeding inefficiencies
Overly rigid ie, often use one size fits all when it never does
Nothing cutting edge about them... like I wouldn’t at all be surprised if we start rolling out a TQM approach next week. 
There’s fear building

Despite all of this, I would love my job again with a different manager.

review_title: Awful place to Work-welcome to the world of political correctness. No job security
employee_history: I have been working at Wells Fargo full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: Pay is adequate as is PTO
employeer_cons: The biggest issue is job security- it doesn’t exist at Wells. Every year you will anxiously wait to see if your position or line of business is to be eliminated. Wells Fargo recently hired a new CEO. The new CEO is pandering to the liberal PC crowd by intentionally “letting go” quality leaders to immediately fill those roles with token diversity hires. Wells Fargo has become a politically correct nightmare. If you are a white male- steer clear- they have made it now that you have privilege. In addition, the new CEO has bent the Q2 Earnings to for his narrative, showing higher than actual loss(by booking future projected losses that have yet been realized). This is an effort to support sizable layoffs  that will occur q4 2020. Wells will use these layoffs to support a false narrative of their new an improved diversity ratios(which didn’t occur by hiring well suited minorities, rather by firing large amounts of existing non- minority team members)

review_title: So inefficient, So many hidden errors; Dysfunctional HR
employee_role: Current Employee - Senior Director, Human Resources Management
employee_history: I have been working at Wells Fargo full-time for more than 10 years
employeer_pros: Work life balance and flexibility of working at home is great; Slow moving and easy to keep up; Leadership focused on regulatory requirements. Finally change!
employeer_cons: Inefficient; Limited potential in HR if you are a straight white man; Errors everywhere; Doesn't embrace formal change (shotgun approach); Charlie is being beaten down by the culture (no stopping WFs ability to "clog the drain" every time and make everything more screwed up than when they started. Charlie is pushing so hard to get the regulators out of our business that many are white washing the problems and kicking the ball down the street. Let's just say, I am NOT a Wells Fargo customer! Tried to be, but the mortgage rate was the highest alternative (even with a TM discount), the processing time much slower, and the process more complicated. And, based on my experience working at WF, they would have made mistakes.

employee_history: I have been working at Wells Fargo full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: You will get experience at a large organization that works with some large clients
employeer_cons:
Th he organization has a large number of problems that make it impossible to do your job and enjoy being at Wells. They are as follows:

1. Management: The people in charge have created such a toxic culture that anyone you would want to work under or with leaves within 1-2 years. Many senior RM staff are simply there because they cannot find another job and will make your life very difficult. Throwing underlings under the bus is a regular occurrence and promotion is based on politics and desperation to get someone to stay that has told management they are leaving. 

2: Career Development: There is none unless you are extremely lucky. Trying to move to different groups will often not be allowed and management can deny your transfer for any reason. After this you will be marked as not “loyal” and you essentially have no future. Few, if any of the things you will do will be transferable to real finance jobs so your time in the position will be viewed by other employers as little better then unemployment. Trying to better yourself through school or programs such as the CFA or CAIA is highly discouraged and can lead to outright retaliation in some cases. 

Pay: You will be paid 25-40% less then the same job at other banks and will be paid 30-50% less then what you would make on the principal side in a finance position. Bonuses are reserved for those that feed managements ego so expect to make only 10-25% of your bonus potential no matter how well you preform.

employee_history: I have been working at Wells Fargo full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros:
- My immediate team is great. Some typical dysfunction, but for the most part, 5 stars for my team.
- Work/life balance is excellent - laptops are closed by 5pm at the latest (only rarely are there extraordinary needs that require after hours work)
- Incredibly diverse team, lots of women in leadership roles (at our level, anyway, not so much 'upstairs')
employeer_cons:
- Upper management is still resistant to approving full-time Work From Home, even with Covid-19 and a CEO who is remote from NY. Some folks are not being approved for FT WFH, even for jobs that have been done remotely for years now. 
- Conflict-avoidant culture... As reported in the press, serious problems and bad behavior still not directly addressed and allowed to go on for too long.
- Old, institutionalized, dinosaur mentality (mostly 'upstairs') and fear of change. Lots of old white guys in charge, so... yeah.
- Under-performers and folks who just won't do their jobs can easily hide, the org is so large. And because conflict avoidant, these problem folks are never dealt with.
- Salaries are below market for design jobs. Raises don't keep up with inflation.
- The process to get any little thing done is arduous and time intensive. There are so many groups and systems involved, it's redonkulous.

review_title: One of the better places I've worked
employee_history: I have been working at Wells Fargo full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: Lots of paid time off, great company culture, and lots of training/coaching if you want it. Company also promotes from within and regularly checks in with you to see what your goals are with the company. Management will work with you to help reach those goals. Pretty good worklife balance, you work your 40 hours and very, very rarely overtime. Company actively doesn't want it. When on paid time off, management never reaches out in regards to work and you don't take work home if you're not management.
employeer_cons:
Likely due to past scandals, policy changes at a very rapid pace. It feels like you constantly have to check to see what the new changes are and calling the back office can give mixed results. Coaching can become overbearing if you're not used to it.

Sales goals technically eliminated, but it's still ultimately a sales job. This isn't so much a con, but different managers will have different expectations for this aspect of the job.

review_title: Used to be a nice place, but...
employee_history: I worked at Wells Fargo full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros:
When I first started:
-Flexible hours (could work 9-5, or work a 4-10 schedule)
-Managers expected results but treated us like human beings
-Work culture was fairly balanced
-Managers were transparent in departments goals and expectations, which made it easier for us to work and obtain (we consistently met 97% SLA monthly all over the country).
-Entry level pay was fairly competitive

When I left:
-Team came together, but it was due to us relying on each other to get through the day.
employeer_cons:
By the time I left:
-They laid off our sister site with little warning, despite our departments doing very well
-They strung contractors along for well over two years before they got frustrated and left; they were dedicated and reliable workers, and new contractors were a mixed bag.
-In my last year, we changed over multiple managers; I believe our immediate manager tried to shield us from a lot of things, but upper management pressed hard, which trickled down to the Processors
-Micro-managing. We were only allowed seven minutes the entire day to use the restroom. As the bathrooms were on the other side of the floor, one visit took 3 1/2 minutes, running. 
-Work environment became toxic, and by the time I left, the turnover rate had been rising.
-Managers no longer were transparent; goals changed frequently without warning, and upper management became obviously disdainful of the Processors when we didn't meet 100% SLA (our team worked with appraisers all over the country, and most of the time if a report didn't come in on time, it meant the appraiser had trouble or just didn't bother doing the report).

As my former coworkers told me, my department no longer exists as it used to.

employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time for more than 3 years

employeer_cons: On the other hand you’re massively overworked and not paid enough. I’m not talking low salary negotiations I’m talking about working 9/10 hours a day and not being paid enough, working Sundays and weekends and not being paid enough, asking for time off and being told that you someone else is scheduled and finally applying for promotions and never hearing back. For what is worth, I do think that if you’re young and willing to obtain experience at the expense of a few years, it can be a good company to work for.

employee_history: I worked at TD full-time for more than 10 years
employeer_pros:
Great benefits: Tuition reimbursement, 401K matching, PTO, employee assistance program, etc.

Great culture: (depending on department) food days, celebrations of work anniversaries and birthdays, celebrations of work successes.

Great opportunities for development and training.

Great team manager (also depending on department). Acknowledged good work, celebrated team successes, regularly met with team members to check-in, and mentored the team.
employeer_cons:
There were some decisions by the executive team that weren't well communicated or understood, but I think that is typical of large organizations.

 It seemed like good managers (managers that understood their teams and their abilities) were fired and others were kept but they didn't truly have their pulse on the people they were leading.

As per my job: I have had the best experience out of college that I could ask for. Amazing access to the executives. Very laidback environment but at the same time a very high functioning team. Great culture

Great benefits and job security

employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: If I could rate less, I would.
employeer_cons: Convenience at the cost of employees simplifies it. I don’t think I would say much if I didn’t find the mission statement so utterly hypocritical when it comes to them putting their employees first. The health insurance and pay is abysmal compared to the competition. In addition, the branches are called stores for a reason...they are ran as such and often lack professionalism. HR is awful when addressing issue pertaining to discrimination and bigotry, which TD prides themselves on. File And EEOC if you need to, nothing can be resolved at the corporate level. Don’t expect promotions even after reaching your individual goals, your supervisor will not let you seek advancements at the cost of their bonuses at a different store. If you have a degree, this place isn’t worth it. Your payout for bonuses are little to none and won’t compensate for the low base pay in larger cities. You 401k is a joke, because you can’t contribute on the pay you receive.

review_title: Loved my co-workers, but there's always a catch
employee_history: I worked at TD part-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: Great team! Supervisors and managers were always available and willing to help. Consistant one on one coaching  and  full staff meetings were wonderful tools to unlock full potential in order to meet both personal and company goals. Ability to earn quarterly bonuses based on both personal and store sales. Health, dental and vision benefits for part time employees.
employeer_cons: One of the main reasons for leaving TD Bank NA was the structure used to determine P.T.O. and the employee's contribution to health, dental and vision plans. For example,  as 20 hour employees P.T.O. was accumulated based solely on their 20hr structure, and employees contribution to other benefits were also based on the same structure. I would consistently work more than 20hrs, yet only earn P.T.O. and contribute to other benefits as a 20 hr employee.  Sales expectations were also becoming exceedingly unattainable.

employee_role: Current Employee - Senior Customer Service Representative
employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time for more than 8 years
employeer_pros: Flexible hours, decent benefits, and many locations.
employeer_cons:
Has a tendency to not promote from within. While individuals within the company may vary, there is no loyalty for good employees, and little to no notice when one's position is eliminated through no fault of your own. 
The company has an increasingly commercial and wealth oriented nature, resulting in increasingly poor customer service and experience, and a decrease in quality of employee treatment.

employee_history: I have been working at TD part-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
- Flexible schedule for college students
- Decent pay for a part-time job before moving to something meaningful
- Great addition to resume
employeer_cons:
- Work environment is more of a playground than professional setting
- Stagnant salaries that do not adjust to performance
- Most employees are "cross-trained" which leads to inconsistency and directly affects sales goals as a result
- "Be Legendary" program requires all employees to lobby-lead(greet customers in the lobby) for hours per shift rather than taking care of tasks that are actually important. Lobby Leading is mandated for all hours of operation, meaning that even if there are no customers inside, an employee is still required to stand there for hours on end twiddling their thumbs.
- Computer hardware is extremely old(late 90's) and internal software is just as out-dated(we run Microsoft Office 2008) which is seriously laughable
- There are often times no internal lines to call for customer support, instead; such as with contacting online banking, employees are forced to make calls to the same customer contact number with average wait times of 20-30 mins

employeer_cons: Flex schedules that force employees to bid on a schedule every 6 months. Very long hold times so more irate customers. Processing and fees suck so always customer complaints

review_title: A place to work hard and get very little
employee_history: I worked at TD full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: The best part about TD were the relationships I got out of it. You are overworked and exhausted with some of the ridiculous rules and regulations, but so are your coworkers. There is a sense of unity among the staff most of the time, and you truly feel like you're all in this together.
employeer_cons: Pressure placed on employees for maintaining "operation excellence" while still providing a WOW! experience for every customer was nearly impossible. The punitive discipline (that affected every team member, regardless of which individual might have "broken a rule") made it so that staff hid errors, rather than reporting and reacting. It was a stressful position with sometimes ridiculous rules where everyone was constantly held accountable for the actions of others, and where the sales process often pitted employees against each other.

review_title: Great Company Culture But Pay Is Low & Advancement Is Difficult
employee_history: I worked at TD full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: TD has a unique corporate environment. Excellence is regularly celebrated (with a yearly award show known as WOW awards) and the company definitely breeds an enthusiastic culture.
employeer_cons: It is very hard to advance. Without upper level degrees or the backing of a executive, it is easy to become stagnant and lose motivation. In the banking world, pay is also significantly less. I later discovered that my position at two different financial institution was paying its employees $7 & $9 more per hour than what I was making.

employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time for more than 8 years
employeer_pros:
The main redeeming quality of working at TD Bank is that there are a lot of great, talented, dedicated people that I enjoy working with. 
Salary and benefits are good
Office location in Falmouth is decent, easy access to 95 & 295 with parking and some amenities like an on-site gym and a range of visiting food trucks.
employeer_cons:
Upper management for the most part is a deplorable mess.
They expect you to work 24/7 and treat you like a number but tout the laughable “human” brand.
Frequent “job eliminations” are losing valuable people and they blithely ignore the impacts on morale and productivity. It’s become a pretty toxic place to work.
They’re instituting an open concept floor plan just to cram more people in and save money. The idea of promoting more collaboration is a joke. 
Run, don’t walk away from this nightmare!

review_title: Such a fun place to grow

review_title: Work-Life Balance is Horrible but Benefits are fantastic

Full-timers feel the brunt of the long hours and have many many asks r from upper management. Store Managers are rarely in the Stores, leaving the Assistant Managers to deal with everything. Upper management raves about the "TD Culture" but it is never enforced when it matters

There are opportunities to move within the organization; this is not an up or out culture.

employee_history: I worked at TD full-time for less than a year
employeer_pros: There are none.  I think they are going to close after they transfer all management to Canada.
employeer_cons: They steal their customers money.  One disabled customer they trick into putting his workers compensation check (which is all he had ) into a Relationship Account then pressured him into an appointment to talk about investing.  He insisted this was all he had and had to last him for the next 30 years when he came back his balance was zero.  When he didnt come to the appt he ended up with a zero balance.  He brought his wife with him to find out were his money was and they told her he spent it.  He must be living a double life she doesn't know about.

employee_history: I worked at TD full-time for more than a year

employeer_cons: Complete bias that goes on from management, from branch managers to Regional managers. Seems like most employees who are good at their job leave after realizing the company sucks, and it leaves all the people who can't to do better to become a manager after working at the branch for 10 years.

employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: great benefits and flexibility, if you go to school they really try working with your schedule (to an extent)
employeer_cons: Recently the company has come to this, SALES SALES SALES. You HAVE to push the Credit Card to EVERY single customer, needed or not, even if it is absolutely not needed. Aren't we suppose to help these people financially ? Not just shove a credit card pitch to every single customer that walks through the door. Also when I first was interviewed I was never told this would be a  SALES job, now the management holds my job and tells me i'm going to get fired every single second they get the chance simply because I did mention things to customers that they do not need, they say they are America's most convenient bank and that they care about their customers but they are moving towards what Wells Fargo did, SALES, do whatever it takes to get the SALES up. MICROMANAGING NEEDS TO STOP, simply exhausting having someone breathe over your shoulder when you can do the job perfectly fine without that. Also one thing to mention is if your entire team is leaving or thinking about leaving, something is wrong with management.

employeer_pros: good amount of PTO, work from home option for some positions
employeer_cons: After more than 8 years at the bank I make less than $18 an hour as an AML Rep II. With such a high level of responsibility and given the workload we are grossly underpaid. Bonuses are sad, the focus on things like dress code in the back office where we never see customers are a joke, there is miscommunication where different managers enforce policies/procedures different than others on the same floor. Another thing, there is a culture created at TD Bank where it is very shunned upon to speak about what your wages are. I have in the past been told outright not to speak to my coworkers about our pay. This is clearly done to keep people from realizing what others may be making and to allow TD to continue to under pay their workers. Sure we live in Maine and our cost of living may be lower than New Jersey but its 2019 and no one can survive on crumbs.

employeer_pros: The only good thing about working for TD is the benefits. However all banks provide the same benefits package.

I worked for TD for 4 years. The company is not what it used to be. Sales goals increased tremendously and the employees are under a lot of stress and pressure to reach their goals. Management is very poor. Senior management is in a different world and does not care about what is happening on the floor.
Salaries are a joke and payouts are almost nothing and it’s hard to move up unless you kiss your big bosses hands. No work/life balance and schedules are not set plus hours feel like a retail store not a bank.
So glad I don’t work there anymore and do not recommend it to anyone!

review_title: Decent Company, Outdated policies and technology.

employeer_pros: Networking and building relationships with great customers. Insight into the Insurance / Fixed Differed Annuity Market.
employeer_cons: The technology systems that are used are out dated. Solving simple customer issues can become a tiresome journey simply because of a lack updated technology. Often takes 30 minutes to an hour to solve a small issue such as even updating customer information. In the year of 2018-2019 this shouldn't even be an issue to a "innovative" company.

review_title: A train wreck waiting to happen
employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: Lots of room for promotions. You can increase your rate by $10-15 easy if you put your mind to it
employeer_cons:
Oh boy, where to start: 

TD claims to want to be the better bank, yet uses the worst resources and technology available. ATMs are constantly eating people’s money, the card machine works when it wants to, the wait time to speak to a representative in back office can be 30-60 mins, computers crash constantly, TCRs jams frequently, and when a customer expresses dissatisfaction due to any of these, it’s somehow your fault for not resolving it. 

Management has a “no excuses” attitude towards their employees. They are expected to pledge their lives to this job. If you work in a busier branch, one call out ruins everything. Your PTO package has no allocated sick time so calling out for any reason is a mark against you.

If you work Sundays, which are only 5 hour shifts, you will end up working 10-11 hour days to make up for it. 

The training is hilarious. They teach you a few common transactions you’ll be performing in the real world and then send you off in it. You’re basically set up to fail.

review_title: Dont believe the hype on top place to work at branch
employee_history: I worked at TD full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: Diversity, team outing when we can
employeer_cons: Minimal training for staffs at branch. People are thrown on cash in day 2.  Pba and advisors have minimal training and practicing sales on live client. They all learn as they go. I wouldnt spend my hard earned money with advisors they have. Bunch of rookies without any knowledge from the market are selling products just Because they have license. Management in rural areas are all new promoted within 6 to 1yr from teller. No leadership training whatsoever. People are promoted based on sales. Immature hanging out after work and partying type of culture within small town is nerve wrecking to people who are trying to just work hard. Favoritism due to personal relationship. People dating and having a fling within department. Small town branch is overlooked by corporate office.

review_title: Overall great place to work but pay could be better
employee_history: I worked at TD full-time
employeer_pros: Pretty excellent people, CEO is great - had the pleasure of meeting him a few times and remembered me on each occasion after the first.  Lots of people that have been there for years and have a great wealth of knowledge which they are more than willing to share.  Promote from within culture - at least in my experience.
employeer_cons: Compensation was definitely below market average.  The office and group you are in will impact your experience.  Some of the lenders and regional VPs you collaborate with can be great but some of them are miserable to work with.  No credit background means they come to you and you get to figure the entire deal out. it's decent experience but when you have other pressing deadlines it's unnecessary work.  The summer crunch to get annual reviews done was also pretty miserable.  Nicest time of the year and you get to work lots of extra hours

employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: The starting pay is decent and I've made a lot of good friends and harvested some good business relationships in my time here. Great benefits and PTO.
employeer_cons: Management is only concerned about sales goals because if you and the store don't reach your goals they don't get their bonus. Employees are expected to do whatever management doesn't have time for and aren't compensated fairly. They tell you to find the "best solutions" for customers financial needs but, if the best solution is that they don't need a solution (often times this can be true), they say you're doing something wrong or not doing your job right simply because you didn't sell something or open a new account for someone who doesn't need it. If TD  isn't careful, they're going to end up going under or having a Wells Fargo type incident on their hands because the sales goals are VERY unrealistic.

employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time for more than 8 years
employeer_pros: We get two days a week we can set as our work from home days. Two days is awesome.
employeer_cons: We cannot stay home if we feel we are too sick to go into the office unless it is our scheduled WFH day. Forcing people to unnecessarily come into work and spreading germs.  Even on a snow day in the northeast (when we are told days in advance to stay home if possible due to extreme weather)  we are expected to have another adult present while working from home if we have grade school aged children home or not work. *Newflash* if it's a snowday I have multiple kids home all day long and my production doesn't suffer one bit.  And of course, if your child is sick and you have to stay home you also are not allowed to work from home and are forced to use a full day of PTO which eats up days off that could have been spent with with the family and/or vacationing. Furthermore, we are not allowed to make up more than 4 hours in a week and I have been told by management that they "don't have to let me make up any time unless it was missed for a scheduled appointment."  I'm sorry but life happens, especially for people with multiple children. Why knock the employee down who WANTS to make the time up so they arent in a position where they are tight on PTO at the end of the year and having to sacrifice days off during the Holidays because they had to stay home with one sick child in February because they supposedly are too much of a distraction?
