review_title: Great benefits, good pay, good people, horrible and inconsistent bureaucracy
employee_history: I worked at TD full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: The benefits are amazing- particularly the paid time off. Having 5 weeks of vacation to start as just a level 5 employee was incredible. They also have maternity/paternity leave, tuition reimbursement and quarterly bonuses. The people are good, they invest a lot in good management. The culture is very inclusive and focuses on the "Legendary" experiences. They also  tend to cross-train a lot and encourage you to learn as much as possible and take on more responsibility. I had a great experience working there, for the most part. Employees, especially managers, also get paid far more here than at other banks.
employeer_cons: Access to information is not only difficult but sometimes info is non-existent, forcing a lot of time and energy toward finding an answer (usually only to have support specialists not not the answer either). Stores also sometimes create their own rules and there's a lot of inconsistency with guidelines put into play. There are waaaaay too many different programs to do simple and frequent tasks. Upper management seem to never know when and how to implement change appropriately; Particularly with technology. Why implement a program during the Summer when there's more customer traffic, people are taking time off and naturally have staffing shortages (and without any preparation for it in advance)?You're setting your teams up for failure. I know of quite a few policy violations that take place on a very consistent basis and there are managers that I have worked with that are guilty of illegal activity, playing favorites and breaking company policy on a regular basis and they still work there, despite having HR involved in some cases. I just don't get it. Some people manage to stay while others get fired for accidental or trivial policy violations. I have seen the brown-nosers get ahead of everyone else that performs well. In a business that is all about building relationships, sometimes top performers get crapped on if they're not kissing enough butt to the right people.  Pay increases are extremely difficult to get beyond 2% if you stay in the same store, even if you kick the crap out of your goals; It's just not right. As soon as I started focusing on myself and being more genuine in my feedback toward managers, bad things happened for me.

review_title: A common theme of toxicity, disrespect & double-standards
employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: Solid bank North of the border, with a global presence in key markets. The bank does have an emphasis on social impact and has a decent U.S. presence it is trying to grow.
employeer_cons:
Having seen the earlier reviews for the Houston office from several years back, it is safe to say that very little has changed for the better. Frankly it is one of the worst types of environments to find yourself in. It can be daunting. It can be draining. And above all, it takes a toll by lowering morale and is one of the worst feelings to experience. Office leaders do not understand the work that occurs and hence do not truly grasp the issues they contribute to.

Having been exposed to different environments, the level of politics and constant gossip between upper-level staff is remarkable at TD Securities (USA) LLC, especially considering the shear number of people Houston has hired in a move to grow in the market. The reality is that there are a few folks driving many of the antics, but you can expect to be demeaned openly, questioned at every turn, and find yourself always being on the look-out because trust is devoid.

The team leads are drivers of considerable gossip behind closed doors, and the Director level staff feel as though they have earned the positions to the point they act in vindictive manners towards those below them despite the junior staff doing the vast majority of the work for them. Staff in Houston want quick promotions and are willing to go behind others' backs to make it happen faster. The exposure to a variety of clients is great as is being a part of CIB, but the buck stops there. The level of nasty folks and rising toxicity is unfortunate, especially considering many of the staff members do recognize this and discuss the issues that cannot be voiced to those making key management decisions.

review_title:
Senior Financial Services Representative (FSR II) -
Heavy on sales and meeting numbers, work-life ba
employee_history: I worked at TD  for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: The FSR position is a great role to get your foot in the door as a much more distinguished individual in branch and in banking & insurance and sales in general. You’re essentially the top banker (aside from the bank management team) in the bank providing fixed investments to prospective clientele. If you’re really good , you can really be distinguished amongst your peers and likened amongst the senior management team and it can immediately help propel you to where you want to be in your career at TD if you’re a top performer. Meeting senior leadership with luncheons, gifts, regional highlight of your success, exclusive awards and recognition from top leaders and even all expenses paid trips if you’re the top of the top.
employeer_cons: A LOT of turnover due to overly pressured in sales and trying to meet goals. As an FSR you’re expected to hit 4 investment unit sales a month and meet your banking sales goal for consumer and business banking and then you are also looked upon as a “leader” to lead by example or sometimes having to be a member of the management team and having to reprimand your staff. One month you could be the top sales person in your regional territory or even the company, but next month you don’t hit the numbers you’re getting pressure from the management team or even the Regional Market Managers themselves.

employee_history: I worked at TD part-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: Great company to work for. Plenty of ways to grow in the company and the higher-ups I had contact with wanted to see me improve, and gave me plenty of opportunities to learn new skills. Pay is competitive and raises come if you are performing well.
employeer_cons: If you work part-time, generally, you have no opportunities for time off. You also are generally forced to work the 4pm-7pm shift. These hours normally shove you in the back with the drive-thru window, with the customers mostly being regular business deposits. It was incredibly hard in these conditions to get a credit card or account opening sale. It also gets pretty cold during the winter. If you are a new associate this is incredibly frustrating as it makes trying to grow your sales abilities almost impossible. On weekends you sometimes have the chance to work the lobby, but this was also very rare.

review_title: Stable, with a good culture that is good when practiced
employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros:
- Good job security.
- Good benefits/PTO time allotted.
- Good annual bonuses.
- Depending on Department, can be WFH-friendly.
- Good on diversity, women in leadership, community/charitable leadership.
- Recognition system is solid.
employeer_cons:
- Pay is slightly below average.
- Raises are meager.
- Work/life balance truly varies from team to team. Some are great, some are atrocious. You'll notice if you read some of the reviews, you will see work/life mentioned as both a pro and a con. You really have to do your homework to know the manager with whom you will be working.
- Systems are replaced frequently, and training tends to lag behind.
- TD has an extremely strange promotion/career development model. Employees very rarely are promoted within their own role. They are expected to apply for new jobs/roles to advance, and to do so, the employees are required to let their manager know ahead of time. This creates a lot of uncomfortable working situations, reviews, etc.

employee_history: I worked at TD part-time
employeer_pros:
-Generally higher than minimum wage
-Great benefits and paid time off
-A tiny bit flexible in scheduling
-Great start to a career
-Work hard and advancement should come quick. Advancing to the next position every 2 years is average from what I've seen.
employeer_cons:
-Some branches are severely understaffed and that affects the employees of that branch. Customer service can't be satisfied if the branches are understaffed.
-The bonus payouts were very minimal, despite TD doing great and generating so much money.
-It is hard mixing customer satisfaction and banking. TD tries really hard to please customers and that can often backfire. One of the few examples, Customers are too used to hearing "Yes" and when customers come for their fifth courtesy fee refund of the year,  they don't want to hear "no" at all.
-Their rate of adjustment needs to be worked on when it comes to loyal employees and our salary. I worked there for 4 years, advanced from entry level teller to senior teller to Banker/customer service rep...only to find out that newly hired entry level tellers were getting hired for almost the same hourly rate.

employee_history: I worked at TD full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: TD is great for work life balance and treats their employees right. Employees often stay at TD because they are comfortable with where they are at and the lives that their job helps them lead. There is significant diversity at TD, and the company is working even harder to improve it's impressive culture of inclusion, respect, and customer-focus.
employeer_cons: The downside is that leaders at TD understand the value proposition to their employees: you like/love working here so we can afford to pay you less. Employees are recognized for exceptional work but often need to step out of their comfort zone and advocate for themselves in order to receive promotions and progress in their career. Many leaders are okay with people coasting in their job but will not reward this kind of behavior beyond the below industry average compensation that TD pays.

employeer_pros: Work life balance and decent coffee.
employeer_cons:
It’s all about the ranking. They will do whatever it takes to have their ranking up for the best place to work. 

The management team pretend to care without much actions. There are a lot of surveys going around but none or few provide anonymity. Those who writes the actual feedback would actually get published financially or growth. Managers lack transparency and failed to actually engage in difficult conversations. 

A lot of poor managers get away with treating the employees like dirt because of treats being made. A lot of accusations are being thrown around without engaging the person. Hard to improve anything because teams take it as negativity than making things better. 

Some teams hire more visa holders because they can’t complain for fear of losing status. 

Overall, a very toxic environment.

employee_history: I worked at TD full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: While employed at TD, I couldn't complain about the benefits or vacation time, and I was paid fairly.
employeer_cons: The second the project I was assigned to went behind schedule and over budget, they released people rather than try to fix what was wrong. employee_history: I worked at TD full-time
employeer_pros: There aren't a lot of pros, but the one thing I can say is that the friendship you develop with your co-workers and regular customers is really great.
employeer_cons:
The job itself is soul-sucking. You are constantly pressured from management to sell new products or upgrade current products, and if you don't reach your quarterly goal you are put on a performance improvement plan. You feel terrible when you increase credit limits to customers who can't afford to be in more debt, and then are admonished by management when you don't. 

The opportunities to grow within the company are few and far-between, often presented to favourites within the branch. 

The HR delegate for the area that I worked in was extremely disrespectful, and showed bias towards certain employees when dealing with them.

review_title: Great place to work and be a part of the TD Family
employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros:
TD is constantly trying to be the best it can be for it's customers and employees. They have an employee appreciation week every year, great PTO (i get more than my family whose in a medical field), pay is conservative but better job security. Excellent parental leave. Employee discounts. 24/7 Support for customers. 

TD Truly cares about it's employee's and it's customers. Anyone who says otherwise doesn't understand it's still a business.
employeer_cons:
Certain departments i've talked to have made it known they don't really get the recognition they deserve. The team who handles access issues hardly gets recognized. Employees don't use the recognition program that much for them or for the Service Desk. It seem to be expected and not appreciated, I've even heard people call them the helpless desk while they resolved their issues. 

Upper management hardly recognizes the work these departments do. They've laid off a few of them and say they try to help get them internal jobs but usually it's only people in management positions that get the job. Not a lot of room for advancement in technology. 

The people are amazing to work with but if you're on a phone channel, be prepared to be stressed. I don't know if they don't realize that they're talking to co-workers or if they're just phone brave but people can get extremely rude and you just have to take it you can't correct them or hang up.

employee_role: Current Employee - Senior Customer Service Representative
employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: TD is a wonderful company to work for in terms of culture. I work in retail. Regional management, in my region specifically, is very committed to rewarding, recognizing, and promoting hard-working employees. In the right store setting you will be valued and encouraged toward a career. Retail banking is a great stepping stone for someone looking to transition into the finance world without a degree, like myself, or other qualifications most companies look for. PTO is very generous, the best I've heard of at my level in any company.
employeer_cons: The pressure is very high in retail banking to achieve sales. The quality of your production will really depend on the kind of atmosphere your store management team sets. if your direct leadership aren't good leaders - as in any industry - the store really suffers and isn't equipped to deal with performance pressure. While PTO is very generous, it can be hard to use it when you want in a store of 7 - 10 people on staff. Recently, TD has also suffered from a myriad of technology issues and inconsistencies impacting customers, which makes the customer service aspect of our jobs very difficult at times.

employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time
employeer_pros: Good work life balance, people leave at 5pm
employeer_cons:
Gives lip service to diversity and inclusion; of over 300+ US executives, can count on 2 hands the number of minorities.  2 hands and 2 feet the number of women executives.
Biased towards Canadians
Lower pay than US counter part banks
Promotes based on who you know, not what you know

employee_history: I worked at TD full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: TD has a great culture and for the most part, you meet a lot of great people. They have a great benefits package and the 401k match and core contributions are nothing to scoff at. Depending upon the role you’re in, management is pretty flexible with your schedule and they’re generous with PTO, as are most banks. Every few years they even give an extra PTO day and bonuses are awarded based on performance yearly.
employeer_cons: It’s easy to get comfortable here because the culture is great and the benefits are great, but the pay leaves a lot to be desired. It’s hard to get promoted because they constantly are doing reorganizations of various departments which causes more people to be posting for internal positions, it’s very competitive and unless you’re in with the right crowd, it’s unlikely to get the job. They claim to want to promote from within but I know many, including myself, who have been looked over for an external candidate or an internal candidate who was far less qualified. The biggest problem at TD is that management is completely disconnected and there’s no training, you’re thrown into a role with little to no support. I am disappointed to say the least as I wanted to continue my career with them for years to come, but after being promoted and not being fairly compensated as well as being bored out of my mind, I knew this wasn’t for me.

employee_history: I have been working at TD part-time for less than a year
employeer_pros: The pay here is much higher than previous bank teller positions I have held.
employeer_cons: Management is a pain to deal with.  We are overstaffed at our branch and management complains about us trying to take time off because it will affect business somehow.  Head teller complained my second week on the teller line that we were making too many mistakes, which is absurd.  Head teller also runs to management if we blink our eyes the wrong way.  Management is way too overbearing.  I don't recommend retail banking under any circumstances, and I sure don't recommend TD Bank.  Also, insurance is insanely expensive.

employee_history: I worked at TD part-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros:
The only good thing is they have a 401k but at this point I feel like most jobs offer this. 
They will also give you a chance with absolutely no experience but they wont train you correctly. Basically you’ll be dropped in the middle of the ocean with no life support. Even the pros are cons.
employeer_cons: Might pay a little bit more than other banks but everything LITERALLY EVERYTHING else is so bad you’ll be willing to take a pay cut. The first 3 months they will be very nice and after that they gaslight you and manipulate you. Crazy hours, no regard for your life, toxic work environment. If you have no choice but to work here just don’t stay and get trapped. Leave for capitol one the minute you get the chance. This is literally the worst bank you could work for.

review_title: Good job for 2 very specific types of people
employee_history: I worked at TD full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros:
This is a good job for 2 types of people:
1. A recent college graduate WITH A PLAN. do not come here and expect to find a career, you MUST have a broader plan and use this as a steeping stone.
2. Someone who just needs a decent pay check and has no desire to advance. TD pays decent wages and has ok-ish benefits and it is better than a minimum wage job.
employeer_cons:
The managers of Retail Credit actively discriminate against age, if you are over 25, you have no chance of management or promotions. They aggressively promote younger people and they do not value any experience at all. 
Also they have 0 work life balance. Management loves to say "your hard work and dedication does not go unnoticed" however the workers have shifted that phrase to "your hard work and dedication continue to go unnoticed"

employee_history: I worked at TD full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: Most employees are great, Management on the other hand will ask you to do things that are against policy. (Thinking its going to be another Wells Fargo law suit soon)
employeer_cons: HR and upper management does not have your back when it comes to informing them of ethics not being followed. When you hit 200% of your goal they email store manager to find out why you are above goal and why was that goal assigned, instead of recognizing excellent sales ability. Payouts are the lowest I've ever seen at a financial institution. They have clawbacks when customers close/chargeoff accounts within 90 days which means they take away all your work (sales) for those accounts and make you double the work to catch back up. They don't run Chex Systems so that happens ALOT. Their technology lets just say is something to laugh about.  Oh can't forget about their hold time for Bank Support, Fraud Management, or Collection Dept is on average an hour so you are literally helping 5 customers a day for service instead of actually making sales. Don't forget that most branches are open 7 days a week and late hours but not all departments are that you need to help with some of the customers needs.

Tried reaching out to managers for help and they will have you call another department to get it resolved with us like a 20 + minute hold time, which upset the customer even more. review_title: Good for some people, not everyone.
employee_history: I have been working at TD part-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
Very flexible with scheduling, since they are open 7 days a week.
Very understanding as to what your career goal is.
Paid Time Off, great benefits.
employeer_cons:
Too much customer driven, they will fire you or suspend you on the spot if you mess up, regardless of the circumstances of the situation.
Customers, are like gods for them, even when they are wrong. they are right.
Sales commission is the worst in the history of commission. 
Open seven days, which means you will be working a lot of weekends. 
Do not pay enough, ask for too much in return of paying you almost nothing. 
Pay for TD brand garbage, such as pens, lollipops, crayons, bubbles, coloring books, rather than increasing the employee pay.

review_title: Bad Tasting Experience; Even Worse Operation
employee_history: I worked at TD full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: Decent amount of Paid Time Off (when actually granted); Occasional generous rewards from upper management for meeting sales goals (1 or 2 per year).
employeer_cons: Unnecessary verification of family situation and allocation of benefits; All requests for promotion were either rebuffed or ignored, always with some excuse (eg: "you only made 99% of your sales goal last quarter, that's not high enough for promotion"); Daily branch operations were improvised and lacking structure; Punished with extra job tasks for using PTO; Legitimate complaints & escalations were made to HR, only to be forgotten later on; Bad management causes unstable relationships between branch employees, and never any resolutions from HR; Constantly understaffed, with constant employee call-outs for dishonest reasons; Employees abusing overtime, never getting caught nor punished; Often unfair treatment of good employees, while evidently rewarding the bad ones; Scheduling and days off were always incompetently arranged by management; PTO was never granted as per the wishes of the employee, due to poorly-made excuses by management; Management was consistently absent from the branch, yet increasingly demanding of sales & customer service goals; Training of various tasks was mediocre or non-existent; Estimated start time of menial job tasks became expedited without warning; Inconsistent scheduling of activities (Holiday-related, etc. events were always cancelled, deferred or postponed); Longer working hours than any other bank. The list goes on and on…

employee_role: Current Employee - Vice President Product Management
employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time for less than a year
employeer_pros:
Work-Life Balance, Excellent On-Boarding Process, and Excellent Team Chemistry

TD Bank is very unique in a sense that it isn’t your usual Financial Institution. When I wake up, because of the “Dress for your Day” policy, I get to choose what I want to wear depending on what is going on in my day. If phone meetings type of day, I’m wearing jeans! Once I get to work, I don’t always have to be physically in my desk exactly at 9am. If I am a parent dropping my kids off in school, as long as I do not have any scheduled meetings and it doesn’t interfere with my work or my team’s schedule, they have Flex-time! On days I have to stay home, I can work from home too. If you are planning for a family, birth or adoption, you get 4 months paid vacation. Those are just some of the perks I love in TD.
employeer_cons:
So, as they always say, good things come with a price...

TD doesn’t quite pay industry standard, at least for the area I’m in (tech). The only thing holding this good company to becoming one of the greats is the salary. Great companies do not need to compromise salary because the benefits are great. Once TD fixes this issue, not only will they be able to improve their employee retention but also attract better talent.

employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: My immediate team is awesome, high work ethic, extremely intelligent, would work everyday until night to deliver results
employeer_cons:
Personalities and departments vary greatly. If you happen to work with toxic people and departments, it's very draining but the company doesn't hold them accountable. Bullying or bulldozing their way through is rampant with no repurcussions for the people who behave that way.

While my immediate team is awesome, I am part of shared services supporting multiple lines of businesses. My negative experience comes exclusively  from people hired who were with Chase previously that have no real leadership, planning, or vision and the only strength they employ is bullying and bulldozing their way through flawed assumptions. 

TD, you have so much gold in the original talent pool from within + those hired from other banks. But you keep putting people from Chase in leadership positions they have no business being in. This is producing such a dramatic and toxic working environment, you make me want to quit because my health and talent is not worth these people. 

I don't mean to generalize and I'm sure there's great people you hired from Chase, but 3/5 they're terrible. They're being difficult just to be difficult is impeding work and progress.

Company does not care at all about employees (the ones that keep them in business)

Sell, sell, sell even if the customer doesn't need it or can't afford it and then sell some more.

employeer_pros: Great benefits, PTO, flexible schedules. Management cares about its employees and treats its people well. If you show them you are a hard worker and take your career seriously they will bend over backwards to help you achieve your career goals and growth. High focus on developing employee talent. At the same time, struggling employees are nurtured and encouraged rather than thrown out the door.

employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time for more than 10 years
employeer_pros: The company offers and promotes various professional development opportunities (eClasses) on a wide variety of topics, mentoring opportunities, networking groups, and volunteer opportunities.  They emphasize the importance of employee experience as well as customer experience.  TD offers a culture of inclusion and acceptance.  In June of 2017 the company announced 16 weeks paid parental leave for mothers AND fathers.
employeer_cons:
Pay scales are on the low side.  
Although the company talks the talk, not all members of the management team walk the walk.  Many managers do not foster growth and development even though the company does.  Employees must be diligent about owning their own careers (which is not a con and is true anywhere).
Health insurance is mediocre but not bad.
Current leadership does have a "boys club" approach to promoting new management and blatant favoritism regardless of lack of required skills is obvious.

employee_history: I worked at TD full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: The corporate training is good. Benefits are decent.
employeer_cons: Management was horrible. People were allowed to get away with questionable practices for far too long. The environment in the store I was in was extremely confrontational an cliquey. The hours are far worse than other banks, which you know beforehand. At my interview they said they would work with me on my schedule, then when I started working, it was a problem.

employee_history: I worked at TD  for more than a year
employeer_pros: Paid Vacation time, most holidays are pto, opportunity to advance if you have a good coach and manager. Tuition reimbursement
employeer_cons: Upper managements expects very high level of performance for customer satisfaction and sales. they really don't have a clue of what's going on in the stores or how the store managers are running the show. They preach about employee development and growth but that can only happen with good store management and good team building and coaching. Some stores may have that but the store I worked in definitely did not.  Customers constantly complaining about how other stores will break rules and policy, it makes the stores that do follow the rules look bad and makes the customers angry. Not an engaging environment for the customers, almost impossible to meet the high standards upper management expects. I dreaded going in everyday and felt the stress to meet the high sales goals. all the employees I worked with would just complain all day and create negativity. Horrible once a month store meetings that were absolutely pointless and boring. If you are going to take your coworkers away from family at dinner time, the least  you  could do is buy them dinner and actually have information and coaching that is worth being there for !! Upper management says Scheduling must be out 4 weeks in advance. We were lucky to have 2 weeks and no week was the same so you could not really have a work/life balance unless you're a higher up or in management. Forced, repetitive coaching and training.

review_title: Outdated IT infrastructure and very bureaucratic
employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: Salary is on par with other financial organization.
employeer_cons:
The IT infrastructure department is outdated and is making life harder not only for the developers but also for the business by having a very slow delivery. Where in any companies, ordering a server is a matter of months if not weeks, here you are considered lucky if you get one in a year.  The bureaucracy is out of the chart where you have to fill a form for every small thing you use (library, server ports, ...) that needs to be approved by a humongous number of managers.

Because of that, every team has a very limited number of servers that can barely run their applications and cannot support all the tools that might be needed.

I saw several talented employees that are left with no other choice than looking somewhere else to keep their skills up to date and have a decent career growth.

review_title: Decent place is you like sales jobs
employee_history: I worked at TD full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: It's a very comfortable corporate environment. They do well with keeping the call center from having that negative vibe that you always see in other call centers. The benefits are excellent and very affordable. Very clean work environment.
employeer_cons: Sales.... Ugh. If you don't like sales jobs, don't apply here. They say that sales aren't important, but that is a straight up lie. I saw many times the only way to get promoted out of core was through stellar sales stats. Not every single time, but 90% of the time. Computer chairs suck. Main portal for looking up resources to field questions is unwieldy. They were instituting a new system when I was there, but it was worse then the one it was replacing. But again, it was just being launched. Floor politics... This place is a breeding ground for gossip. Keep your personal life out of there and you'll be better off. And the new flex scheduling sucked. We started off with a fixed schedule. In an effort to cut down wait times, they put all of us on a flex schedule meaning that your hours fluctuated moderately and you were never guaranteed a certain day off. Schedules were created for two weeks in advance.

review_title: TD Call Center in a nut shell
employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
Opportunity for upward progression
One on one time with management to discuss personal development, career goals, and current positions. More so, allowing discussions on how to achieve those goals in the near future.

Fast-paced (most days)

Ability to make a direct impact on the lives of others

Allows for employees to make recommendations toward improvements internally to better support both the employee experience and the customer experience.
employeer_cons:
Need emotional strength: Non-customer facing brings about the boldness in others. Especially, on Tuesdays. There's no telling if an irate customer is about to curse someone out, or if a sweet elder is adjusting their ledger. Either could be this next call.

Rigid scheduling: 
Lack of intra-communication: Promotions (online, regional, call center ect.), system access (what some departments have access to, but don't know it), and the ability to find answers efficiently in the intraweb can be difficult and are sometimes lost in the cracks of the system. (But there IS support to be found elsewhere)

Continuous change in structure: People move into other positions frequently at TD which is both a pro and a con. Pro for obvious reasons (everyone enjoys a promotion). Con because one may sync with one system of personal management, but clash with the next--stunting performance overall.

Built for an Extrovert (Personal preference): As an introvert I gain and restore energy by being able to focus on complex problems and processing internally; using my creative abilities to push me forward and find new solutions to problems. As a call center rep, I speak for eight or nine hours a day. Sometimes, I feel like I'm more entertaining than finding solutions. I come home feeling exhausted. Some say that's a sign of having a successful workday, but not all. Where an extrovert gains their energy and propels through life exchanging energy externally with others, the call center position would work toward their strengths, and they could thoroughly enjoy themselves in this position. As an introvert I found this position to be exhilarating at first (learning to navigate the multiple systems, the physiology of each arm TD possess, gauging myself against the metrics). After 18 months, and having mastered those above by 6 months, I began to feel the erosion of repetition.

review_title: Great opportunity to begin banking career
employee_history: I worked at TD part-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: PTO,  Medical, Dental Insurance, 401 K matches 4.5% max, annual 401 contribution.  Opportunity to learn about banking, mortgages, Business development.  They have TD University and an opportunity to register for courses to gain more knowledge in different areas.  TD also offers tuition reimbursement.  Employees earn quarterly incentives.
employeer_cons: Office politics, no work life balance, pay is below average, most promotions are based on favoritism and who you know, some managers fail to acknowledge hard-working employees,  management overwork their employees and tries to sabotage any employee who speak their minds.  Nothing is really confidential so be mindful what you say to to other employees, management and human resources.   Annual raises are a joke but it depends on who your manager is and  if they favor you .  TD mentions that they are focused on their customers and delivering a "WOW" experience, but its all about numbers, sales goals, leads and money out products.  It takes the fun out of working in a financial institution when you are constantly pressured to promote sales and you are always worrying that your job is on the line each quarter.   Some assistant managers, managers delegate all of their responsibilities (ex: audits, supply ordering, delinquency reports, safe deposit box audits, wire reports) to one Customer Service Representative and still expect them to still make their goals each month.  Some assistant managers and managers don't assist customers even when it gets busy. In addition, some management teams are not supportive.

employee_history: I worked at TD full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
Pay
Training
Culture is ok
FSRs do get to go to a lot of meetings at the TD Garden
employeer_cons:
Your FSR work will be secondary. Your job as being a fully trained bank teller will be prioritized over everything else. No matter what type of work you were planning on doing, prospecting, meeting clients, wanting to go home at a normal time, your job as a bank teller and open/closer will take precedent. 

They didn't give me any room to study for my licensing, because saying hi to people was more important. On my second day, they had me just greeting people at the door, which was not important at the time, studying for the exam has to be important. If you do not pass, you will be let go.

You have to remember, even though you are a quasi-financial advisor, that will not be your role 90% of the time, they will use you as a teller the first chance they get. They will even schedule you as a teller some days. 

At the end of the day, outside of the teller stuff, you are NOT a financial advisor. That job is given to TD Ameritrade. So you can only offer fixed-annuities.

review_title: Company will never let you sleep
employee_history: I worked at TD full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: TD Bank was good to me as a contractor.
employeer_cons: As soon as I became a company employee (as opposed to a contractor) they demanded 70-80 hour weeks.  The  applications are spaghetti code, and they never invest in anything except for band aids.  My manager demanded that I work nights and weekends, and even during my family events.  They make you sign all kinds of conditions for employment that other companies don't so they can use it later to force you into 80 hour weeks.

review_title: Depressing call center work, very pushy sales.
employee_history: I worked at TD full-time for less than a year
employeer_pros: Good benefits, good training.  It may be a good place to work outside of the call center, which is known locally as being a bad place to work and only for in-between jobs.
employeer_cons: The sales you are expected make while working in the call center are ridiculous and to meat your quotas you have to offer products that don't make sense.  People who are promoted are people who can get people to open accounts they don't really need.  Like, a third or fourth checking account to someone who can't manage the ones they have.  You are incredibly isolated from co workers while taking back to back calls.  When I was new, they had me shadow a more experienced Banking specialist who did not follow a lot of the training I had just had.  She just randomly asked every single customer if they would like to open another checking account.  I don't have a problem offering services but it was just ridiculous.  They like to offer checking accounts vs savings because the average checking account produces more fees.

employeer_cons: LEI is screwed up. The surveys are basically hard wired so its a guessing game whether you get a good one or not. You could be as loving with your customers as ever and they'll give you a great review but if they don't want to increase business you're screwed. That's all that really matters. Also you get surveyed by secret shoppers who are sent from corporate TD to rate your transaction. Some are these people are ruthless and don't care if you're busy with a line out the door, you better say their name 3 times,say your name , use a catch phrase to offer them a product, welcome them back, and make sure you seemed so delighted to take their transaction. Remember you don't know who this secret shopper is so you have to act like this with EVERYBODY till you get the report back saying you got shopped. It's just a messed up system.

employeer_pros: Good benefits, the PTO is amazing. I learned a lot in my line of work, but also about employee appreciation & being a good coworker. The WOW! Culture is something I wish many more organizations would learn & adopt. Do a browser search for Halloween photos, they depict this wonderful culture :) They go above and beyond to make Employees and Customers feel special. They have a mission of diversity and inclusivity, and it's apparent. WOW! your Customer, whether internal or external, fosters a positive working environment.
employeer_cons: Balance. During my long tenure, it was always expected to respond to emails at all hours and on vacations. No matter what department I reported to (there were 3 in my tenure, and in separate areas of the bank. Same expectation in each one). I once had to take my laptop to Europe on vacation. Yes, the work is important, but there have to be better backup and coverage plans. And sometimes...it can wait. It's WOW! to get back to people quickly, but you need personal balance too...and some things can wait until Monday.

employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: Good work culture, a lot of support, decent training, very vocal about job role, PTO is decent.  The people I work with are all good people.  Management seems to take an interest in you.  Low stress work environment.
employeer_cons:
The hours are hard to create a routine.  You will work 7 days in a row one week and then have off a weekend.  Also if you work a weekend you will have off a random Tuesday yet work longer hours the rest of the week.  
Some branches are very slow where it is difficult to get sales.
You only have the Life Health Annuity License so you are very limited on the investment options.  
Managers will be moved a lot, sometimes leaving the branch without a manager or assistant for a period of time.
Vacation schedule has to be set up in the beginning of the year, which is difficult to have flexibility when setting up vacation times. 
Most branches are understaffed, you will have a lot of time rushing people in and out instead of being able to take time to explore investment needs with each customer.
Not a great career path for advancement if you want to stay in with investments.  They pretty much say that the only way to get into wealth is to get promoted to Assistant manager and then store manager.  A lot that some people do not want to do to get into TD Wealth.  
Assistant managers deal with a lot of the nonsense and stress from management.  Micromanaging is big too. 
Increases in pay each year are sad.  2% is the most they can offer each year.  
Commission is a mess, and they are bad payouts.

employee_role: Current Employee - Field Project Supervisor/Store Planning
employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: Flexibile PTO, off on most holidays.
employeer_cons: Open 7 days a week

employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: Good people at this level. Upper management seems good too. Flexible hours and a decent amount of PTO. 1 day a week- work from home.
employeer_cons: Terrible management! The managers at ground level look out for themselves. They will take credit for your work and deny, deny, deny. I've seen people get fired or laid off by management, just to prevent them from being wrong or exposed. All the staff talks, but if someone brings anything up to management, they're fired. We are all scared, so we keep our heads down.

employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: Plenty of opportunities for career growth. Consistently awarded for learning and development. Good place to get experience. Great co-workers. Lots of teamwork. Lots of opportunities to network. Managers, including regional and market managers, that genuinely care about their teams and are always accessible. Laid back work environment that lets you have fun with each other and with customers. Plenty of recognition events that reward teams for hard work and results. Very generous PTO time even for newer and entry-level employees. Quick promotions if you're interested in staying in retail for a while.
employeer_cons: Pay scale is terrible. Many employees, especially young and unmarried employees work two jobs. Very easy to hit a learning plateau and get burnt out if you don't want to build your career in retail. Many jobs in more lucrative and challenging departments want at least two years of experience in the store, and it's easy to get burnt out and sick of the low pay before that time is up. Open 7 days a week with long shifts during the week to make up short weekend hours. No rhyme or reason to scheduling either, so unless you like to ask for a lot of PTO, work-life balance is terrible. Benefits are expensive for what they pay us and there's a minimum contribution to get a 401k match, which is difficult if not impossible for most retail employees, who make less than $45k a year. Extreme emphasis on customer service is not for everyone. There's a lot of pressure to make small talk with people, and you're expected to drop everything when there's customers in the store. As a customer, having four employees focusing entirely on me in any retail establishment makes me feel strange, but TD does not see it that way. This kind of culture can be very exhausting and fake-feeling if you're not an extreme extrovert.

employeer_cons: Great Resources and mentoring opportunities

employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: Quarterly bonuses, promotion opportunities, green company, professional, decent base pay, incentives for supervisors to assist in guiding you towards promotions, medical and retirement benefits, HSA options, core contribution to 401k, short and long term disability, paid maternity leave (6 weeks), paid vacation / sick time, ability to schedule your paid time yourself, flexible schedules
employeer_cons: Shared desks (contact center), unable to decorate desks, bathrooms consistently dirty, few smoking sections that take time to get to (I don't smoke but thought this would be relevant to people who do), goals for calls per hour and sales can be difficult to meet, surveys are marked on the most recent representative even if the customer specifically states the rep was amazing but the survey score was low because of hold times or issues at the branch, lunch breaks are only 30min, breaks and lunches are not always consistent (I.e., sometimes my lunch will be at 11am and sometimes it will be at 12:30pm...) Food offered on location is expensive and not worth purchasing (it comes from an off site vendor and often times isn't fresh)

employee_role: Current Employee - Senior Customer Service Representative

employeer_pros:
- Great Brand
- Friendly Co-workers (for the most part)
- many ways to advance (provided you work hard and aren't afraid to network)
employeer_cons:
- lower pay
- iffy work/life balance
- high variance from store to store due to inconsistent manager quality (this is the big one)

employee_history: I have been working at TD
employeer_pros: Good hours, bonuses are sometimes ok. Team building
employeer_cons: Incompetent people, short staffed all the time. Expect you to be a robot and memorize words.

employee_history: I worked at TD  for less than a year
employeer_pros: I Worked here as a summer intern full time. I was paid very well and was treated as a regular employee. I worked on numerous projects and was able to learn more about banking and rotate throughout the summer. Anytime I traveled they would pay for me to go The company is very professional and has a really good culture. I hope to receive an offer upon graduation and I would recommend this company to anyone interested.
employeer_cons: There were no cons. I love the company.

employee_history: I worked at TD full-time for less than a year
employeer_pros: Nice, peaceful, good culture overall
employeer_cons: Boring work, good amount of free time

employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: Employee benefits are a plus

employee_history: I have been working at TD  for more than 5 years

employeer_cons: Open 7 days a week

employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time for more than a year

employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: Good training and education and benefits
employeer_cons: Hard to move up in the firm

employee_history: I have been working at TD
employeer_pros: Great place to work plenty of  growth opportunities
employeer_cons: No cons great place to work I love the people I work with

employee_history: I worked at TD full-time
employeer_pros: Benefits and compensation are good.
employeer_cons: Financial Services Rep program is about 5 years old, they seem to be confused about where they are going with this position. When hired i was told i would do more insurance/retirement products, turned out I was a licensed Customer Service Rep with an added sales goal of financial products. Technically making the position a sales leader role. All of this was revealed after a few months of being hired and going through the training. You will need to either have or get your health and life insurance licenses for this role. Unstable scheduling, some days you will work 12 hrs and other 6 hrs, never consistent. The position is good for learning everything but you essentially become an assistant manager without the title or pay. I had a first year branch manager who didn't know how to manage and only delegate and micro-manage. Career path isn't high since after this position the next level is branch manager.

employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: Culture, people and passion for doing what is right for their employees.  TD is one of the best companies I have worked for or been associated with.  I am also a long term customer of TD and the experience is always consistent and TD employees truly act as advisors and want to ensure you have the right experience and level of support required based on your needs.  This is completely a reflection on TDs recruitment practices and ensuring they hire the right person to fit their culture and vision.  Kudos to TD for attracting and hiring the best people in the market place.
employeer_cons: There is absolutely no negative feedback to provide..

employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: Inclusive and supportive of most decisions you make in our personal life- allow us to be on own individual! Longer hours and weekends allow part time positions to maintain work with us- ex. people attending college, parents with children in school
employeer_cons: I can't think of any significant cons to my job. I have been with TD about 5 years and because of how inclusive the company is, the team at a store level becomes family- so when you lose a member, the entire team feels the pressure of being shorter staffed than accustomed to. Thankfully, the hiring process has become more fluid over the last year or so.

employee_history: I worked at TD full-time
employeer_pros: Very easy to advance in the normal Retail Banking way. If you want to work your way up from a teller to a manager they make this very easy for you.
employeer_cons:
Very hard to transfer out of Retail Banking once you are in it.
You can be fired very easy for an operational mistake.
Need to be sales oriented. Every employee has a sales goal that they HAVE to make.

employee_role: Former Employee - Senior Customer Service Representative
employee_history: I worked at TD full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: Vacation time is out of this world, medical benefits are pretty good, flexible work schedule due to variety of hours the branch is open, no harsh sales goals, friendly managers and staff
employeer_cons: Pay is terrible, no commission on your sales, computer systems are absolutely archaic and would go down all the time! Management expects you to operate on pen and paper in that event. They are always understaffed and expect one employee to do the job of 10. Customers complain about lack of staff, and there is always a line out the door.

employee_history: I have been working at TD part-time for less than a year
employeer_pros: Great work environment. Friendly co-workers. Flexible scheduling. No late night hours. Professional setting. EMPLOYEE FRIENDLY. Benefits (Health care, Vision, Dental, and 401K) Even for part time employees. Quarterly pay incentives (Bonuses).
employeer_cons: Retail job, meaning that sometimes customers can be rude and you have to be polite to them. But that is virtually every profession. No other down sides.

employee_history: I worked at TD full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: TD can be an excellent bank to work for and most departments understand their employees have families our outside obligations to balance as well.  Great time off and benefits, and free online education is continuous and encouraged.  In the right department, there is a fantastic team environment.
employeer_cons: Some departments are still a bit clicky, making it harder for newer team members to transition into the department.  Can be a real cookie cutter or stifling environment for the high energy types.

review_title: Very good company with great outlook.
employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time
employeer_pros:
Great Benefits 
Great work life balance
Generous PTO 
Large company means lots of opportunities. 
Upward mobility is encouraged and important to the company.
employeer_cons: Because of all the acquisitions there are so many systems. I know the goal is to simplify operations, but it very slow.

employee_history: I have been working at TD  for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: Great benefits. as a part time employee you get 6 weeks of Paid time off, tuition reimbursement, dental, vision, health. great company to work for, they really treat their employees well
employeer_cons: you're required to work weekends. the hours vary weekly based on your position. every position is very demanding and can be emotionally exhausting.

employee_history: I have been working at TD
employeer_pros: You can move up the ladder quickly here
employeer_cons: Longer hours then other banks

employee_history: I worked at TD full-time
employeer_pros: Overtime, hour lunch, money management
employeer_cons: Hard to move up, always calling you to come in

employee_history: I worked at TD
employeer_pros: Company works as a team! Yeah yu have individual goals but you definitely have support for reaching those goals
employeer_cons: None that I can really think of! I enjoyed working there

employee_history: I worked at TD part-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: Vacation time. Health and Welfare benefits. The end.
employeer_cons: Unrealistic expectations regarding, call times, time off the phone, sales goals. This company allows their customers to berate and abuse their employees.  The pay isn't particularly good. After working there for a year and getting a .25 raise, the company increased their starting pay, however, long time employees received no increase.  I was encouraged to open second,  third, fourth checking accounts as a way to stop overdrafts, I was encouraged to get the customer to have an additional card for that account and was supposed to get the customer to agree to turn off the the system that prevented them from overdrafting their accounts with their debit card, for "emergencies ". I was written up three times in six months for my lack of "sales" due to my unwillingness to bamboozle customers. If you have no problem selling your soul, this is the job for you.

employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time
employeer_pros: Help from other colleagues in the same role.
employeer_cons: Wish the commission would be greater

employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: A lot of PTO, excellent Sr management and Great place to network with customer. The TD group makes you feel appreciated and important but...
employeer_cons: In the store there is a lot of Micromanaging. I felt like I work for a Military concentration camp and this part really disappoints me. The Store and assistant manager doesn't care about your development and learning opportunities. They are not coherent because they want you to act and think like a customer but they don't do it. They ask us to use the - bump it up system- when you are not sure about something but when you are going to ask them they just act like if you are bordering them. Even their face is like that.

employee_history: I worked at TD full-time
employeer_pros: Great people, enjoyable atmosphere, flexible work environment
employeer_cons: questionable mgmt choices, lack of faith with employees

employee_history: I worked at TD full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: I absolutely loved the team I worked with.  Management was a different story.
employeer_cons: Very low pay and sales goals are pushed hard on tellers.  I've always thought a bank's focus should be on customer service, not sales.  Because I didn't sell, I was never looked at for promotions.  My customer service skills were always highly rated but that was never enough.

employee_history: I have been working at TD part-time for more than 8 years
employeer_pros: Convenient for student employees since it has longer hours/more flexible schedule to work with (than other banks)
employeer_cons: So much political drama (like many banks have) - it's like high school every day, it gets exhausting. But that stems from the leadership, I'm sure other branches have better dynamics. It can be difficult to move into desired positions if you don't have the right people on your side.

employee_history: I worked at TD full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: Good Company with real bad leadership
employeer_cons: This company’s leadership has dual standard and full of hypocrisy. My advice to all current employees that keep track of all communication with your leadership. Chances are you will be left alone and your leadership will not keep their words and you will not be supported you when time comes. I'll be happy to provide addition details if needed (917) 687-9980

review_title: Solid base with minimal room for growth
employee_history: I have been working at TD full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: Insurance selection.  Company culture.
employeer_cons: Vacation time is limited depending on employee status (full time/part time) due to method used in calculating paid time off accrual rate.  You will be forced into using vacation time for any national holiday the bank is closed for in order to meet weekly hours, unless you work extra days.  Vertical movement in the company cuts off on a retail branch level once you hit Assistant Store Manager as upper management frowns upon promoting internally to Store Manager.  Externals for higher positions are seen as the optimal choice due to lower introductory pay and ability to mold into corporate culture with minimal investment needed.

review_title: Maybe try Cisco across the street instead
employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: Great heath and dental, decent 401k contribution, fantastic PTO (vacation, sick, maternity, sabbatical, etc.), multiple employee diversity networks, and a shiny new campus in Raleigh.
employeer_cons:
Offers are incredibly low, it’s actually almost embarrassing for an international investment bank. The same applies to raises and bonuses, no matter how favorable your performance evaluations were.
Diversity and inclusion is just not there yet, especially in Raleigh. I was such a fan of the “culture” and push for “diversity and inclusion” and I ate all of it up but the fact is, the diversity numbers are flat and retention of diverse employees is dismal, likely because they also only promote the same types of people. Not to mention everyone at the top pretty much looks the same. There’s sort of a mix in the middle and at the bottom but not really. Most who have any power or influence are w/m, with a w/f sprinkled in here and there. 
Employees basically go unsupported by ER because guess what, it’s not illegal to be backwards, ignorant, or a bigot, nor do they consider it a fireable offense. If you stick your neck out on the line just know that your career is over at the firm - they will not lay a safety net out for you and you will be labeled “problematic.”
Internal mobility is nearly impossible if you don’t have someone on the inside. You will also never truly get any objective feedback on why you weren’t given an opportunity.

employeer_cons: Fragmented technology. Staff in silos. Very heavy workload — double hating is a normal term here. Not enough staff in NY. Non front office jobs moving to Raleigh, NC — they call this Project Liberty! Eurocentric leadership with no regard or respect for US regulatory expectations. New leadership are composed of uninspiring castoffs from other global banks and former regulators with “semi-retired” work ethic - they’re out the door by 4:55 pm!

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time
employeer_pros:
- Salary is ALMOST at market rate (though had to fight for salary that was still 5k less than male counterparts with less experience)
- COVID's home office mandate helped for escaping daily in-person interactions with the team's more abusive members/managers
- A few genuine folks on the team, serving as beacons of hope until they made their respective escapes
- Office located in the city center, though there are plans to move to sad Oerlikon towers
- Car discount
employeer_cons:
- Absolutely psychotic and delusional upper management that rewards employees for regular 15 hour workdays and cluttered powerpoint presentations
- Abusive, bullying bosses providing a constant stream of conflicting directions/expectations while breathing down the back of your neck at every second
- Total creeps that carelessly leave books out on their desks about manipulation techniques
- Greasy, used car salesman types who fake their way through failed projects while using their colleagues as punching bags, all for the coveted DIR promotion
- Developers from the boondocks who have never heard of Slack and can never properly estimate their work
- Revolving door levels of turnover: 10+ colleagues (out of 15) left the team in under a year, all citing the same reasons, such as "no psychological safety" and "toxic environment" and "abuse"
- HR department only exists to hire and fire-- the only way to report anything is via the "Integrity Hotline," advertised as a place to report highly suspicious and unethical behavior like fraud and proven sexual harassment (effectively discouraging more commonplace issues like deranged bullies)
- Antiquated ways of working while lying about modernity
- Obsession with titles like VP, DIR, etc. though they have zero meaning outside of the bank
- Compliance uses other bank's mistakes as examples while completely ignoring their own colossal failures 
- Nonexistent onboarding, needlessly complicated and irrational offboarding procedure-- making life hell until the bitter end

review_title: Great place to work & to develop your skills
employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 8 years
employeer_pros:
Lots of focus on internal mobility and career development
Opportunities to learn new skills
Exposure to large IT estate and leading technology
Opportunity to collaborate with colleagues and global peers on a daily basis
Compensation and benefits
Focus on Corporate Citizenship and volunteerism
employeer_cons:
- last several years has seen significant IT transformation and reorganization... displacing roles and creating uncertainty
- work-life balance

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
Very inclusive environment - was immediately impressed by the ethnic diversity and number of PRIDE ally flags I noticed when I entered the office my first day of work.

There is a strong culture of internal mobility. Once you are hired, it is likely that you will have opportunities to grow and advance within the organization - even if not in the same business function.
employeer_cons:
I attended a workshop that outlined the promotion process. While I was not employed long enough to pursue promotion (2-3 yrs), the process seemed oddly subjective. From what I understood, unless one has the support of their direct line manager, they can never be promoted. So if a manager does not support one's personal growth, or if there are any clashes between  that manager and employee, that single manager can hinder an individual's opportunity to advance - even if the issue(s) are not performance related.

Titles are also important within this culture and will dictate how much income one can earn and how swiftly they can grow within the organization. Even if experience meets requirements for a role, employees cannot skip title levels. This could be limiting if one is hired as a lesser title simply to "get in" with the company or secure employment.

employee_role: Former Employee - Credit Risk Analyst- Corporates
employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: Financial modeling, weekly presentations to management, industry knowledge
employeer_cons: Not the best opportunity if you’re hoping to be recognized for your hard work. Management primarily sits in the NY office so the day-to-day in Raleigh is overseen by a VP that clearly has favorites and a chip on his shoulder. Role is primarily focused on completing quarterly and annual reviews that can be interesting but are mostly mundane. Compensation is not competitive and you are expected to work long hours. Retention is low.

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: For the most part, your job is secure and you don't have to fear being laid off.
employeer_cons: You will constantly be at odds with their ailing IT infrastructure. I think the payment system at McDonalds is probably more advanced than some of the custom software employees are CS are forced to use. It seriously hinders productivity and efficiency. They keep going on about innovation but they are unwilling to address many of the underlying problems that make the company inefficient in the first place. Furthermore, although the Raleigh site is the largest campus for CS, the company's senior management has no respect for the area and its people. Remember Raleigh employees, the only reason they hire you is because they're too cheap to hire in New York. As a result, the pay is absolutely lousy, completely uncompetitive compared to other banks and other companies in the Raleigh area. Between the lousy pay and the poor IT infrastructure actively hindering your ability to work, it is hard to actually be inspired to work well. Imagine an investment bank that is unable to get timely stock prices due to a broken system, as unbelievable as that is; that is Credit Suisse.

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for less than a year
employeer_pros:
Great Benefits
Great Employee Programs
Opportunity to gain skills
employeer_cons:
After dealing with Recruitment it all went downhill. Recruiter was awesome. Knowledgeable and consistent. Global Markets is an unorganized disaster. The training is inconsistent. Trainers who don't understand or know their job training new hires. The processes are some of the worse I've ever seen and they are not open to feed back. They only want you stuck at your desk all day. 

Pressure to meet deadlines and perform well with no direction and inconsistent feedback. But it's not worth complaining because they will only ostracize you and treat you like you mean nothing.  

Your every move is scrutinized and you're treated as if you are not trust worthy. No one listens to you if you're not praising them. Management focuses on the wrong issues. It appears to be an innovative, encouraging environment but it is outdated in management style. You have to conform to their antiquated way of doing things and you are not allowed to stand out. If you don't behave like the masses they treat you like a criminal. 

Keep your head down, comply, get your experience and leave. Don't believe them when they say they want your input or suggestions. It is a trap. Just smile and agree. Even if the process is broken. They don't want your input because they have to much pride to admit processes are inefficient.  Don't try to be an individual.  Nothing makes since and it won't just do as your told. Also, if you are not "a favorite" they pretty much ignore you. My enthusiasm was crushed one month in.

review_title: Could be great but it isn't
employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse full-time for less than a year
employeer_pros:
The pay is good as an employee that transferred in
Benefits
employeer_cons: Onboarding and training process is awful. I am in upper management and can not get anyone to take time to train me. I am 6 months in and now everyone expects me to do thing that I haven't been shown. I have spoke to numerous people that say "the first year you will feel like you are going to get fired everyday because no one will train you and you don't feel like you know how to do your job". I have literally begged for a list of job duties/responsibilities and training. My boss will not give me any of his time. I am so disappointed on how this has turned out. I am unfortunately looking for a new company. It doesn't have to be this way. Everyone is stretched out and angry. Its a keep your head down and try not to be seen kind of company. Very heavy New York work style here.

review_title: Watched a strong talent management strategy steadily decline over 15 years at firm.
employee_role: Former Employee - Vice President, Global Technology
employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 10 years
employeer_pros: Profit sharing of about 8% profit sharing into 401k yearly is one of the stronger retirement plans.
employeer_cons: The company has no strategy on how to manage and deploy talent with transparency in deploying all positions to low-cost centers without clear strategy except that attrition results in position moving to low-cost centers.  The office workspace is a joke -Credit Suisse is the only NYC based employer in the history of commercial real-estate to fall below the threshold of 100 square foot of office space per employee by basically stacking employees on top of each other.

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: Above average coworker relationships. Good benefits.
employeer_cons: No work-life balance, management chooses favorites. High burnout rate but a good place to learn the value of what a work life balance should be, by being in an atmosphere that doesn’t value it at all. Even though this group is under the CSAM umbrella, the culture and work life balance reflects that of the investment bank. 15+ hour work days (9am-12am) or later is a standard at the analyst level. As an associate, 10-12 hour work days become standard. There has been more turnover in recent years due to the cultural aspects of the team.

review_title: Great learning / not so great work-life balance

employeer_cons: Work life balance is not ideal, and sometimes culture can be not very constructive to team work

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: Office is fancy. Great work-life balance - Hours, WFH option - but negotiate this aspect once you get an offer, smart people. Latest Re-Org in the CRO division seems promising with (what appears) to be a smart/strong CRO.
employeer_cons: People are sneaky, people are not SMEs, there are continuous re-orgs, upper management turnover... the list goes on. The place is so disorganized and operating with a lean headcount, its very hard to execute under these circumstances. Also, no one is about doing the right thing. A lot of talent is leaving and you would be working with satisfactory individuals, which could get frustrating after a while. Promotion is difficult.

review_title: It's tough to be in banking these days
employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 10 years
employeer_pros:
- Philanthropy is a priority
- Offices near Madison Square Park / beautiful historic lobby and building
- Good / friendly  work culture 
- Gym in the building
- Good benefits
- A supportive manager will make all the difference
employeer_cons:
- Pay is not commensurate with experience or performance
- Bonus / discretionary award is laughable
- Very difficult to get title promotions
- Lots of bureaucracy,  it can take ages to get something done
- Office politics plays a huge part in how well your career goes
- Long hours for IT
- Slow to adopt new technology
- Moving many jobs away from NYC
- Smart working floors are crowded and unattractive
- No tech support available by phone - it's all online

review_title: Lousy Comp in COO division, Excellent Benefits, Outdated Senior Mgmt, low appreciation of technology
employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros:
Great benefits:
401k match (up to 6%)
Excellent vision, dental and health insurance
Nice gym in the building
Standing desks are now available to most employees

People:
COO division people are very friendly and helpful. Good culture fit for people who are closer to retirement age. The median age is probably 40 and above.
employeer_cons:
There are not many young people working in back office which probably is the reason why a lot of processes that can be automated are still stuck in the flintstone ages.  Slow in adopting new technology. Senior management speaks highly about the benefits of new technology like robotics and automation, but still prefer powerpoint presentations and piecharts printed on paper. 

Terrible compensation in COO division if you are VP and below. Internal promotion for same role doesn't provide you a big increase in salary. Better to switch jobs. Little growth in skillsets.  Nuff said.

employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros:
Awesome people, great work-life balance, great culture, strong investment in diversity, great opportunities to explore mobility to other roles internally
Started my career here out of college and have grown so much professionally as well as met a ton of incredible people!
employeer_cons:
The analyst program lumps all Technology new college hires together for the same salary, which means that it may be more or less competitive to other offers depending on what you majored in in college.
General sense that technology/back office is a 'lesser' role than front office/finance positions in the eyes of the firm as a whole. 
Lack of an Associate title in Technology means that new college hires have to wait 4+ years for a formal promotion, which gives a sense of a lack of upward mobility and stagnation and can be off-putting.

review_title: Too much micro management, slapped down for everything.

employeer_pros: Clean work areas and restrooms.

Management only knows numbers, they have no idea how it is to be a tech, the stress and they expect more than what's possible on a human being. There is no time for life outside work, there are no options for overtime. I worked many days where I was an hour past and told I would be fired if I submitted that extra hour to payroll as they do NOT want to pay overtime or extra hours. No bonus or benefits to keep employees happy!

employeer_pros: Benefits and salary were okay.
employeer_cons: For all its talk of innovation, this company is stuck in the past. Seniority is prized and longtime employees are unwilling to entertain change. Newcomers are discouraged from introducing new ideas. This is a company where "We've always done it this way" is still excusable. Make no mistake - this may be a global company, but it is Swiss to the core. Diversity is an abstraction here. Hiring and management practices that would immediately raise red flags in a U.S. company are treated as routine.

employeer_cons:
- Shift of strategy starting in October 2015 resulted in numerous changes to the business, including low morale and consistent turnovers (especially true on the S&T and Research side)
- Unclear focus of strategy and commitment to businesses 
- Turnover has been a huge issue either by choice or via downsizing (on average, every other week someone I knew left;  senior members / head of business would rotate in/out so much that it became almost comical) 
- Very limited career opportunities due to politics and the constant changes 
- Lack of transparency is a huge issue

employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 8 years
employeer_pros: Collegial atmosphere, better than at any of 3 other large financial services firms I've worked for. Good teamwork. Working from remote locations is well supported. Management is serious about diversity; a wide variety of employee networks are supported by management (Black Professionals' Network, Asian Professionals' Network, Veterans' Network, New Generation Professionals' Network, Americas Women's Network are only a few). Good focus on philanthropy, although donations to U.S. educational institutions are not matched.
employeer_cons: Swiss-based focus takes decision-making (and rewards) away from U.S.-based staff. Often conference calls with Zurich or Wroclaw start at 7AM and can go back-to-back until 1PM; night calls with Asia are not unknown. Each year since 2009, total comp has dropped for me and everyone I know at CS. A large proportion of NYC jobs are outsourced to consultants / contractors. A high proportion of NYC employee positions are being relocated to North Carolina with dramatic pay cuts . Given these circumstances, not much chance for advancement, of course.

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 10 years
employeer_pros:
Good investments in Technology and online training content.
Good cafeteria in NY location. But very expensive. U get no subsidies of any kind. 

Cannot think of anything else.
employeer_cons:
Bad place to grow your career. Bad or poor hiring practices and rampant politics and nepotism have led to a toxic culture where hard work is overlooked and bad managers who should have been fired for flouting corporate rules thrive! 
They have good policies and practices on the books but somewhere along the way they have lost it. 
HR who is supposed to be the last line of safety against harassment and abuse are toothless tigers. 
I would recommend anyone joining this firm to use it as a starting point for a short stint and Look for better opportunities elsewhere. 
They have been singularly focused on cutting costs and have totally forgotten about the adage - what U pay is what u get!
