review_title: Great place to start a career in finance
employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: Great benefits, positive culture of doing the right thing for colleagues and clients.
employeer_cons: To get promoted, your manager nominates you for promotion and makes their case to a promotion committee which includes people from other departments. The committee must approve the promotion. Often many on the committee don't know you personally because they don't work with you, and you're just a name on a piece of paper, so if they disagree that you should be promoted it doesn't matter that your team thinks you should be promoted. Thus, this process heavily favors extroverts and people who join lots of extra-curricular activities and groups which enables them to know many people in other departments and get their names out there. If you just want to do a good job and then go home at the end of the day you will be disadvantaged against those who are always networking and getting involved in outside-of-work stuff.

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time
employeer_pros: Decent work/life balance on our team; bright junior bankers; ability to work with seasoned bankers on other teams and gain insight into their own experiences
employeer_cons: Our small team was headed by someone petty, reactionary, and protective of the team bully (despite complaints from three separate individuals about their actions). Short of going straight to Jim Amine, there was no other mechanism to prevent consistent caustic interactions that were rubber stamped by our boss. COO provided little meaningful support and became a secondary mouthpiece for the group head. Unfortunately, despite being a consistently high performer in my reviews and after years of dedication, I left because the culture on the team became so unbearably toxic and mimicked trashy behavior that I haven't seen since middle school.

review_title: Basically what you think it would be
employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: Who YOU are; someone who does their job, correctly, and doesn't need to be watched as they diligently work away. This environment is conducive to this approach, with good resources and great facilities. The kind of work is manageable and my experience with those banking personalities (hot heads) has been almost, non existent. In turn, yes, management is not on top of the admins, teams mostly help each other out, morale is oookay, and this is a decent living, if not a brief stop/pause in your career path, as one ascends to something more... meaningful.
employeer_cons: TURNOVER HEAVY, management is really inefficient- god only knows what they're doing if they are not actively managing people (the admins.) Bankers are not children, so why does the position cater to them as if they were infants? A good portion of the work one does could have been avoided with some adolescent-level organization. For most, a day here involves working until fatigue dominates whatever time off is to be had. Taking vacation is tantamount to sin. Unless one's best years are invested, an in-human level of servitude, and a lack of feeling towards exhaustion, don't expect a raise, a promotion, or a modicum of consideration outside a yearly, week long vacation and a couple of email-thanks... bankers and admins. Maybe some tips for service if you have some grit, but not if you fall short for a minute.

HR team needs to be vetted for their competitiveness, totally unprofessional in their attitude in dealing with employee issues. If you are hiring Work visa employees, understand what work visa is, that's your job role.

review_title: Credit Suisse, good company to work for.

employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 8 years
employeer_pros: Good people (just not at senior management (decision making) level).
employeer_cons: Organization lacks direction. Matrix organization with too many reporting lines so no one is really accountable for anything also creates serve conflicts of interest.  Culture has changed drastically in last 2 years for the worse.  CEO has created culture where everyone is out for themselves. Severe cost cutting/penny wise-pound foolish mentality.  Work-life balance does not exist.  Not allowed to hire, even in key roles so expectation is everyone needs to work 12+ hr days, everyday to make up for lack of appropriate staffing levels. Then faulted/scapegoated when things go wrong or don't get done.  Unsustainable.

review_title: The Prime Services is a pretty horrible place to work. work life balance is horrible.
employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time
employeer_pros: I can't think of any. Initially I thought salary is a pro but other banks pay much more for similar profiles.
employeer_cons: They treat you like machines, give you work which is not very meaningful (Lots of number crunching and excel sheet process that you won't know what its for). In long run working here will not add much to your skillset unless you are working in a very key role which is rare. Most people end up leaving the firm in a 1 year. If you are lucky and stick around, they start giving you hints by the time you are in your third year, to look for another job, which makes sense, you are still doing the same work as a first year since your skill hasn't improved, and you are getting paid more.

employeer_cons:
Being at a bulge bracket means there is lots of pitching that usually does not lead anywhere
Lots of labor-intensive grunt work that does not end up being used

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: Good benefits. Low premium health plans, many options to choose from. Matching 401K.
employeer_cons:
Promotion process is highly subjective. Based more on who you know, not what you know or deliver. Took 6 years and 3 lateral moves to get into a department where management was not threatened by talent before I was promoted and I was rated a top performer consistently year after year. 

Rating system is based on a bell curve but this does not work when some teams have less than 10 people. Overt hiring of college talent leaves few options for older and experienced workers.

Pay is 28% below market value for senior talent. This is according to Glassdoor!

Current CEO is not accessible, holds executive meetings off-site and only interested in cutting costs. 

Many IT departments require non-officer team management to 'self-fund' by convincing senior business leaders to fund poorly defined projects that rely on junior talent to deliver.  

There is also a culture that will not recognize your abilities if you don't hold a title of VP or above. 

Some management in IT are overly-aggressive and will frequently badger employees into delivering on unrealistic goals and use intimidation tactics in the presence of co-workers to wield their influence.

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: not overloaded with work and nice people
employeer_cons: not space for innovation. Not so smart senior management

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: Great benefits and many learning opportunities.
employeer_cons: Management not always available to talk to about issues.

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time
employeer_pros: Great external reputation in the financial world, friendly and mostly younger employees, great benefits (medical, 401k, PTO). Credit Suisse is also big on internal mobility and urges employees to try out new roles within the organization.
employeer_cons: Compensation is less than industry average, since Credit Suisse prides itself on optimizing cost-cutting strategies in case of a market downturn. It seems as though management expects long hours to be put in, but there is no over-time pay (only half time). Promotions process is ambiguous and promotions are hard to come by, and seems to be more based on networking rather than performance. It doesn't seem like there is a lot of room for career growth, I've seen many people who have been with the firm for 3+ years who have not yet been up for promotion. There is high analyst attrition and many get their 1-2 years of experience before moving on.  I've seen multiple candidates hired with no former business education or background (leading to slow learning curves and decreased performance).

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: Pockets of good people. Interesting projects.
employeer_cons: Lots of red tape to get anything done. Very political.

review_title: New management has changed the culture of the firm for the worst....
employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros: Good benefits and compensation for employees.
employeer_cons: The company is also slow to change and not invested enough in technology.  The firm is not committed to having excellent people and doing excellent, innovative work.  It is slow-moving, consensus driven in the wrong way, and bureaucratic.   The new management team is not transparent with employees, does not accept feedback well, and is not committed to providing a positive environment and culture for its employees.  They are decidedly unfriendly and autocratic-- a disappointment, considering that the previous CEO and leadership team was truly accessible, authentic and down to earth.

review_title: Fantastic Company in a Challenged Industry
employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: One of the best companies in the world with top talent from top schools.  However, there has definitely been a brain drain to VC and tech as salaries are under pressure while hours continue to be intense. That said, this is still one of the premier investment banks in the world.
employeer_cons: Layoffs in equity research (and other divisions) are frequent as the industry is clearly headed in the wrong direction as markets becomes more efficient causing more investment dollars to flow into passive investments and regulations continue to kill profitability. CS remains a great company but the industry is not what it used to be.

employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse  for more than 10 years
employeer_pros:
CS is a large company that provides employees the opportunity to have numerous, different jobs during their tenure to diversify their skill sets.  Over the past 5 years the Firm has greatly increased its appetite for internal mobility.  An employee has a much higher chance for a new role over an "outsider".  

The people / culture are one of the biggest drivers for employees that have long tenures.  While it is a big company, most groups are small and the environment is generally collegial.
employeer_cons:
Credit Suisse is under a lot of regulatory scrutiny and fixed costs to run the business have risen, which have negatively impacted employee job security and compensation.  Most foreign banks operating in US with employees in the NY office, in particular, are struggling.  

After a new CEO was appointed in mid-2015, there is still a lot of uncertainty about further imminent re-organizations and changes in senior management, which makes strategic planning difficult.

Overtime is Half time i.e $10-$13 per hour depending on your salary

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: Most investment banks I've worked at or have had friends at seem to be singularly driven by short-term profit and completely ignore employee development. Credit Suisse, like Goldman, doesn't view its employees as transactional and really focuses on helping them develop careers either within their existing group or elsewhere in the organization. This ultimately leads to a bench of talented employees and impressive retention (in a cutthroat industry)
employeer_cons: Investment banking & asset management are challenging businesses and not for the faint of heart.

review_title: Wage theft, retaliation, and worker misclassification thanks to Credit Suisse
employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for less than a year
employeer_pros: I have a valid federal lawsuit filed in NYC against Credit Suisse & NTT Data, Inc. for misclassification as an independent contractor, failure to pay overtime, retaliation. I have numerous e-mails that I received from an attorney representing NTT Data, Inc. that confirm all of my allegations against Credit Suisse and NTT Data, Inc. Credit Suisse approved timesheets confirming I worked 50-hour workweeks on average in 2012 that I still haven't fully been paid for. It's quite possible that a thorough audit of Credit Suisse's labor practices may be conducted by one or more regulators. The U.S. Department of Labor issued updated guidance last week about what constitutes a joint-employer that strengthens my lawsuit. Losing to me in court may have additional consequences for Credit Suisse, such as whether shareholders keep or cease their investments in a company that is already a felon.
employeer_cons: In retrospect, I should have made a greater effort to identify additional people at Credit Suisse that were subject to similar labor practices to further strengthen my lawsuit.

review_title: Low pay and peanuts for bonus in Credit Risk Management.
employee_role: Former Employee - Credit Risk Analyst ENO
employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
Strong internal mobility support, but they require that you stay in your current role for a year. I was outta there in 18 months so can't speak much.

Good gym - $40 bucks per month for analysts, more expensive the more senior you are.
employeer_cons:
Very very low pay. Came from front office into risk, two years experience when I joined, they paid $80k base (I started in November), no bonus come January, and the following January, $800 dollars (yeah you read that right, that's 1%) in base raise, and an $8k bonus. This was after strong performance exceeding expectations. I took advantage of the $10k per year tuition reimbursement (I was doing my Masters degree part-time), and management had the cheek to imply that the BONUS WAS LOW BECAUSE I ALREADY GOT a 10k reimbursement.

Bear in mind that the tuition reimbursements do NOT come from your team's budget. Could be a really bad boss. Stay away from risk management here.

Jumped ship 18 months later to a hedge fund, now 100k + 50k bonus. Good riddance Credit Suisse!

employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse full-time
employeer_pros: Good name on your resume, people respect Credit Suisse as an institution. Nice view from SF office.
employeer_cons: Limited professional development, benefits are sparse - no coffee, no holiday party, pay half of your health insurance, limited PTO. review_title: Most IT workers in U.S offices are foreigners or recent college hires.
employee_role: Current Employee - IT Assistant Vice President
employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
It is a job (when most U.S. IT jobs have been outsourced to foreigners).
Schedule flexibility (very limited).
Internal training (very limited).
Business casual dress code (jeans allowed).
Opportunity for new hires to gain broad professional experience.
employeer_cons:
Managers discourage employee engagement in internal training opportunities but encourage participation in goofy activities to make their team look active in company community. 

It is a very punitive environment; team has been told that if anyone misses reporting their status on time, forgets to close a request for change (RFC) on time, etc., even just one time, their rating is automatically reduced to a B. Getting a B status would prevent the team members from qualifying for internal mobility and could impact their salary and bonus, if there is one. 

IT employees have to listen to bastardized English all day because very few IT workers speak fluent English, and workers are expected to understand the message that is relayed even if the wrong message is mistakenly delivered. Employees receive conflicting messages regarding the assignment expectations and are expected to meet the different expectations at the last minute.

Managers from India, and even workers from India, seem to aggressively push for work to be sent off-shore or to bring more off-shore employees to the US. They look for excuses to send the work off-shore. They try to facilitate sending work off-shore too, but do not assist the U.S. workers in the same way.

It is definitely a foreign work environment, not an American work environment. It is like entering India when you arrive on the IT floors. 

The schedule flexibility is minimal and managers ding you if you exceed their undocumented and unspoken quota, even if they approve it (late arrival due to doctor appointment or work from home). 

There is a significant communication problem in IT due to the language and cultural barriers.

The application-level onboarding is terrible. 

The communication gap and cultural gap create much unnecessary frustration for employees, not to mention the loss of information critical to the success of projects, and draining the morale.

Foreigners promote foreigners like in a good old boys type of network, excluding U.S. citizens. 
They promote the foreigners at the expense of the U.S. citizens. When work is going well for a U.S citizen, they will yank it from them and send it off-shore. When the foreign manager is in a jam due to being behind on something way overdue, they will assign it to a U.S. citizen. They do very little to help the U.S. citizen learn applications even when other workers are familiar with it, but expect the U.S. citizen to learn and document the applications to make it "easy" to bring the off-shore workers up to speed, to send the work off-shore when there are unemployed U.S. citizens who could do the work right here.

employeer_cons: Generally, teams are very lean, which means team members are expected to "play up" a level -- i.e. analysts become associates, associates become VPs, etc.  The flip side of the coin is that you learn a lot from being on lean teams.

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time
employeer_pros: It is a very prestigious institution that holds itself to extremely high standards. Provides great opportunities and has a top team with human values. Located at an unbeatable place.
employeer_cons: IB hours are long, and no one cares that they're long, as it is a given in the industry. Still, this bank probably has among the most reasonable hours.

employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: Supports meritocracy. Very professional conduct. You will learn daily. Opportunity to grow. Supports mobility. High into D&I campaign.
employeer_cons: Under resourced, so more work and long hours. Regional bias, Americas aren't the favorites. Hard to justify high cost center position if you're in NY, oddly no issue if you're in London or Zurich.

employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse full-time
employeer_pros: Competitive environment - stimulating, smart employees. Culture that is conducive to learning, and friendly co-workers.
employeer_cons: Work life balance can be a challenge, but everyone knows that when they sign up.

employee_role: Former Employee - Junior Chief Operating Officer
employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 10 years
employeer_pros: Very collaborative. Great group of people. Very smart atmosphere. Challenging.
employeer_cons: Long hours but that was welcome in exchange for big bonuses.

review_title: Investment Banking - Equity Capital Markets Associate
employee_role: Current Employee - Equity Capital Markets Associate
employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: Credit Suisse has a diverse work force, and a management team that is committed to an accepting culture. This attitude is reflected in the majority of employees, which makes it a pleasant place to work. Work life balance is not necessarily possible in Investment Banking, but Credit Suisse seems to be more sensitive to it than other firms. Junior people are not expected to work Friday nights or Saturdays, which is a dramatic shift from what it was like 5-10 years ago. Compensation is competitive, and the work experience is very good because the firm works on many of the more high profile transactions. Internal mobility is another focus for the firm, which creates many opportunities for people that want to move around and try new things
employeer_cons: Although it's not as bad as some other banks, working in investment banking is just as grueling at Credit Suisse for the most part. Also, since it's a large company, junior people don't have as many opportunities to "see the whole picture" as resources as often assigned to specific roles and are not able to work on certain aspects of a transaction

employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros:
I joined the IT analyst program which was definitely a great career starter and provided great exposure to the company and the different businesses. The benefits are very solid and high performers have plenty of ways to get recognized with various initiatives and a cash bonus from your manager. 

Internal mobility is widely advertised and strongly encouraged, it's a nice win-win for everyone and I made a move one year in and as a result have no regrets. I now have a new network of colleagues and get to see things from a different perspective. International mobility is also encouraged and supported.

There are a lot of internal networks and communities that a lot of employees partake in and there seems to be something for everyone, with enough support and a sponsor you can even create your own! 

Joining from college I was very impressed by the general level of professionalism and drive a lot of people have here. Now, I'm not one to like politics and tend to stay away from political matters. Like most large financial institutions there is going to be a fair amount of it in play the higher up the food-chain you go and Credit Suisse is no different. I will say it certainly pays to have good reputation with as many people as possible. 

Every year CS hosts an event recognizing individuals and groups who have contributed heavy to philanthropic efforts and every year I see employees from all ranks and departments devoting their own time to charities, outside initiatives, non-profit boards and local community projects which is really inspiring and lends an interesting contrast to the work-work-work mentality. CS gives all FTEs one full day off a year to participate in a philanthropic event or project.

Depending on your manager you may be given some leeway to have flexible work hours and work from home. I take full advantage of this and spend maybe 30% in the office. It helps break the daily routine and saves time, commute costs and energy.

All my managers have been very supportive of me and have been willing to defend my work and actions in front of others. They have all encouraged me to drive my own career and always seek new opportunities. They've also not tried to micro-manage me and put of a lot of trust and responsibility on me. They always made time for me if there was something urgent that needed addressing and in my opinion have been honest, no-BS type of people who I look up to.
employeer_cons:
Depending on your role you might experience a fair amount of red tape which will prolong tasks like requesting resources (servers, applications, access) and tools. IT procurement is probably one of the most painful due to the number of justifications and approvals required.

Tight budgets and heavy regulations will likely have an effect on your productivity one way or another. The plus side to this is that, compared to smaller companies, accountability, ownership and responsibility is more heavily weighted here but I've been in situations where there has been finger pointing or where people didn't take responsibility for a project or consequence. 

Working in IT I'm exposed to what seems to be a never-ending spree of change freezes which, unless you request an exception, causes all production impacting changes to be postponed until after the freeze, major/minor releases, changes to a production server, even the smallest of changes.

Along with the above CS seems to have a process for everything (if you can find out what it is). Having a relatively junior position I use my naive-ness to point out processes that are much too burdensome for small requests but a lot of time there's a lot of push-back to change the process that has been around for a long time (people also like hiding behind processes to evade extra work or to play the evasion/hot-potato game). It sometimes feels like I'm taking to a brick wall in these situations and the only way is to escalate this up but sometimes it's just not worth bothering.

Being a global organization means that certain platforms and applications are only supported out of one region and sometimes you'll loose a good chunk of time due to time-zone delays (you're always asleep when they're awake and vice versa). Having the support team be in more than a single region could help but unfortunately, like in the case of Switzerland, certain operations cannot be outsourced due to regulatory or legal reasons.

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: Credit Suisse has a business casual, laid back atmosphere.  A lot of the people that work there have been employees for many years.
employeer_cons: Credit Suisse is notorious for taking care of the big players and ignoring everyone else.  Unlike most investment banks, CS only pays half time to non exempt employees (as opposed to time and a half).  And bonus for operations and middle office staff are below average.

review_title: Good training can't overcome the selfish nature of this business
employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
Strong belief in training - the firm sends its MBA private banking associates to Zurich for three weeks and then to New York for six weeks to get acclimated to the firm's culture, products, and people

Stellar reputation for private banking - no one does it better than the Swiss (some tax issues, not withstanding)
employeer_cons:
No loyalty to employees - this is not new to anyone and is standard across the industry, but they unceremoniously fired the managing director in 2012 who had been there for years. 

No collaboration between colleagues - not only a dog-eat-dog culture but colleagues were known to attempt sabotaging peers to get better leads or clients.

Private bankers don't care about incoming MBA's or relationship managers - again not unique to CS but common to all private wealth management, but there really is no incentive for any established RM's to help people

employeer_cons: "Smart working" desks so everyone sits on top of each other, dull work, rampant incompetence, expectations that you work 24/7, vacation time is declined unless you agree to work during and then they don't pay out accrued time when you quit. I am still having ptsd from this place. I couldn't get a monitor but my MD had a special desk installed and had custom artwork hung.... I could go on and on about the horrors.

employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 10 years
employeer_pros: There are many very talented people at CS that are passionate about their jobs, truly care and want to make a difference.
employeer_cons:
These very same talented people are put in impossible situations.  The firm continues to be pound wise-penny foolish, cutting areas that desperately need resources to meet regulatory requirements, outsourcing jobs to unqualified/inexperienced people in CoEs in lower cost regions just to save a few dollars not taking into account the true economic impact on the bottom line by lost/lower productivity, sub-par deliverables and missing regulatory deliverables.  Certain areas of the firm have been underfunded and under-resourced for so many years that it has now reached a critical tipping point....borderline crossed over to the point of no return in terms of the firm's ability to meet current regulatory commitments.  The issue is only exacerbated by all of the new regulatory requirements set to take effect in the next 1-3 years (ex: Volcker, etc.).

Work-life balance does not exist.  Expectation is to work 12+ hour days, every day in order to meet deliverables and make up for mismanagement of the firm for years (see above regarding resourcing).  If pay made up for the extra hours logged that would be one thing but there is no increase comp for essentially doing 2 jobs.

The bank cannot do anything about this, but the system should be geared to more going after the individuals that make mistakes personally rather than levying massive fines on the bank itself, as it is very unfair for all other employees putting in hard work.

review_title: Great place to start your career (IT Back office)
employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 8 years
employeer_pros: Work life balance is great in IT Back office. Pay scale is mid-level in the industry. Lots of opportunities for personal development and internal training. Work from home available and encouraged by management to alleviate some of the stress of work load. Campus recruits have a proper job growth track and given the freedom to choose from areas to work in and also to move internally after the first year. Internal mobility is possible. some have used it to move across continents.
employeer_cons: Promotions are not standardized and depends on who knows who. Many a times a person is able to negotiate a title purely because on cultural ties or because he is the loudest in the team irrespective of who actually works hardest in the team. Often times management appears stone deaf to your problems. If you are stuck with a bad manager the only option you got is to move if not there is no opportunity for training or growth and lots of hard work and no reward.

employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: Benefits are pretty solid, although they have been getting reduced.  Starting out with 15 vacation days/year, with the ability to roll 10 days to next year is pretty great.  $4k flat contribution to 401k regardless of your contribution is definitely top notch.  Half-time overtime is laughable, but it's in the Pros section, because there doesn't have to be overtime at all.  Very little taking work home with you.
employeer_cons: Job is extremely redundant.  Sitting in front of a computer all day might not be for everyone.  Priorities are often unclear or fluid based on the attitude of the day.  Compensation is rather lackluster, especially in the way they promote.  Usually, you are unofficially promoted first.  Then, at the end of the year there may be a raise.  However, that won't become effective until April 1.  It's not retroactive, and we are paid on the 15th & last day of the month, meaning you won't see that raise until April 15.  To be promoted to AVP (the lowest title you can have,) you must apply at the end of the year.  Being located in RTP, you're also extremely replaceable considering the nearby schools.

review_title: To every season, churn, churn, churn
employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: The best part of CS was the opportunity to see a Swiss bank morph from the core business of SECRECY to a mainstream financial organization.  It's not there yet, but moving in that direction.  When I joined, someone said, "that's where the smartest people work."
employeer_cons: Unfortunately, many of the smartest people have been RIFed.  Outside of Switzerland, the churning of talent is phenomenal -- and the word is out on the street.  If this is Tuesday, we must have a new strategy.  The posters and sayings do not align with the practices.  Perfect example -- much marketing of opportunities for women and yet the disproportionate # of seniors (MDs) RIFed have been women.  Politics have replaced meritocracy in the US.  DLJ retail brokerage mindset is not the same as a true private bank, and changing the label does not make it so.  Little is done to develop new MBAs post training in the US -- turnover is higher than 80%.

review_title: Long hours, low morale, generally toxic culture
employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: Well respected investment bank, decent exit options

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
- Employee perks were decent, but probably still worse than their competitor's.
- Very inspirational head of talent (google Pamela Thomas-Graham).
- If you like cubicles: the cubicles here are spacious
employeer_cons:
- The work is not challenging at all. If you are not looking to stay in the finance industry all your life, then plan to leave as soon as you can. Regardless of your department (even tech included), the soft (emphasis: SOFT) skills you build here will have no relevance to any other position in any other company. Plan on staying here if your dream is to make excel spreadsheets for the rest of your life. The tasks you do here become so specific to one subfunction of one old proprietary computer system that this will actually hurt any future career endeavors. Try explaining what you do here as something to impress future job interviewers (hint: sometimes I felt like my Credit Suisse entry in my resume made it look even worse than if it wasn't there at all).

- The environment was absolutely sad. Yes there were some kind, good-humored colleagues, but everyone - and even they - were very explicitly dissatisfied with or indifferent to their jobs. No one liked coming to work. People only came to work to count down days till the weekend. 

- Everything regarding professional development and mentorship felt extremely shallow. Goal setting and performance reviews were largely made out of interrelationship fluff and emphasis on commanding menial tasks. 

- Regarding just the micro-perks of an office space - I think most corporations will give you SOMETHING free to bring up your daily mood, right? AT LEAST coffee, right? Nope, good luck finding that here. All you get is free water and sugar packets.

review_title: Stay away from IT in the AMRS region at least in the equity derivatives space.
employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: Location and having the name of a "big" bank on your resume.
employeer_cons:
1) I was hired after the crash in 2008 after mass layoffs at another firm.  They gave me a lowball offer that I unfortunately had to take - not a great way to start building trust.

2) All the decisions for this company are made in other regions.  Equity derivatives IT was a bare-bones operation in AMRS.  The management decisions were made in London and nearly ALL of the development and tech talent was in Singapore.  Every ounce of knowledge I needed to learn was offshore and specifically in Singapore.  I consider myself a fairly motivated person driven to succeed but you can't build a good initial knowledge base of the systems you need to work on if the only folks you have to talk to are in the complete opposite time zone and too busy to teach you which leads me to my next point.

3) The folks in Singapore(mostly from India) were worked like they were at a Foxconn factory and we in AMRS were expected to compete with that.  This essentially means no upward mobility if you want any kind of a life.

4) The lower level managers are pretty weak and transparent in their efforts to pull results out of people and teams.  I wouldn't consider any of them good leaders or even good mentors.  Managers are afraid of upper management and just whip folks below them.  Part of this is company culture but years later being in that position myself I either mentor and look after my folks properly or it's time to leave.

5) Insane amount of bureaucracy but this is typical of a Swiss bank - you wouldn't see this at other investment banks at that time.

6) Insanely cheap; penny wise and dollar foolish - management couldn't wait to get their hands on the next up and coming tech-region where folks were even more desperately looking for work.  This year Singapore, next year close down that hub and head over to Malaysia or somewhere else all the while killing continuity in your development projects and team growth.  It's not like they were paying the folks in Singapore anything good either compared to a salary in the EMEA or AMRS region.  Beyond that, offshoring everything and providing everyone an awful service just to save a buck just gets annoying to all but upper-management.  You're constantly trying to sync up with folks in other regions and more time is spend doing that than actually getting anything done.

Years later I have learned that offshoring can be utilized but there are limits.  Follow-the-sun models and regional dependencies look great on paper but in reality they are much tougher to execute properly for the folks actually doing it.  You'll wind up with a high turnover rate.

7) No free coffee - this seems small and petty but it raises an important point.  If a company is too cheap to offer free coffee at the bare minimum you do NOT want to work for them.  This is the cheapest and simplest daily "thank-you" lifestyle accommodation a company can make for their employees.

I'm sure there are folks who are very happy in this company but they are at least at the director level where they can stay above the churning of the masses.  Don't be dazzled by big banks for IT; you will not get ahead there.  Unless you're coming in at a high level use the short time you have there to learn how they do things and how not to do things.

Further they are also able to pass the blame to their subordinates for anything that goes wrong and there is no opportunity for workers to refute their claims as HR just turns a blind eye. Also, no one really seems to know whats going on as there is a fair amount of turnover and restructuring and the information systems are a mess as management cuts corners with everything.

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than a year

employeer_cons:

employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros:
Overall, Credit Suisse offers a lot to its employees outside of our primary roles. There are numerous affinity groups that help you connect and network across the bank through shared interests (veterans, photography, toastmasters, women, LGBT etc.) and an emphasis on giving back to the community through individual and team philanthropy. They give all employees one day off a year to volunteer at the non-profit of their choice and are supportive of employees joining non-profit boards. 

The firm as a whole has a big push on internal mobility, which is great for career development over the years and for continuity of company culture.

The collaborative environment means that you will succeed here if you are able to develop a strong network and foster relationships within and across departments.
employeer_cons:
As with all other companies, your experience as an employee is significantly defined by your immediate group and manager. Some managers are better at executing on the Credit Suisse culture and beliefs than others.

The con of a collaborative environment is that there are times when getting everyone on board and committees add bureaucracy and slow down initiatives. It is a fine balance.

review_title: Not the sexiest job, but a good job for sure
employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse full-time for less than a year
employeer_pros:
- Decent benefits
- young workplace environment (mostly everyone I work with in their mid-20's) which is less intimidating for a recent college grad like myself. From what I can tell, your enjoyment of your job at CS completely depends on the team you are assigned to. My team is very sociable and always talking, making work much more bearable. I see other teams in the office that don't seem to talk... ever. I don't imagine I could work on a team like that for very long.
- learning opportunities
employeer_cons:
-inconsistent hours. you never know when you're going to end up working until 7 and/or later.
-some weekend work
-Some managers (not all) seem like they don't want to be bothered by the "analysts" and their problems

review_title: High turnover - standard technology.  Over promise and under deliver

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 5 years

employeer_cons: While a great company, the red tape can be at times very frustrating. It takes a while to get people through the hiring process particularly when it is close to the end of year. The best time to join CS in my opinion is February or March, when recruitment budgets are open.

review_title: Fixed income IT is a complete mess, biz leadership is non existent
employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: They will pay you as new employee on the way in.
employeer_cons: Expect to be abandoned after initial hire.  Steady decline in comp.  IT org is a mess on the FID side, Equites IT better.  If you're a manager that owns a budget, be prepared to spend all of your time in the constant (I mean constant) quest for funding and the constant (I mean constant) defense against random budget and staff cuts.  Staff morale very low, voluntary attrition rate very high.  A few pockets of happy and productive folks - so it varies quite a bit by manager (like everywhere).  Overall climate is one of cost-cutting to the extreme.  Staffing restrictions mean is all but impossible to hire a direct employee, even if one resigns - you can only hire contractors.  Take a look at how well, or not well, your business is doing before join - you'll find that very informative to your decision.  Cost cutting, cost cutting, staff cuts and more cost cutting.  If you like to get stuff done, it's a tough place for that. If you want to hide and just be employed while eking out an existence, might be the right place for you.

review_title: Great benefits but work environment will vary by team.
employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: Company benefits are great but growth and training will vary by the department you're working in. For the most part, everyone I met was professional and supportive, inside and outside of my department. The cafeteria was great, loved the food selection, especially on comfort food Thursdays. I could then work off those calories at the on-site gym, one floor away. Also had on-site mani-pedis, shoe shining, and dry cleaning by the gym.
employeer_cons: My department was doomed to downsize given the Volcker Rule so it was only a matter of time before I had to get out of there. When my manager left and I was exploring lateral opportunities within the company, the HR department wasn't helpful at all. They basically allowed me to stay on for as long as it took to find a new job but didn't even point me in the right direction to look at positions within the firm that I could potentially take.

review_title: Great training and culture as an analyst program.  Still used by most as a platform to other jobs
employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
Positive and cooperative culture relative to the investment banking universe.  

Once you establish some competency and an ability to get work done, managers will go out of their way to get you onto good deals, and also be supportive of some level of work/life balance.  Sure the hours overall are terrible (that's true for all entry-level IB), but they will try to avoid blowing up your holiday and vacation plans at the last minute unless it's necessary.

Offers good deal experience as an analyst program.  Most analyst "graduates" go onto good PE/HF/corporate jobs.
employeer_cons:
Hardly any analysts stay on as associates, so there are always cases where an experienced analyst gets paired with a brand new, career-switching MBA associate to work on deals.  This creates an awkward relationship as one is supposed to be managing the other, but has less experience.

The timetable to reaching a reasonable work/life balance as a Director or MD is so long if you start as an analyst that most just get deterred to doing something else.

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time
employeer_pros: High compensation; Excellent cafeteria; Excellent benefits
employeer_cons:
Back-stabbing culture
Employees seem to come from another planet - brilliant automatons
Micromanagment
Cold-hearted

employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse full-time for more than a year

employeer_cons: Long long long long long hours.  Very hierarchial

employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 10 years

review_title: Good starting job, your experience will vary greatly from team to team.

employeer_pros: Relatively easy corportate job, easy float by, decent pay, great benefits.  They have an excellent 401k plan which requires only 3 years of employment to become vested.
employeer_cons: I have seen people fired over minor infractions.  It takes a lot of effort to get ahead and even more effort to get fired.  There tends to be a lot of dead weight throughout the company... which can be expected of many large corporations.

review_title: Stretching and growing experience in a difficult industry
employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 8 years
employeer_pros: Lots of opportunities for growth and exposure to people and teams throughout the globe.

review_title: Great experience, learned a great deal, great platform to leverage inside and outside of the firm.
employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 8 years
employeer_pros: Competitive, fast paced, has great intellectual resources. I enjoyed coming into Credit Suisse during the growth years. Very fast paced and entrepreneurial, many development programs and access to some of the most talented people in the industry. Management is accessible and is actively participating in employees' development. Proper recognition procedures are in place.
employeer_cons: Despite claiming to be entrepreneurial, it has become too large for entrepreneurs to be able to enjoy working there. I fear for the company because the landscape is changing dramatically and I am not sure the firm is doing enough to stay ahead. Idea generation process is stifled by the regulatory regime where the management is afraid to do almost anything in fear of being in violation of some regulations.

Good pay does not make up for costs to health and normal personal relationships in the long run. That being said, this is pretty much the same across all the investment banks.

anti social environment

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: I made some great connections with a lot of the people I worked with.  The culture overall is heavily influenced by the Swiss culture/mentality which is good in some ways - like the fact that they take less risk than a lot of their US based counterparts.
employeer_cons: The organizational structure is very complicated and it often felt that communication between departments was non-existent.  The Swiss culture, while great in many ways, definitely comes through when trying to think progressively about problems and solutions.  They seem to be afraid of their shadow a lot and make every effort to stay "neutral" on everything. This was frustrating because creative ideas and solutions tended to get brushed aside for fear of how it would look publicly.

- Priorities and direction would substantially change from year to year.

review_title: Credit Suisse had some amazing people but was less than perfect organizationally.
employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: The people.  Really talented and entrepreneurial.  It is one of the premier banks in the world and therefore you had access to an incredible network of people and product.
employeer_cons: The firm culture comes a clear second to the allegiance to your desk.  And that means that it is political and that you have to watch your back and that you have to discount the guys at the top who like the idea of a warm culture but don't have the mechanisms or people in place to create that.  However, Brady Dougan, himself, is an amazing guy and have only the best to say about him.

employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse full-time for more than a year

The firm has a strong equity research franchise, which management cares a lot about, given its strategic shift to a more service focused bank. Over all the firm is committed to growing its research business. in today's world, that aspect alone gives you a little more job security.
employeer_cons: It is a European bank, so pay is not as good as the US bulge brackets like GS and JPM.

employeer_cons: CS in RTP, NC is a cost saving location. Most of the jobs are operational which means throughout the years management encourages lateral movement. It's very difficult to move out of operation positions.

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 3 years

employeer_cons: Very active in trying to keep salaries in the area low. Typical investment bank; view s/w developers as resources rather than assets. Also, much of the work was staff augmentation, meaning that architectural design and higher level decisions were made/driven by primary locations (London, New York). Also, due to off site dev centers (Singapore, India), off hours work was common.

review_title: Defensive management, Survival game (NY investment banking review)
employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros:
- Healthcare and pension benefits are very good compared to what I've seen in other Wall Street company
- NY headquarters location, right by Madison square park
- Work/Life balance
employeer_cons:
- Management is poor, driven mainly by self-interest and minimum risk taking. A standard management practice is to follow what "Goldman is doing". The feeling is that the best managers left over time, leaving the bank with a layer of class B or even C executives. One of the consequences is the extreme lack of communication between managers and the associate/VPs, so if you are not joining as a manager you shouldn't expect a lot of involvement and learning from your superiors.
You're experience might vary, but I've heard the same refrein again and again from people in different NY groups.

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for less than a year

employeer_cons: Hectic work schedule, old technologies, noncompetitive salary

employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros:
1. Internal mobility is somewhat good. 
2. Most colleagues are nice compared to other banks I've worked at
3. Salary is somewhat competitive
4. Work/Life balance is not bad
employeer_cons:
1. Way too many project managers that do not add any value. Not enough business analysts nor developers. 
2. It doesn't matter how much you work your butt off, salary increases, bonuses and promotions are very arbitrary. If you are coming in make sure you get your title with the initial offer, otherwise it is very difficult to get promoted. Titles matter in this company. 
3. Keep in mind this is not a technology company, so you will be working with the latest technologies here. 
4. They are moving all development to India, so eventually the NY office will only be PMs and BEs. and if....

employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 10 years
employeer_pros: People are generally nice to work with.
employeer_cons: There is a recent and extreme focus on offshoring at the moment and for the foreseable future. Offshoring does not actually save money, only headcount. It's a shell game designed to play with the numbers and give middle and upper management their fat cat bonuses. What actually happens is that the contractors that are assigned to the job are not experienced or familiar with the project. Their turnover rate is high, their work pace is slow and they are mostly likey working on another firm's project while billing CS.

They do not make any attempt to ensure fair compensation throughout the organization and are focused on cost cutting and creating new process that increases bureaucracy, lowers morale and ensures systems remain out dated. The good talent is walking out of the door and is being replaced by mediocre people.

review_title: Not bad of a Company, depending which Division you work for...
employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: CS is not bad of a Company, depending which Division/Department you work for. The culture differs a lot from division-to-division. If you are working on the Business-side, you might like it, and just fit-in (of course, at the end of the day, what really matters is your Manager who can make or break your life). But the Business in any Bank is seen as a God; so the I feel the culture and etiquette is different. If you are working in the IT, its not that different from other IT divisions of other Banks I've worked for; its typical and mediocre at its best!
employeer_cons:
Pathetic Management (esp Compliance IT); Precarious Management 'strategic' policies, which changes from year-to-year, as the Management itself changes every year - this demoralizes the employees. A lot of cost-cutting activities; off-shoring and outsourcing; IT is seen as a cost.

What really sucks is the lack of growth opportunities (as the bank from past 3 years is only interested in cost-cutting); there is no team building and collaboration; as I say, IT is mediocre at its best!

Let this not be your only review; read other comments, as everyone's experience differs, and you need to average-out your perception about this one bank, whose brand image has eroded, at least in my sight!

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: Product Control was full of great people to work with and the RTP, NC location is nice to work at.  The benefits are some of the best in the industry in part because this is a Swiss company so if you are planning to have a family it is hard to beat.
employeer_cons: Advancement seems to be slow going even after a few years of hard work and communication with management.  I met many people who had been there 5-7 years that where told they were not getting raises or received very little when recently promoted.  Bonuses where also very low compared to years past I was told.  This was due to the economies and poor performance of the bank they Management told us.  This was tough to hear and kills the motivation of newer employees.  Our department implemented overtime pay for hours over 40 which was often however  we where paid half time!  Not time and a half but half time.  You make $22 hr your paid $11 hr for hrs over 40.  I guess this is better then previously being paid strait salary with no chance of extra pay but it seems wrong.

review_title: Great co. to work for when started in the 90s but has steadily gone downhill hill since, there is no work/life balance.
employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros: Good benefits, Credit Suiise is a strong, well established Company.
employeer_cons: Shared Services employees get lousy bonuses and go years without raises while the Front Office receive insanely large bonuses and raises.  To top it off, when Front Office works with Shared Services the Front Office employees often treat Shared Services with total disrespect.  The Shared Services employees are always told there is no money in the budget to hire more employees, employees working in certain groups are expected to do the work of two people.

employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros: It was rewarding. When I started with the firm, I was given the opportunity to build my own team, develop a reporting package used by sr management to monitor the group's risks and performance.  I was then challenged with enhancing the SOX documentation and testing, and then transitioning the work into the line.
employeer_cons: Given the recent downturn in the markets, along with senior management turnover, the environment has changed.  Employees are mandated to support why the firm needs them.  Management performs morning and evening rounds to see what time people come in and what they leave.  Employees are working longer hours.  Functions are being turned into production roles, with no opportunity for growth and expansion for those performing those functions.  Other functions are leaving NYC area entirely, which is contributing to the low morale.

employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse

review_title: There are a lot of politics.
employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros: As with any investment banking job the pay is good so that keeps me around.  The benefits package is also very generous.
employeer_cons: It is very political at CS.  It is hard to get promoted and it is more about who you know than what you do,

employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros: As a contractor, the hourly rate offered was decent.
employeer_cons:
While in training, the trainer stated that he was being asked to cram about 3-4 weeks of training into about a span of 5-6 days. He said he was not happy about having to do this, but his superiors wanted us up to speed and out on the phones as soon as possible.
We(those of us in training), did not feel that we were prepared to step out onto the call center floor and perform our job to the best of our abilities. If the training were more in depth, than maybe my experience would have been different at Credit Suisse. My overall rating, on a scale of 1-5, I would give my experience at Credit Suisse at a 2.5.

review_title: Good work environment..but the bank is not doing well
employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse

Recent layoffs creating confusion
Plan to move some employees to NY office is not clearly communicated. This creates lot of uncertainty among the employees as they could not plan anything long term like buying property etc.
Management dont update employees about the new developments. They all sit in NY office and there is communication gap.
Each managers have their preferred employees in their group and you can survive only if you are in a group.
Benefits and bonus are not great .

employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros:
Depends what division you work in. If you work with financial products and the trading desk, it's a good ole boys club. If you support systems, it's much more inclusive.

The pay was excellent with great bonuses. I really liked how they conducted reviews and gave ample constructive feedback. They promoted a fantastic work life balance with different "fun" events to facilitate networking and relaxing during the long work day.
employeer_cons:
Incompetent managers. Seriously. I knew more than my direct supervisor and he would constently belittle me and keep me late to work on a project while he tried to figure out how to do the job.

The expectation that you stay late even if your work is done but your manager is still there.

review_title: Started with high hopes - Faded with bad memories
employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros: Easy to have internal transfers. Lots of training available - if you have time to take them its worth it.
employeer_cons:
Too much politics. Unfair treatment. 

If you are soft spoken and straight forward, this is not a place for you. Seen often times, managers with abusive manners get promoted. It all boils down to who you know. I have seen excellent talents leaving this place due to lack of recognition.

Promotions are very strange - Last year, Project Managers, who did terrible project mgmt , got promoted as Program Managers, managing Project Managers. 

Terrible work life balance - sometimes 80 hour weeks  - not worth it.

PS - AVOID Program Services in IT - worst management; rude behavior; offensive language.

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse

employeer_cons: Pretty much everything else.   The work load was impossible.  They expect you to work all hours of the day/night.  I was asked to come in on Sunday nights to help with our Australian office (it's Monday to them).  It was very cutthroat.  People on your own team were willing to sabotage you to get themselves ahead.

Managers deride team members even when they are performing well in a misguided attempt to whip them into performing more. Awful life-work balance, most people put in 10+ hour days.

employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros: Credit Suisse is a growing company with great opportunities, in pockets, within the firm.  Company is non-elitist which appeals to certain individuals.
employeer_cons: There is strong leadership from Brady but top senior managers often the lack ability to lead strategically. Company does not develop talent well and lacks training and leadership programs. New Talent lead does not appear to have clear strategy aligned to bank and employee needs.

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros: CS has a great brand name, decent benefits and cordial employees in RTP.  The training that new hires receive provides a great general capital markets foundation, as well as area specific knowledge.  There is a good team spirit amongst peers also.
employeer_cons: Low pay, extensive hours, not a rewarding feeling at the end of the workday.  Advancement within the firm dismal.  You must be with the firm for years before you are eligible for a title upgrade, and when promoted your salary might cover inflation rates if you are lucky (2-3%).  Upper management is solid, however most of the middle managers (and there are a lot) were lacking in leadership skills and were often inept.  Mobility within the firm is encouraged, but often through lateral moves that hinder your chances for moving up.

employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros:
Exposure to different  financial products.
Training are provided for employees to learn financial and other areas.
Majority of the co-workers are nice to work with.
Vacation and days off are generous.
Bonus is ok.
employeer_cons:
Very low salary even for senior developers as compared to competitors or market. They will give you either average or below average for what you are worth, which is stupid.

Chances of career advancements are hard to come by. You have to wait 1 to 3 years before you might get promoted even if you do hell of a job.

Recently seeing too much shakeup in the management and structure and people are leaving as they are not getting promoted despite doing great work.

Salary increment are rare and might take 3 years after you join.

Remote teams can be a pain in the rear to work with especially folks in London and Zurich think they are gods and have freaking huge attitude problems. Team in Singapore take things very little and work on their pace and schedule.

Too much administrative stuff like reviews by zillion people for you, twice a year to save your behind and keep your job.

No work life balance, long hours and no structure at all in project and products management. 

Credit Suisse  departments mostly use band aid solution for their IT products, fix and patch........

IT technologies are decade old as compared to competitors e.g. DB and programming technologies and focus is more on bulky and thick client GUI using C#.

You might be working 3-4 projects or tasks at a time per day.

review_title: Not too bad, not very good
employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros: Credit Suisse provides work life balance, flexible working hours, (above) average benefit. You get training opportunities. It is a relatively stable company.

review_title: Good place for building your resume but not your career
employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros:
- Good benefits
- Flexibility to work from home when needed
- Internal mobility is encouraged
- Various opportunities to get involved in philanthropic, sports and social activities
employeer_cons:
- Promotion process is very opaque. There are no clear rules for what it takes to get promoted, and even when a manager nominates their employee for a promotion, the promotion request may get dropped for unknown reasons.
- Due to the somewhat high turnover rate managers come and go all the time, and often teams are left in a state of instability in between management and organizational changes. A lot of information and knowledge is also lost when people leave, which leads to more frustration.

review_title: Do not accept a position in the OTC Derivatives group.
employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros: CS had a very nice facility and cutting edge hardware. Before the pay cuts the pay was great! I met some of the best and brightest people while employed at CS. Except for my department, most other groups had mostly positive things to say about their work experience.
employeer_cons: Pay cuts, layoffs, outdated software, very little initial training, and any ability to change. I would say the worst part were the managers and the review process. The grading is based on how you are liked and not the work you actually perform (the word perception was used often). I know that may sound bitter but there were moving benchmarks to be measured against. All employees faced the same issues in both good and bad times.  Therefore, it was an unfair situation for employees to be judged differently when they produced the exact same results. Also, the managers did not keep any metric of how the employees were performing on a daily basis throughout the year. For example of the review process and bias: 2 employees both have 10 unresolved problems. Employee A (who started with 100) is told that we are experiencing a high volume of problems so you did your best great job. Employee B (who started with 500) is told you have not resolved these problems therefore you are not within working parameters. This happened the entire time I worked there and the bias of the managers was brought to HR by multiple individuals on my team with little result.

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros:
Tuition reimbursement is easy to get, so if you have a thick skin, this is a great place to use for a free degree, but you should know that you can only get reimbursed for 2 courses per semester & you have to stay for a year afterward (otherwise you'll receive a retroactive bill for a any courses taken within 1 year of your departure).

If you work for a successful team, its a better job because you have more ability to make more money (assuming you have equity in their business), and management will be less inclined to bother you.

Camaraderie with other assistants (ie not management) was good - most of the brokers were nice too.

It was a good stepping stone and as difficult as it was, I'm grateful for my degree.
employeer_cons:
Management, or the overall company, has NO interest in the growth of the assistant.  

This is only a satellite office and the only 2 jobs are Broker & Assistant, so if you want any kind of vertical growth or career path you would have to move to NYC or look elsewhere.

Management can be very rude & condescending to the assistants.  Their responses to conflict are unprofessional, and they read the emails of their employees (brokers included) and then gossip around the office.

You have no personal space.

employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros: Great company to grow and make a difference
employeer_cons: performance measurement are somehow strange

review_title: Consistently underpaid - verbally promied compensation, but not delivered
employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros: Good benefits, company gym, some good employee networks
employeer_cons: Too dragged down by process, Management not always supportive, poor traininig opportunities, poor work/life balance, difficult to get promoted or appropriately compensated.

review_title: Overall excellent place to work, better in the satellite offices, in head office you can get stuck and stalled
employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros: excellent environment, very entrepreneurial atmosphere, lots of smart people
employeer_cons: in head office opportunities for recognition and advancement are limited unless you are associated with the right group and the right clique within that group. far east opportunities are much better, smaller offices and therefore better opportunity to be noticed for your accomplishments,

employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros: Good benefits and highly compotent employees.
employeer_cons: Low salary and back office promotions are political.

review_title: Management competence and communication are a needed component of organizations
employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros: Good benefits and financial compensation
employeer_cons: Morale is very bad.  It's easy to get pigeonholed into ones role with limited possibility for advancement or transfer internally.

review_title: Credit Suisse is a good place to work for
employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros: It is well run and has professional competent people.  The communication is good and the review process is quite wwelll structured.
employeer_cons: Your experience will depend a lot on the department you are in and the people you work for.  But for all the talk about "career advancement", managers are not really vested in team memebers' growth.  Training budgets are tight and there is always a large workload.  There can be a lot of demands and pressure.

employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros:
Compensation is comparable or better than other companies
Bonus structure is higher than most companies in the area
Flexibility in working from home when needed
employeer_cons: Setting up the RTP site to save money from the NY site is a good idea, but poorly executed.  NY is reluctant to give away any power or is unwilling to collaborate.  It is in most cases that it is the NY way or the high way.

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros: CS offers a progressive and competitive environment and competitve compensation.  CS encourages mobility within the firm for employees looking for new roles and challenges.
employeer_cons: CS can be very political and advancement in the firm may sometimes be based more on connections and posturing than merit and performance.

review_title: Great place to work. Employees are treated well.
employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros: Great place to work. Outstanding benefits.
employeer_cons: Not much growth opportunity outside of NY, London and Zurich.

review_title: Good place to work -  Lack of  helpful goal setting
employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros: Collegial, interesting work, has resources available if you want to use them, nice campus
employeer_cons: No energy in the building whatsoever!! People seem to be going through the motions without much extra effort. Could be there for 15+ years and be in the same position. Uncertainty in future role growth, and lack of clarity from management as to where we stand

employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros: Credit Suisse managed to emerge from the finacial crisis well..... not because they anticipated the crisis or because they managed their positions well.  They were simply slow movers that never got in deep into the CDO market.
employeer_cons:
Completely incompetent management, especially in IT.   What once was a semi-competent senior management team in IB IT, has been completely replaced with a bunch of incopetents, starting with the current CIO.

HR is used as a wepon to demoralize the the staff.  has to be the worst HR department I've ever encountered.

review_title: An above-average investment bank to work at
employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros: Credit Suisse Investment Banking is improving year by year, and it has pretty good training programs for its analysts. Overall, I thought that the culture was as good as it could get for an investment bank.
employeer_cons: Still, compared to some of the other BB firms, Credit Suisse lacks brand prestige. This results in Credit Suisse's exit options not being stellar (hard to get into good B-school straight out of any IB analyst program, and getting into a TOP P/E firm from CS not all that easy). For me, if I was going to spend 100+ hrs/week working, I would want a guarantee that I could get amazing exit options out of it.

review_title: Overall okay, but lots of big egos.
employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros: Global firm with a good reputation.  I think there is a true culture of doing what is right for the client and the firm came out relatively unscathed post financial crisis.
employeer_cons: A few downsides that come to mind is that management's attempt to control costs sometimes border on the absurd.   IT is about 10 years behind, which makes it hard to be productive sometimes.  Lots of children of MDs working there...

review_title: Great place to work and further my career
employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros:
- challenging work 
- great colleagues
- good benefits
- fun environment with opportunities such as sports and social and to give back/philanthropy
- nice building
- firm came through financial crisis very well
- plenty of training and cross-training opportunities
employeer_cons:
- large firm, some processes too cumbersome and beaurocratic
-  better working across different departments
- some groups on old technology (but some on very new)

review_title: Horrible place. Egos, work you till the bone then outsource your job
employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros: pay benefits and donation to causes
employeer_cons: expect to be laid off at a moment's notice, lots of bad attitudes, snobby

review_title: Right Hand talking to Left Hand?
employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros:
- Great people at VP level and below
- Hard-working environment
- Huge oppty to be a great firm
employeer_cons:
- HR needs to be completely re-vamped
- Technology is poor relative to Street
- In some markets, bad people promoted based on who you know, not also how you perform (expect both to play a role)

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros: good training ground and exposure
employeer_cons: higher up management turnover and high in attrition

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros:
Good deal flow, wide variety of deal types.
Lots of responsibility, associate often called upon to put together the entire book with little initial direction
Fast paced, like drinking from a firehose.
employeer_cons:
Because the levels above abdicate some of the presentation creation to the associate and only parachute in after a draft is complete, you often end up wasting work when they change their mind.
The review cycle is a joke.  New York groups know how to play the game and trump other regional groups during review cycle.

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros:
Chance to learn some new skills.
The pay was generally competitive.
Most developers very clever.
Probably good job for someone fresh from college, but not seasoned pros.
It wasn't the worst job that I ever had, but close.
employeer_cons:
Top heavy management. Too many bosses, not enough consensus.
Low life/work balance. Need to push back just to take lunch or time off.
Too much emphasis on process not enough on producing working system.
Parking a joke. Crowded, had to take shuttle from overflow lot most days.
Very crowded cubes. Everyone shares a cube with low walls with someone else. Can hear everything on floor. Very hard to concentrate on work. Layout is like a giant call center which isn't good for doing any kind of software work.

employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros: Some businesses and leaders are innovative.
employeer_cons: Too much bureaucracy, some areas have a culture of mediocrity.

employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros: Good place to work, in Mid town
employeer_cons: office space is a limitation

employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros: The promotional opportunities are endless. If your located in the major financial hubs the pay range is very competitive. If you enjoy exposure to various teams throughout the world the cross divisional collaboration opportunities are endless.
employeer_cons: I currently work for the COE center located in the Americas. The compensation is not on par with the market due to lack of competitors. Company is utilizing the market of recent college grads and locals intent to living in the Southeast. If you want a competitive salary you have to move to Charlotte. Promotions hinge on how much you impress your intermediate boss rather than how efficient and productive a worker you are.

employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros: The people and the philanthropic efforts
employeer_cons: Things take a long time to get done

employeer_cons:

employee_history: I worked at Credit Suisse

employeer_cons: No life outside of work.  BRUTAL hours...can be very tough to work in such an intense environment.

employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros:
Good company to work for.
work environment good
employeer_cons:
Opportunities for growth are limited.

review_title: Better than where I was before this job.
employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros:

Credit Suisse came out on top from the banking crisis.

Bottom line, I feel blessed to have a steady job.
employeer_cons: The hours are better than my last job, but that's not saying much at all.  It is still about who you know, not what you know.  My manager is in another country who has never even met me in person.  Wish there was better internal professional growth, as opposed to bouncing around between companies.

People and good benefits are some of the best

Opportunities in London and NY are great.  Globally they trail off quickly...
employeer_cons: Politics, and favoritism are rife.

employeer_cons: they seem to be not as sensitive to employee needs and can do better job of the same especially around promotions.
