review_title: Solid employer, honest pay for an honest day's work
employee_history: I have been working at Credit Suisse
employeer_pros: CS doesn't have stumblebum managers like they have in Citigroup.  Also in my 4+ years at CS, I haven't yet been screwed by a dirt-rate bonus like GS gave me a few years ago.  CS's 401k benefits are also pretty sweet.   Other than that- the pay's fairly competitive- I have no complaints about it.
employeer_cons: It's extremely difficult to make VP in the IT track.  To become VP, you've to have to manage at least half a dozen people in your own team.  Meaning it's entirely too easy to work a decade in CS and still only have an AVP title.  What a morale drainer.

review_title: Great company! Great job - especially for anyone with lots of energy.

employeer_pros: flat leadership.  No egos in management.  Always fair and accessible.

review_title: Great place tor work and have a long term career  with great potential for growth.

employeer_cons: Very large organization which can be hard for some people to who do not want to expand their networks to grow in.

review_title: Good opportunities but low salaries. Move to NY/LDN if possible!

Easier to get Title and Band promotions in certain groups but very difficult in other groups. Cramped workspace (after "Densificiation" project) with no privacy.

employee_history: I worked at Société Générale full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: Smart and hardworking worker bees. Interesting deals. Try to be creative. Structured finance-focused. Good benefits, was an early adopter of 1 day a week WFH, casual dress.  More life balance, at 50-65 hrs/week.
employeer_cons: A lot of overseas armchair quarterbacking in US markets they are not experts in. Many at the top of the house in CIB seem ill-equipped to run businesses - good individual contributors but shouldn't be the stewards. Often felt like they threw ideas at a wall to see what stuck rather than taking time to do white papers. From a competitive standpoint, they copy what BNP, Credit Ag and Natixis do, rather than other better performing IBs. Cannot compete on cost of funds vs many competitors in the US so have to take on more aggressive businesses.

review_title: Sinking ship - good benefits but the rest is pretty bad
employee_history: I worked at Société Générale full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: Benefits are very good. PTO is excellent: 27 days for most in US to start, can go to 32 days.  401k match 100% of up to 8% (with 10k total cap) also excellent. Other benefits industry-standard. Hours expectations more reasonable than many US IB's. A few good, smart people left.
employeer_cons: The Chicago office of SG has been reduced by over HALF in the last five years. The office is bleeding to death, morale is very low. SG Paris HQ inserts managers to try to make the former Newedge offices (Chicago, NYC, NJ) more SG-like, but they end up failing and causing lots of friction for no good reason. Change is good, but not change just to put people in line. More cuts are coming soon too. Pay varies, but many people are underpaid. As a sinking ship, I would caution most people to avoid this place.

review_title: Quietly Moving in the Right Direction
employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros:
- Smart colleagues and senior management with long-term vision, even when that means less popular short-term decisions.
- Environment that values performance, contributions and ideas. That may not have always been the case and maybe not in all departments today. But in  general, SG has moved out a lot of the old school senior people who were just happy to stay under the radar and not interested in real change.
- Truly a very good place to work if you want to be involved in charity activities, diversity and inclusion efforts, and general input and involvement in culture of the bank. There' always something going on, and there are plenty of opportunities to get involved and do things beyond just the typical work experience.
employeer_cons:
- It's still part of a global bank. So decisions made in Paris sometimes aren't favorable for the US. 
- Banking in general is mired in a regulatory swamp. SG's no different and perhaps has even more complicated systems and processes for getting things done. It can be frustrating. Again, better than it was. But still room for improvement.
- Even in NY, it's very much of a French or global bank. If you can't deal with diversity or people speaking French in the elevator, then it's probably not the place for you.

employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: None.  There really aren't any.
employeer_cons: The simple truth is SG has been in bad shape for several years.  They’ve repeatedly used mass layoffs to balance the books and don't have any problem using the livelihoods of their people in order to meet arbitrary projections for an arbitrary date. In so doing they’ve destroyed their culture and employees trust. They also suffer from a very inefficient organizational structure, wasteful spending, declining revenues and gross misallocation of resources.  The company stock is down over 45% in the last 12 months and over 10% in 2019, and we’re not even through the first quarter.  Let’s face it, companies come and go.  It’s a simple part of the overall business cycle.  Businesses are born, they age, and eventually die off.  SG is in the dying off phase.  I don’t think the bank will fail overall, but their presence in the US will be dramatically scaled back in the next year or two as they’ve already announced thousands of job cuts.

review_title: Barely Treading Water and Going Nowhere Fast
employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: None.  There really aren't any.
employeer_cons: Make no mistake SocGen’s Chicago office is headed for near certain wipeout in the not so distant future.  Over the last several years profits have eroded and the business they run in Chicago has fallen apart.  Throughout this tumultuous period, their presence has been repeatedly downsized as they desperately try to save a dying business (think Blockbuster Video). What does this really add up to? Well, in a nutshell, SocGen is a terrible place to work.  If you choose to work here do so at your own peril knowing you’re nothing more than a number on a spreadsheet.  If you do decide to work here, keep an ear out for buzzwords like "reorganizing" (this is their favorite), “restructuring” and “realigning” as they all result in layoffs. For the love of God, whatever you do stay away from this company, as I would not even recommend this place to people I hate.

employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale full-time for more than 10 years
employeer_pros:
Have been in the bank since 2005 and have been in the closet for 10 of those year. A few years ago I decided to come out. I received an overwhelming level of support from management, HR and colleagues. 
There are plenty of opportunities to move. I worked in Paris, now I’m in New York and go offered to move to London.  Being from Argentina and having all these opportunities has been encouraging. 
Have had great managers that encourage taking ownership of tasks, there had been only few exceptions.
Cafeteria in New York have been told by consultants is really good compared to other places they worked at. It is small but indeed it has good options.
employeer_cons:
The end of year review rating has quotas so even if you do great and went above expectations you might get an “in line with expectations.”
There is little clarity on how the promotion process works. 
Jersey City Cafeteria not as good as the one in New York.

review_title: They're going out of business but just don't know it yet
employee_history: I worked at Société Générale full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: None. This is not hyperbole
employeer_cons:
This review will focus on their FCM business in Chicago as this is the area I worked in, however the comments in general are relevant to all areas of the organization mainly because the issues at this company are widespread and encompass all business lines.

The morale in the company is at an all time low. It’s truly like a ticking time bomb. You never know when the next round of layoffs will be, but rest assured there will be more.  I am sure the vast majority of employees are searching for job.  

Management is basically inept and at the ready to layoff employees as soon as the slightest dip in earnings occurs.  In other words they'll layoff people purely to make quarterly numbers.  Several months later the positions for those that were let go will be reposted, but at salaries that were well below what they being paid.  It's sad but true.

Compensation is a minimum of 20% below market, that's if you're lucky, but more like 30%.  This is something they openly admit to, and as you can imagine results in them being unable to recruit any real talent.

There is NO growth in Chicago.  Instead the business has been in steady decline for at least the last five if not ten years. You don't have layoffs for years on end if your business is succeeding!

The pecking order is Paris, New York, and Chicago being a very distant third.  If you work in Chicago you’ll more than likely report up to someone in New York.  The problem here is that most management in New York have had careers that started and reputable firms but have since followed a downward spiral to working for Societe Generale.  Since most are incompetent and only concerned with their own continued employment they make hasty decisions just to make numbers, which results in loss of jobs.  You'll read this in almost every review.  

HR preaches inclusion, diversity, and mobility.  In reality none of these things exist and their responses to the reviews here are nothing more than a failed attempt at damage control.

review_title: Chaotic mess with a surreal backdrop
employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: Few and far between, frankly, I can't think of any.
employeer_cons:
To put it bluntly SG is a disaster! Headcount in Chicago in 2012 was around 550, today it’s around 200.  I’m not a math whiz but that’s roughly 64% reduction in force over 4 years.  Most of the jobs were lost to either India or Montreal as SG views a developer in India as fungible with an American developer with a decade of industry experience.  Needless to say their offshoring and nearshoring tactics have not had the best results for the company.  Back in November of 2016 they laid off the entire development staff for a critical back office component in their architecture.  Volume increased the software broke and there was no one to fix it.  If you want to read an article regarding this google “SocGen Computer Glitch Said to Ripple Through Bond Derivatives”.  SG may have saved $1M in headcount but the resulting outage cost them in excess of $50M.  The continued layoffs over the years resulted in over three empty floors in their previous offices at 550 W. Jackson, which prompted the firm to look for new space.  They ended up moving to 440 S. LaSalle, a building that is 60% empty, where they could pay pennies on the dollar compared to where they were before.  Don’t be fooled by the thin veneer of their new shiny offices as below surface lurks nothing but a company on the verge of imploding.  Glassdoor did a great article on the types of companies to avoid titled “7 Types of Companies You Should Never Work For” and SG fits almost every one of these.  I bring this up now as one type they mention in the article “The Curb Appealer” just popped into my head when speaking about their new offices.  

When it comes to talent there isn’t any left.  The brain drain has already run its course, leaving the firm with absolutely zero talent in their Chicago office.  What they’re left with are C players who think they’re A players (umm…, A players work for Goldman) and cult-like managers and their idiot followers.  When it comes to incompetent management, you’d be hard pressed to find a bigger group of lackeys.  I’ve never worked anywhere where the vast majority of people including management were uneducated.  It’s fair to say 80-85% of their employees in Chicago lack a college degree and most if not all are just hanging on hoping they aren’t let go in the next round of layoffs.  

The complete and total disaster SG’s Chicago office has become is not entirely their fault though.  The trading industry as a whole is in the worst shape it’s ever been in.  It is not just FCMs that are feeling the pressure but also exchanges like CME and ICE that have been struggling as well. In the vendor space 99% of the technology being sold is at least a quarter of a century old.  SG’s core vendor on the front office trading side is Fidessa, which was written in the early 90s. In the proprietary trading space, most firms are on life support especially the high frequency players most of whom will exit the business in the coming years.  If you’d like to learn more about the current state of the industry just google “Dwindling numbers in the financial industry” one of the first results is an article that paints a clear picture as to just how grim things really are.

I totally expect this review to receive a tone-deaf response from Paris touting what a great place SG is to work for but the harsh reality is my review paints a clear picture of their Chicago office. My advice to anyone looking to take a job with SG is to think twice if not three times before accepting an offer.  You’ll be doing yourself a huge disservice by working here.

employeer_pros:

4) Severance payout and related benefits are fairly generous towards laid-off people.
employeer_cons:
1) They are very willing to lay off people with very little warning at the slightest dip in profits, even though management is always touting how profitable the company is doing.
2) If they lay off people, the company will not allow its current employees to provide you with job references.
3) They are always looking to cut the fat and save money, but it's inconsistent . . .sometimes they'll spend money on useless, wasteful technology (such as, providing Dell tablets operating on obsolete Windows 8 OS to all employees) or on corporate training programs that emphasize too much on soft skills (e.g. reducing workplace conflicts) and not enough on hard-core computer programming and tech skills that are more useful in our jobs.
4) If you're not French and white and always praising the company, you're probably not going to get promoted.

review_title: OK firm, pass if you want to excel.
employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale full-time for less than a year
employeer_pros: Very  nice and good natured people. Work life balance is very good. Creating technology to enable work from home and remote options. Lots of firm sponsored events and exemplary HR communications.
employeer_cons: Way too many committees inhibit direct dialog and stymies upward mobility. Very clubby atmosphere. Same handful of people make most decisions. Management team is aging in-place and resistant to disruptive change. Paris treats US like a colony.

review_title: When you work at SG, what happens to you is called Getting SG'ed
employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: It's about as close to a 40 hour a week job that you can get in banking.
employeer_cons: Societe Generale only cares about itself. American's are treated poorly compared to the French. SG will take advantage of you in any way that they can.. internally it's called "Getting SG'ed".

employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: If you keep your distance you might be able to avoid breathing in any of the acrid fumes.
employeer_cons:
- Most unprofessional atmosphere I have ever been a part of in my life
- Staff take pride in surviving near constant layoffs
- Rife with politics
- Inept uneducated management with little to no experience leading
- Enormous army of contractors
- Absolutely no career development
- Archaic technology
- Projects that have beginnings but no end

This place is in a complete nose dive.  They can't seem to stop offshoring and near shoring jobs, which is a major issue that's totally backfiring on them.  It wouldn't surprise me at all if their FCM business implodes within the next year or two.
Only if you are very very very desperate would I tell anyone to ever work here.

Provide an environment where employees look forward to coming to work, are respectful of each other and promote people based on their performance not their nationality or skin color.

review_title: Avoid at any cost. Micromanaging everything at a ridiculous scale
employee_history: I worked at Société Générale full-time for less than a year
employeer_pros:
OK benefits.
They have a decent cafeteria for employees to buy lunch and breakfast.
employeer_cons:
Worked here for 3 month, and I quit after it. 

They didn't give me a laptop to work on. They gave me a very old hardware. 4:3 monitor  that has some color issues and a computer that's very slow. When I asked for a newer hardware I was ignored. My phone has a better spec than the computer I was given.

They will micromanage everything at a ridiculous scale. Do you need a software on your computer? Call the help desk. The help desk might not install the software you need for work.

If you need to do development on a Linux server, they will give you hard time getting you access or right permissions. If you need to install git for example, you will need to contact the "UNIX TEAM" to install it for you. Each request for installing a package can take few days. You can waste like 2 month on not doing anything just to wait for someone else to run a yum install that will take them less than 3 seconds to run.

You built a web application and need to deploy it? Call the "APACHE TEAM".  You may need to wait like a month to get things done for you. Developers are not allowed to configured services by themselves. 

No clear goals. I was hired to reduce cost, and they don't know what needs to be done in order to reduce cost.


Back stabbing between the engineers. Engineers are back stabbing each others to the management in unprofessional way.

employeer_pros:

While SG is a big company, they are in many ways small in the US compared to their peers, which on the positive side can give you a sense of working at a smaller company, which is nice.
employeer_cons:
For some of its strengths, it also has weaknesses. 
It is not a super driven place like some of its peers, which can be frustrating if you want to really make progress very quickly. However, this isn't to say that there isn't progress. It is just at a different speed to what one might expect.

This largely comes down to the large bureaucracy that the bank is based on back in France.

review_title: Small company feel in a big corporation.
employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale full-time for less than a year
employeer_pros: SG is an international corporation, but the regional offices feel like a small company. Most meetings in NY are in person so you get to have face-to-face interactions. The office location in Midtown Manhattan is great and there is an entrance to Grand Central in the bottom of the building. They really value a work-life balance and everyone takes all their many vacation days and nobody looks down on them for doing it. People enjoy working here and work hard while they are here. There are a lot of smart people everywhere. They also compensate most people pretty well and the benefits are unparalleled with 8% matching on your 401K.
employeer_cons: Many approvals have to go through Paris, so it is sometimes difficult to get things done. Management also just decided to not create an IHC board for the FED, so essentially there is a glass ceiling on how big the company can grow.  There is also a glass ceiling on how successful you can be if you are not French. If you are french, you are valued more than if you are not and French people will get promoted over someone from the US in most cases.

employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale
employeer_pros: No pros at this place. Worst bank on the street to work for. Surprised this place actually gives you a paycheck to work here.
employeer_cons: Compensation is pathetic. Front office Juniors are treated like trash with no raises and bonuses range between $0-$5k and not performance dependent. If you're not french and your group is...good luck getting ahead. Constant layoffs, restructurings and the whole works. Junior Analyst work in the front office is more like back office work, thus skill set being built is horrible and nontransferable. Promotions are non-existent and opportunity to be a revenue generator is non existent. Morale is extremely low and the cynicism is unbelievable with negative attitudes all around. Compensation and bonuses have been declining rapidly every single year and will be near $0 for a long time. Turnover is very high.

review_title: The Bank Management in Paris Simply Does Not Get It
employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: Stable Company, will still be in existence in 5 years
employeer_cons: Refusal to add the necessary head count even with increasing regulation, refusal to increase salaries, cutting back on bonuses/promotions while increase CEO compensation 18%

employee_history: I worked at Société Générale full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: Quite a few smart people, wider job responsibilities compared to American banks, less likely to lay off people than American banks.
employeer_cons: A very nepotist environment that promotes French nationals from a few select French schools. Links to Paris HQ are a must for serious advancement. Lower salaries than in American banks. Much slower career progression compared to American banks. Very very bureaucratic.

employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale full-time for more than 8 years
employeer_pros: Good vacation time, if you do not perform well there probably will not be any consequences.
employeer_cons: Extremely limited opportunities for non French speakers, zero interest by the managers in developing employees. Morale is very low everywhere, I do not know one person within the company who would not jump at a decent opportunity somewhere else. Management philosophy is to create assembly lines where the employees are the equivalent of machines. The culture throughout the company is one of secrecy and hoarding information without any intent on sharing. It is actually acceptable to not respond to inquiries, and follow ups to inquiries. Constant changes in the organization have eliminated any sense of team spirit, as soon as one reorg is finished everyone starts talking about what the next one will be. It has been 12 months since the last one, I think thats a record.

employeer_pros: Overall talent level quite low, so it is easier to advance

There is a significant reorganization once per year, so the managers have to spend significant amounts of time on that rather than managing their teams. There is a large cultural gap between French and American employees in the NY office. Surprisingly, while this may seem obvious, the management and HR do nothing to address or manage the problem of culture and communication. I would agree with many other reviewers, if you do not speak French I would not recommend working here.

review_title: A good learning experience that fosters growth
employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale

review_title: You are in a glass box
employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale
employeer_pros:
Lots of vacation time, especially if you have been with the company for more than 5 years
Ability to travel to France or other SG locations, if you are lucky
Until recently, the job positions are fairly stable and secure.
Most groups and peers are usually very nice to work with.
employeer_cons:
If you are not French, you can only get so far. Definitely a glass ceiling! Also, be prepared to get paid less than everyone else in the industry.
If you want to advance  or get promoted in your career, don't work here. Expect to wait many, many (MANY) years in between titles.
Lots of politics. Innovation may come from other regions, such as the Americas, but they are usually either ignored or stolen by the Paris office.
If you work in an office other than the Paris headquarters, you are confined to just doing your tasks, and take an extreme amount of direction from the mother office

review_title: SocGen embodies everything that is loathsome about French institutionalism--but there some positive aspects.
employee_history: I worked at Société Générale
employeer_pros: SocGen can be bold in areas in which it chooses to focus.  SocGen takes advantage of the French higher educational system that gave it an edge in areas like derivatives.
employeer_cons: SocGen is not a meritocracy.  It operates with a three-tier hierarchy--with zero mobility between them.  At the top are the French from the right schools or families (their upward career path is guaranteed, no matter how incompetent).  The next level are talented French who have some opportunties for advancement (these include workers like Jerome Kervial, who blew up the bank partly out of spite towards its deeply anti-meritocratic structure).  Below that are non-French employees, who during flush times can fall under the misimpression that they are valued and respected.

review_title: OK in good times, scary in bad times.
employee_history: I worked at Société Générale
employeer_pros:
Flexible working environment
Good work/life balance
Reasonable hours
Exposure to truly international bank (in NY)
Many good professionals as managers (not all)
Can make a lot of money if strongly desired by management in a market-related position
employeer_cons:
Once you get to senior VP / Director In New York, you have essentially three types of citizens:
- The French nationals, who got sent overseas from HQ and are therefore well positioned in France
- The "mercenaries", talented professionals who were aggressively recruited from other institutions, and are well paid
- The rest.  Career advancement and opportunities will be limited in this category, so take the job, learn, but do not expect much in terms of advancement.

employeer_pros: Good work/life balance - good benefits. Conveniently located in midtown Manhattan or Jersey City
employeer_cons: Middle to upper management is usually filled with Frenchies who complete an Inspector position for several years - despite no knowledge of how business runs. They are placed into these roles with no managerial training.

employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale
employeer_pros: Good working relationship with peers
employeer_cons: Management ia always being filled with French based employee

employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale
employeer_pros: Hours are ridiculously good. Work/life balance is not a problem.
employeer_cons: Pay is about 30% off market; bonuses are similar. The sense is that the Company rewards are given according to nationality rather than a meritocracy. Don't always feel like you work with the smartest in the field.

employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale
employeer_pros: easy going environment, very casual, very diverse
employeer_cons:
where do i start?!
-red tape/ steep management hierarchy pretty much ensures nothing get done
- aloof management
- byzantine systems
- a type of place where you show up for a training class and the computers are missing or software is not installed.
- forget recognition, it does not exist here
-finally, do not expect to be compensated fairly at year end. This company spends top dollar to lure away business people from the best banks like Goldman/JPM/MS; the rest get peanuts.

review_title: The worst professional experience I have encountered in over 20 years.
employee_history: I worked at Société Générale
employeer_pros:
Hours are not bad - normal day is just 9 hours.
Vacation time is truly vacation -backup to cover your work while you're out.
employeer_cons: Some groups are truly hostile work environments.  Both H.R and Management are aware of these departments and yet allow the abuse to continue.  It is truly a lawsuit waiting to happen. Also, do not believe a word H.R tells you about compensation.  Unless if you get it in writing, it will definitely be imbelished just to get you in the door but the package offered will not be the package you receive.

employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale
employeer_pros: - it offers a good working environment
employeer_cons: - it has an avg pay scale

employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale
employeer_pros: smart people, hard workers, decent systems
employeer_cons:
no promotions for Americans,
a lot of temp workers

review_title: Very precious opportunity to start your career in financial industry.
employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale
employeer_pros: The french company is operated in a different culture as many other US local investment banks. People here are not that aggresive. Though work is busy, but we handle it in a really elegant way.
employeer_cons: SG is not willing to sponsor H1B visa for international students. It hires long term full time interns to do assistant jobs on the front desk. It is not necessarily a drawback, as it gives students like me the first experience on the trading desk, but it will not lead to a full time job.

review_title: It's hard to get fired here
employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale
employeer_pros: Nice people, free French classes, good hours
employeer_cons: Bureaucracy, limited mobility, poor communication, lazy people

review_title: Nice place to work, don't expect much mobility unless your French.
employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale
employeer_pros:
Good company, not bad overall environment. Very highly ranked International Company (looks good on Resume).

Related departments (i.e. Ops - FO and Legal) work fairly close together in order to resolve issues. Gives good opportunity for exposure.
employeer_cons:
Recently too much Paris oversight -> Daily + Weekly + Monthly + Semi Annual reports.

-Limited chances for mobility or growth if you are not French.

employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale
employeer_pros:
Good worklife balance.
All technologies exist in different groups.
Hopefully they will realise that they need to starting recognising talent even if they are not french and promote them.
employeer_cons:
Technology wise best practices not followed.
Talent unrecognised hence not retained.
Good Work not appreciated.
Just come and do stuff thats asked

employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale
employeer_pros:
Good work/life balance with reasonable hours.
Good benefits
Vacation policy (five weeks after five years of service)
Work environment and Coworkers are usually friendly
employeer_cons:
Two tier system - promotions and management spots are given first to expatriates, regardless of experience and skills.
The Paris bureaucracy spews a steady stream of forms, status reports, processes, and KPIs.  Powerpoint skills are highly valued.
Lip service given to career development

review_title: Good company for someone really wants a life/work balance.  Not for ambitious and entrepreneur
employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale
employeer_pros: Generally good working environment as most employees are friendly.  Good company benefits including defined benefit pension (though very low), good vacation time, work/life balance.
employeer_cons: It really depends on what your job function is  and which team you are in.  Middle  and back offices normally have good hours though relatively low pay.  Front office has relatively less stress compared to top tier american investment bankers but it also shows in the pay check + bonuses.  Huge turnover rates as it has hard time to retain the best performers.

review_title: Good place to work- if you are French
employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale
employeer_pros:
Lots of flexibility and independence given to employees (mostly due to the managers being totally hands off ...see Cons).
Talented Analysts and Developers (lots of smart employees at that level)
employeer_cons:
It is not unusual for management positions to be given to persons who have no real experience or banking knowledge...solely on the basis of their being French.  You wind up with the analysts doing all of the work, managers getting the credit for doing nothing except gathering status. Maybe.

Employees given lip service about professional development. Performance reviews more for paperwork than actual study.

employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale
employeer_pros: At times of recession, as we just had, SG did not lay off nearly as many people as other financial institutions. As such, it's a great place for a stable income and job security
employeer_cons: The price you pay for job stability is reflected in your paycheck. Also job stability implies that people should be let go are not, adding to you having to pull "deadweight". Couple that with a huge bureaucracy and you have one hard place to work

review_title: Perfect place to work for if you are not looking to build a career
employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale
employeer_pros:
Good life / work balance.
Good place to learn and open to employees to do a lot of trainings.
Good vacation and sick days policy
employeer_cons:
Salary is fair but little bit lower than the market
Bonuses are really smalls
Promotions looks "stochastics"
Few opportunities for career advancement

employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale
employeer_pros: Manager nice, and people are great.  Everyone gets along. Benefits are good, not the worst hour, get out around 5:30 or 6, depending on the day.
employeer_cons: Absolutely no career path.  Higher Management blocks you if you want to move internally or develop your career.  Only way to advance is to leave the company and come back in a higher position.  They have just capped the salary threshold, which is bad news, because they do not judge on quality of work, but on politics.

review_title: Understand what you are getting into...definitely kick the tires!
employee_history: I worked at Société Générale
employeer_pros: Good benefits. In general, people are nice and many have been there for a long time. . Very multicultural work force. Location in NY is very convenient. Smaller bank in US which allows employees to be bigger fish in a small pond.
employeer_cons: It is a 2 tiered bank- the french employees are treated differently than the rest and cannot be fired, which is not very good for morale.  Although the workforce is diverse, the upper levels of the company are full of white French males who all happened to go to the same schools. Hard work is not recognized and the amount of red tape is unreal. Pay is far below that of other banks.

employee_history: I worked at Société Générale
employeer_pros: Opportunity to learn is still there - if you have time.
employeer_cons: Middle Management lacking in professionalism and competence. Sometimes severely. Ridiculous share of decisions are made on purely political basis. That against the background of complete lack of focus or planning at these middle layers. Clear preference for quick and dirty solutions to meet arbitrary deadlines and "manage up" as opposed to professional ways of doing things. Employee morale is not anywhere near the top of the priority list. Not sure if it is on the list at all. Clear division between French and Non-French employees is not helping either - "French Connection" actually does have special meaning. Even if you admire and respect French culture.

review_title: Great name, low pay, weird people.

employeer_pros: Strong name in Europe, not so Strong in the U.S.

employeer_pros: As a technologist, was impressed with their lookout, Cloud 2020 vision for example, Citrix integration, Fantastic internal processes in place, statistically driven, good projects to work on and strong camaraderie in team.
employeer_cons:
No room for progression in the company so loose talent who go elsewhere and thus do not get ahead as a whole.

The internal processes are, bizarrely, very hard, Despite you knowing them they pretend they do not know you and are very harsh with how they engage and ask ludicrously difficult questions that hardly have any bearing on the role, They then use this to discount you. Three internal interviews confirm this over-riding style, and speaking with other colleagues they say the same thing.

review_title: Most miser company i have ever seen.
employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: Work wise company is good, as you will always have work. Can learn latest technology.
employeer_cons:
There are lot of cons
1. In term of hike you will get worst in the market. 
2. Employee benefits is zero. Even in the corona pandemic they are not giving reimbursement for wifi/internet usage, despite the fact that you cannot work for 1 sec without internet. 
3. To setup WFH they gave 16k that too after 5 month with 1 year of restrictions.. Height of miserliness. 
4. There is no other benefits like team outing or team lunch.. 
5. Work culture is very bad, no one is helpful.
6. And worst part is, there is no Leave encashment.. So they are saving money ey there also..

employee_history: I worked at Société Générale full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros:
Good Organization in case you are looking to build your career as it will help you to gain a good base in  front office and related functions..
Some managers encourage and do give autonomy.

There is a good work-life balance and judicious amount of annual leave that can be capitalised.
employeer_cons:
Extremely toxic culture that permeates within all levels..  there are no clear promotion and growth guidelines and year on year out of turn promotions fall through the crevices.. Top management buoyed by a dysfunctional and useless HR is out of touch with the ground reality 

The culture is extremely French who seem to take a more than fair share of the pie.. and reflects in the diversity of the top management all across.. 

The mobility program is a sham and again promotes a lot of bias..  Same could be said of the diversity initiatives which only promotes how truly non-diverse this organisation truly is..

You will strive if you are French. The French colleagues or directs constantly need to be reminded that they can only accept positive feedback. Get upset if they receive otherwise or get no recognition for mediocre deliverables. 

Main language is French as they can not comprehend English in verbal or written form, though this is meant to be an international bank. 

It is a very toxic environment, HR and senior management do nothing to help stop it but instead turn a blind eye and let it manifests. 

If you are French, work for this bank as you’ll be fast tracked as competence is not an important factor. If you’re not French nor speak the language, don’t work here.

review_title: A place to learn things but don't stay
employee_history: I worked at Société Générale full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: For a junior, it's a proper place to learn things, understand how things work out and accumulate some experiences
employeer_cons:
1. No clear expectation from the senior, no target set, not cared what progress you made, you are used as a tool and taught things when the senior find necessary for you to take the dirty work
2. No headcount no return, trainees are actually 1-year fixed-term contracts, just recruited to handle dirty work while saving their cost, after 1 year, they get a new guy and you are out, and also poor internal mobility
3. Continuous restructuring of the organization, teams and functions split and combined, combined and split endlessly, even managers are not sure the exact structure of the whole department
4. Shabby infrastructure and tools, laptops and desktops are slow and physically worn, too many internal databases with similar info and purpose, never a single day no database get bugs, many tools are not maintained and have to debug every day, keep developing unreliable VBA tools and changing daily processes
5. Teammates gather either as French or Hongkonger, almost no room to fit into if you don't speak both French and Cantonese, and almost no team building or any other team activities

review_title: Toxic work environment and rude French clients
employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: Good work-life balance. Good salary and benefits.
employeer_cons:
1) Agile for namesake; very few of the agile ceremonies are actually followed. No regard for sprints; user stories are added, removed, spilled-over in active sprints at free will. Instead of scrum masters, they have 'agile masters' who hardly have any knowledge about scrum practices, leave alone having proper CSM certification.
2) Business analysts are used mostly as testers. I am a business analyst and I spend 90% of my time testing. If you want to gain more functional knowledge and move towards product management, DO NOT COME HERE!!!!
3) Some French counterparts can be very arrogant and treat Indians as slaves. I had the misfortune of working with a particularly nasty client whose 'professional behavior' ranged from throwing temper tantrums in scrum meetings to disconnecting calls on your face and ignoring Skype pings on purpose. However, some French clients are good and well mannered.
4) Lots of office politics. People spend more time in mind games than doing actual work.
5) More than necessary personnel at mid-management level who effectively contribute very little but will eat up billing and funds. Too many cooks spoil the broth!
6) Onsite opportunities are few. Your buttering skills are more important here than your actual work skills.
7) You should come here if you are in a stable, comfortable position in life and want to prioritise your personal life.

employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: They give you a lot of training (if you fight for it a little). They have a good benefits package in general (private healthcare etc). The new building in Canary Wharf is pretty nice.
employeer_cons: No job security. The work is simply boring. They are trying to move as much of the development functions as possible to Bangalore, meaning the team you work with will be in a different timezone. The hierarchy seems very important to some people. Often have to comply with directives from Paris Headquarters - sent by people who do not have anything to do with the project you're working on, and therefore had no reason to eg make up a code freeze on your application. The organisation is far too big to get anything done effectively eg set up new accounts for apps, or find the right person to speak to if something is wrong.

employeer_cons:
-Management believes that things will be just completed in seconds like they want all the mails to be answered in 15 minutes with full details. 
- There will be blame game all the time between onshore to offshore, downstream operations team to upstream middle office, front officers to back officers. 
- All Seniour manages here are under qualified and less talented they are serving because of their long tenure and bad politics. 
-Hard working people who has their own prospective or nice Ideas will never be head and they will be forced to do what they want

employee_history: I worked at Société Générale full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: Nothing I could think of. Their health insurance / cab facilities were good.
employeer_cons:
My reviews are based on my experience with the team that I used to work.
I was working in the Cash Support Department. It is the worst project i have ever seen. Below are the things that was alarming:

1. Societe Generale is a bank, so it should ideally be having compliance issue. But in that project, not everyone had their own access to the machines. They used to share the credential and work. Even after reporting this to management, they did not take any action.

2. They still used very old ways of doing things. Like for deployment there was no proper pipeline. People manually used to do that.. Way behind the current trends.

3. Worst thing was the culture. People never used to share the knowledge with any of the new team mates. 

4. They were entirely dependent on the Paris team for any new projects. The Management of Bangalore failed to bring any good quality work from them. So, all good quality works were done by them and all crappy work were delegated to Bangalore team.

5. Management was just mere puppet.

6. In that Cash support project, Business Analysts would just roam here and there and just used to gossip.

review_title: Va falloir un peu plus que du cafe gratuit des fruits frais...
employee_history: I worked at Société Générale full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros:
Bonnes équipes sur le terrain, beaucoup d’energie positive et de volonté de faire les choses bien.
Bons avantages sociaux, horaires flexibles avec possibilité de travailler de la maison.
Technologies intéressantes et avancées comparées aux mêmes institutions du secteur.
Bonne école, beaucoup de défis. La Société Générale est un bon centre de formation ou l'on apprend  a gérer tous types de situations.
Cafe gratuit, console de jeux, fruit frais une fois par semaine, evenements en tout genre...
employeer_cons:
Le haut management (Directeurs et +) en majorité importés de Paris. La vision est donc court-termiste et change environ tous les 3 ans, durée moyenne d'une mission d'expatriation. Pas de stratégie long terme à ce niveau, chacun travaillant à faire évoluer sa carrière dans le bon sens.
New York et Paris tenant les cordons de la bourse, la structure hiérarchique a Montréal est donc purement administrative, sans réel pouvoir de décision.
Utilisation de stagiaires à outrance pour implémenter des initiatives sans réelle valeur business ni financement. Mais peu importe ! Tant qu'on peut y placer des buzz words #AI #NLP #MachineLearning #BlockChain, c'est bon pour la carrière.
Beaucoup de politique. Double voir triple discourt ce qui entraine beaucoup de frustrations car c'est indirectement insulter l'intelligence des employés.
Les plus anciens employés quittent les un après les autres faute de reconnaissance ou de perspective d'évolution.
RH inexistants, littéralement.

employee_history: I worked at Société Générale full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
Work-Life Balance 
Decent salary for the amount of work done
employeer_cons:
I honestly don't know where to start.
Half the developers work on old technology not relevant in today's market.
You generally don't tend to learn anything at your time here. 
Politics. You need to be tactful and smart to even survive in this environment. I am correcting my previous statement, you do learn somethings. Things like how to play smart, how to showcase the talent and how to survive in the wild with predators. 
French don't understand what you say, you don't understand what they say. Whatever little English you might know before coming to this company will be forgotten. Even the official mails won't be properly phrased. 

The biggest con of all: inequality. So I come from a good college, so I was directly hired as a senior software engineer. But the same work and designation are also given to many developers with 10+ years of experience. This is one reason why teammates try to screw themselves. Designation matters. No one will listen to a good idea if it comes from a developer. People will implement the faulty design the lead proposes. Remember about working smart. People think that if they oppose such a design they will be eaten up by politics and get into trouble. So people leave their spine back at home and come to work.

review_title: Great colleagues, uber incompetent upper management
employee_history: I worked at Société Générale full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros:
* Great colleagues to work with and learn from. 

* Interesting challenges if you are in the right team and have a good manager like I had that let's you experiment.

* Can do business trips to Paris, NYC, etc.
employeer_cons:
1. Management promotes a culture of mediocrity instead of promoting a culture of innovation. Management prefers "yes men/women" who do what they are told instead of people who can challenge decisions to make the product and processes better.


2. There is almost no way to be promoted. 95% promotions are filled from expats from France. The company absolutely has no vision for their employees not working in the head office. Often, these people do not understand North American work culture and try to force their management style that does not work in this context.


3. All good employees are leaving because they can't handle the bad decisions from the management anymore.


4. You get promoted in the middle of the year to team lead? Congratulations. You will have more responsibilities and there is a high chance that you won't get a raise until the next year.


5. HR department is completely invisible, we aren't even sure if we have one.

employee_history: I worked at Société Générale full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
-Good work life balance.

-upto Rs 1600 is paid by the company if you opt for shuttle service / Vehicle parking fee is paid by the company
-Apart from CTC provided when you buy SG shares you get some discount + company provides some extra shares.
employeer_cons:
- Even though you are bad at work be good to manager and everything is taken care.
- People who deserve it never gets credit, but usually given to there pets in the company.
- Filled with Legacy technologies, They try to upgrade it but have no clue of the basic software development principles.
- Paris team on the other hand does good work, but they don't prefer to share it with India teams.

- Since Managers are dumb, they pressurise everyone in the team to give more ideas and take away the credit.

- They never value any of the development work done by us neither do they take input from us for any improvements.
- The entire teams' work is done by less than half the people of the team. Rest of them get away with it by being friends with the Tech lead.

employee_history: I worked at Société Générale full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: Used to be good company. Very few good talent. If get chance 15 days travel to Paris
employeer_cons:
More managers, less implementation engineer
Ex: in 10 people team ,4 are above or project managers.
Micro Management. If someone hires from PRIV(private banking) testing department, don't join.
There are 2 managers they will keep watching if you attend more than 5 mins in washroom they will call you.
Less Learning compared to  market standard.
Time Management of 9 hours.
I have seen 1 team resigned all together in one to two Monty of span.

employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros:
Team is good
everyone shares same concern
great varieties of Audit (both Business and IT)
Second layer management - very knowledgeable
employeer_cons:
Top management -  Audit Head very arrogant,  believes monarchy.  no respect for staff. Entire room is locked in one room and have no freedom to speak or to even breath
Middle management - toothless tiger, they cant even take decision to grant leave. always scared to Audit head's reaction.
Micromanagement at the peak - whiteboard is maintained to check who is WFH, Who is travelling, when are you coming to office, what time you are leaving
Simple things they make it complicated eg: policy on Work from home
They force you to deliver without support 
Attrition at the peak, some even left without offer in hand due to toxic work culture.

review_title: Not a Good Company to Work with
employee_history: I worked at Société Générale full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: If you and your immediate manager is in Sync with each other, you will not face any problems. If not, you will start feeling the heat everyday you come to work.
employeer_cons:
> Managers Driven Company and most of the Managers doesn't have Management skills but they behave as if they are the owners of the company.
> No value for your hard work.
> If you are not good at buttering / bucketing (unskilled) manager,  you will find no growth in this company.
> You will never experience work life balance in this company. You should work like a machine.
> Manager(s) will be very soft to their chamchas but for others they just wait for an opportunity to bang you left n right.
> No Flexible work hours. You should work in shifts (weekly shifts change) + Oncall + Weekend.
> Forget your family and play with your health if you are not good at buttering / bucketing your manager.
> No Quality work, most of your time will be invested in doing routine work.
> Awards n recognition's, promotions, good yearly hike, good bonus will be given only to those employees who are good in bucketing their managers, if you are not good at it, don't dream of any such things in this company.

review_title: You are the owner of your career.
employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
1. You will always have a say in what you want to become and what you want to learn.

2. You don't have to beg for leaves. They are approved when required. Very good work life balance.

3. Fair performance reviews. You get what you deserve.
employeer_cons:
While you are free to learn what you want, the growth is slow because of the relaxed environment and you get into the comfort zone. Getting out of it is a bit difficult.

No sweets for any festival :P . Very less perks.

employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: You can work from home?
employeer_cons:
Have worked in London for 7yrs

AVOID this company at all costs, joining will be the biggest regret of your life.

Company does not care about employee development.

Internal mobility results in active punishment and being held back in your career.

Repeated lies and promises of "next year" year after year. Only next year something else will go wrong.

Compensation is a joke and way below market peers. They will use every trick in the book to keep your pay low until you leave only to be replaced by a more expensive hire than then requires someone else to be shafted to make up the saving.

HR function, instead of being a source of help, is utterly incompetent, keeps dropping the ball, unresponsive and just does not care.

Culture has one set of rules for French people and a different one for everybody else.

Widespread low morale, trying to make any positive change is an uphill battle.

Don't make the mistake I did and stay far away.

It was a good organisation.But turned into a another typical  Indian  service based company by Indian management .

->Lot of benefits are cut 
->The number of levels in designations are reduced to avoid people getting promoted and hence save money
->They proudly say ,we do not follow bell curve .But it is followed in secret  ,People are forcefully rated 4/5 just to fit into bell curve .Out of 10 every 2 people are rated 4/5 . When HR is asked about it ,They say bell curve is not there ,But comparison is there .There is no transparency in what they do . 

->Cost cutting by putting low quality milk/coffee
->No team outing 
->variable pay only at end of year  
->No onsite 
->Number of leaves and holidays cut last year.

People on top management try to save their seat at the cost of working class people

review_title: Good first job, bad long term programming environment
employee_history: I worked at Société Générale full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
- Great physical location

- Good first programming job: Some managers are great and open to suggestions, thus allowing some employees a lot of freedom when it comes to architecting/designing applications. If part of a team, this can be a good learning experience

- A lot of organized events (e.g. AWS workshop)
employeer_cons:
- Open office

- Constant phone ringing

- A lot of time wasted waiting on permissions to be given and resources to be supplied

- Absurdly small laptop

- No admin on laptops, only "approved" software can be installed- Past a certain point, the only way to get a higher salary is by becoming a manager and filling your schedule with meetings, thus leaving you with no time to code.

- Low salary

- Some employees aren't given tasks they're qualified for. One of my co-workers left because as a data scientist, he was asked to do a lot of front-end development.

employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros:
This review is for Bangalore office. 
Pros:
Work life balance - depends on the team.
Pay structure- 50% of your pay is basic as such employer contributes good share towards your pf.
European onsite counterparts are really cool to work with !
employeer_cons:
Management is totally clueless where they are heading to.
Innumerable outdated tools/applications.
If you are good at appeasing ur higher ups u;ll climb up the ladder.
Fake innovation / automation projects, they are just adding up more nonsense tools in the name of innovation /automation.
Career growth is very slow and too many levels/sub-levels in the hierarchy this makes it even more challenging to grow up.
Learning curve is really bad as Paris keeps all the creamy works and offshores only unwanted things to India. Dont' ever think of getting into this org if you want good learning curve.
Branching out of this company is really difficult as your skills sets would be outdated by working in legacy environment and  on non-core stuff.
Beware of fake jd's- they sell the jd's very well at the time of hiring,  when you pitch into to the work u'll see a whole world of difference between what was stated in jd and the actual work.
No open door policy.
Management in Bangalore is just focused on pleasing their onsite partners.
Mediocre faclities to employees, hardware resources  provided is of very bad quality, office interiors is outdated,   there is no Doctor on site, cafeteria is just average, transport is pathetic.
Annoying stand ups and wite board meetings.
Hope my review helps you to take informed decision before getting into this company.

employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale full-time for more than 8 years
employeer_pros:
Compensation is above market.
Opportunities given to develop technical and soft skills 
Opportunity to travel abroad is likely if you are a BA 
Other benefits are as good as most companies would provide like free gym, free subscriptions to learning apps ,two team lunch per year etc
employeer_cons:
Projects mainly driven from France
French counterparts are happy if the Basic of Prod support and developments is done. They expect no innovation or anything extra from Bangalore counterparts so it limits in showcasing our talents and skills.

employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: You are more likely to leave at a decent time than other professional services
employeer_cons:
Everything else. The culture is shocking. You are not allowed to have ideas outside of what they already think.
Working from home is talked about but if you dare to do so then expect a grilling about it. It is very much out of sight out of mind and if you aren't in the office then you are seen not to be working.
The support in the office for any kind of training is  almost negligent with new joiners not big given the basics. Compliance emails come around on a regular basis but in practise people don't have a clue and would rather pass it onto someone else than deal with issues themselves.

review_title: Policies great, but only oldies are recognized
employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
1- Good hike
2- Lots of opportunities to showcase your talent.
3- Good joining package for lateral hires
4- Great work life balance for women
employeer_cons:
1- Only oldies are recognized & they run the show. 
2- Managers are morons, who only know how to nod their head in front of senior management.
3- Flexi desk policy has come up, where you need to login at reception & the system will allot you seat anywhere. Though not yet implemented for all teams, soon all will be covered. 
4- Bad cafeteria vendors.
5- If you wfh, use own laptop & internet, no reimbursement of internet. Very few people have been assigned laptops at the company level.
6- Age old systems are being used & not being decommissioned. BAs are supposed to know the systems well, both functionally and technically.

review_title: Good name, Bad management (4 years at SG)
employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros:
Some managers  really care about the personal development of their employees, experiences may totally differ depending on business line and teams.

Good spirit, friendly coworkers with weekly after work drinks and long lunch breaks. 

Some managers can sometime step in and go out of their way to support talented people in 
 other teams than their own. 

Multicultural environment and good humour.
employeer_cons:
No meritocracy.

Parisian head office does not involve UK office in decision making.

Managers can fail their subordinates and do not make good escalation points.

Little training. 

Top (French) managers with poor English skills and UK market knowledge become liabilities in client meetings. 

Strong reliance on trainees and junior V.I.E to perform permanent employees' work. I have not witnessed any retention of junior staff in permanent roles. Youngest permanent member in my team is 40.

Not agile. 

Knowledgeable people leave.

Poor work/life balance.

employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale full-time for more than a year

employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
It's a company that is more people oriented than other big companies. It is not hard to get to participate in trainings/conferences etc that can help you grow your technical skills. Rewarding the employees is not subjective, it's based on the objectives achieved, performance and overall professional behavior. 
In short, people are not always seen as just resources. The environment is friendly and the managers are trying their best to offer employees a good working environment.
employeer_cons: It's not always possible to use latest technologies and practices.

employee_history: I worked at Société Générale full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
Nice people - Overall friendly and approachable staff

Possibility to work from home on ad hoc request
employeer_cons:
SGSS - Societe Generale Securities Services: division of c.90-100 staff within Societe Generale London Branch.

High turnover:
- 6 over 7 Exco members "left" or changed role within a year
- c.20-30% of staff are trainees, Graduates (French VIE) and contractors

Bad people management:
- expectations rarely met
- no particular efforts to retain talents
- no particular efforts to help staff to develop
- no HR follow up

Others:
- Paris sattelite / Highly political environment where dual reporting lines (hierarchical locally, and functional with Paris) shows its limits
- Lack of legitimacy / Experience and ability of some team managers are questionable and more the result of internal networking

review_title: Cronyism, nepotism, inequality & ineffectual management based on favouritism not skill
employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros:
If you have a family member working here, you are most likely to be offered the role, promoted, or given a larger bonus.

If you are a Lady planning to have a family one could say your outlook is good, and you are likely to be promoted upon your return to the office.
employeer_cons:
You are unlikely to be considered for a higher management role unless you speak fluent French, although the business language is English.

Annual compensation review is not based on a true analysis of your achievements, ratings are purely on perception of your manager. Performance endorsed by key stakeholders are not truely considered. Challenging your manager's ratings creates negative ramifications for you for not respecting your managements decision.

The offshoring process ensures that those with most experience, the older staff, the more costly salaries are the first to go. Offshore training is weak by staff who know their role is ending and have no motivation to train their offshore replacements well. This leave us who are left to deal with poorly trained offshore teams who are unable to fix issues we encounter speedily, or they do not understand why they are doing certain parts of the process so when an issue arises they have not the ability to work around it.

Everything is about budget, and the budgets are not planned effectively enough at the start considering the years objectives for development and improvement.

Coordination between departments and teams is inefficient. Communication between different lines of the business is siloed and fraught with disagreement.

Problems with processes are so embedded that staff cannot easily make solutions work. 

Nothing is delivered on time.

- Continuously cutting cost and budget by pushing staffs into list of not good performance without actual / solid reason and measurable criterias. Indirectly forcing people out without any compensation by using this tools with HR together. In substance, only cost cutting but making staff stressed on his/her performance and resigned by themselves.
- Significantly offshore operation and reporting processes to India Bangalore without proper goverance so the onshore staffs would be hard to work on.
- No prospect for non French or non Indian staffs.
- Extremely political in managements and exco members and you need to shoe polishing with them and serves those old colleagues who just play politics and leverage French senior management power to push other departments to serve their own credit to ladder up without recognising people vaule and contribution.
- No transparent in annual bonus review process and you don't expect at least a complete month of bonus.

It seems the India organization requires intellectual slave who just follow them blindly.

review_title: A Service Company for SG France
employee_history: I worked at Société Générale full-time for less than a year
employeer_pros:
Few teams are matured and follow agile the way it should be. A very hierarchal company, not sure if it should be quoted as pros. With agile teams are getting lean however here a stream of non-doers occupy some stale positions which is non existent in todays world. 

A lot of push from SG France to give more autonomy to SG India, however "non-leaders" at leadership position is not willing to take it. They do not know how to take this opportunity, exhibits  more talk than action.  

Started hiring "experts" having good credentials form tier 1 company.
employeer_cons:
Very much Paris drivern organization, some french co-workers are very rude. People coming from American / Europian culture may find it unacceptable.

Ironically SG is considered as a place which provides a balance work-live, that is a myth and a 9 hour which usually may overrun to 10-11 hours is closely monitored by managers.

Some really very old people were promoted not because of their competency but because of their longevity, they have become incompetent over the period of time can not really bring beats with new thoughts and ideas.

Incompetency is ubiquitous, few people survive only because of sycophancy towards their manager and Paris, they know where is the right button to be pressed for their survival.

"expert" hiring does not seems to be working as "experts" hiring seems to be as lenient as normal hiring, they are paid 1.5x to 2.x as compared to normal employee at the same level, brings a lot of demotivation to existing employee.
 
Non-functional HR, for every concern they have template answer. No resolution provided.

review_title: A place you can learn a lot from
employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
If you stand out by coming up with good ideas and their efficient implementation, you will first get recognition, and eventually also credit for your consistent contributions. Management values employees' initiatives and supports the staff who are committed to innovating the business. 

Employees tend to stay within the company for more than several years, and many of them get the opportunity to try out a different role in the company due to occasional restructuring of departments and teams.

Corporate culture is constantly developing, and from year to year it may almost seem as if you're working in a different company, thanks to significant emphasis on innovation in all sectors of the bank.

All employees receive a private health insurance for them and their children, and subsidized private health insurance for their spouses. Also, employees receive benefits in using banking products. Last but not least, employees receive annual bonus, based on evaluation of their work.
employeer_cons:
Bonus is awarded each year to best performing employees (not to everyone), which makes the working environment very competitive.

Societe Generale Serbia has a tradition of being somewhat conservative company, but in order differentiate itself from the market, it strives to developing an innovative, fresh and more flexible approach to doing business. These two opposite tendencies can sometimes be a challenge for your projects.

Being a bank, the company is heavily regulated by both the law and internal compliance procedures. So a liberal mindset needs to be paired with good wits in order to find grounds for implementing unconventional proposals.

review_title: Lot of flab at higher level  - Not good for techies
employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
Work life balance. Other things may be people dependent.
Paris management may intend to change things for good.
employeer_cons:
The single most irritating thing is the presence of lots and lots of managers at unit head level in India, doing absolutely nothing good !! This is almost unbelievable. One has to see them in front of the French to really believe what weight on earth they are. Yes I mean sycophancy. French are not bothered either because at any time they are lot more cheaper and somehow 'help' running the company in India.

If someone want to see live example of the (in)famous Peter's principle, Societe Generale Global Solutions Centre, Bangalore is the place to see. God only knows what the managers here are good for. They don't provide any functional or technical leadership, simply because they don't tackle challenges in their day to day work. They have long before stopped building any kind of competency. The only skill left is survival, and it is not that much difficult in a outsourcing based business model or so called 'cost centre'. Do nothing and look busy ! this is guiding principle. Organize futile sessions but don't do anything meaningful. Sessions are organized frequently, sometime by external 'experts', with some childish powerpoint and lot of gibberish.

Senior managers pretend as if they are getting the work done by the real work horses, which anyway will be done even without them. The pseudo hyper activism of senior folks is just due to this, lack of real work. So they end of up doing all kind of meaningless stuff, whatever they do their heart is not there, only objective of these people is self promotion.

The mangers do lot of pretense and useless stuff wasting their and others' time. Ninety percent of meetings are waste and still they sit in those meetings as if they are discussing the most important matters !
In their desperation to look smart than others the managers do more meaningless things. They are non technical and as far as management is concerned, there is not much to manage as such, they have lots of cheap labor to employ. So a deceptive seriousness and attentiveness in futile meetings keep them busy !!!
Yes it is so hollow in Societe Generale, Bangalore.

The technology is generally old if not very old. Most of the work is around the so called production support.
The company don't provide much to a techie, the managers rule here. There is very less fresh work and people are not aware of latest things in world of technology. They repeat jargon day and night that is another matter.

review_title: A former employee who beliefs in principles & his experience of working in Societe Generale.
employee_history: I worked at Société Générale full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
Disclosure:
I worked for the company in bangalore and i resigned from the company as the company management ( not only project manager,I'm talking about the very top management here )was indifferent to employees concerns on escalations related to violation of company's policies and values by our immediate management and putting the business interests ahead of doing business in a right way. Still i found some positives

1) As per the policy, your manager cannot close the appraisal unless and until you agree and close it in system.

2) The company' has creche for toddlers ( for employees kids) and a gym.

3) The company, being a investment bank, you can expect a decent hike every year.

4) The company based on your entitlement pays a less-interest loan of some amount( I got 1 lakh rupess as loan).

5) Not sure, but I've heard people saying that work-life balance was good in the company.

6 )Importantly the company pays you on time.
employeer_cons:
1) The top management will always side with your manager if you've differences with your manager on any count( sexual harassment, appraisal was closed due to pressure from manager, long working hours , staying back in night, etc) as they tend to put business interests first.

2) Location : The company is located in ITPL and most of the employees used to spend everyday 2 or more hours everyday on travel only.

3) There will be a 10% variable pay on your salary, which they will pay only at the end of the financial year.

4) Once you join a department, ex: Compliance, it will be literally very hard to switch between departments( even though as per policy you can switch after a year or so) as they won't allow you citing various reasons especially if you're a performer or they've committed your time to the client. Importantly you don't know which department you're going to join till you join the company :). They won't tell you in the interview.

5) Critically, the company don't have anything like a Resource management system (like RMG in TCS) which will be of great use to know which projects are there in the company , what are the opportunities and what is the openings available currently.

6) The Business analysts used to slog it out and were under tremendous pressure.

So the critical thing is ask the HR during interview itself on which department they're going to place you and get as many details you can get about the project. Have a word with your project manager first before joining the company.

 I wish you all the best. 

Nine Seven Four Two Four Six Four Four Six Seven.

review_title: Not a good firm to start career and limited career options for techies
employee_history: I worked at Société Générale full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros: Offering good package and a very decent onboarding while joining and then hopeless
employeer_cons:
Extreme politics, technical guys not at all a good place to nurture your career, top management useless even below industry standards , HR operations just for name sake. Jobwise employees just need to follow the orders from counter parts, every thing predefined and pre calculated , benefits only for those who are in close relation with management no matter how bad they are at work and even management tells empoyees to play politics in team to succeed
Usual approach is just use resource for immediate unavoidable requirements and after their need is fullfilled just throw them away,no job assurance, had came across multiple people 
explaining the same scenario,for one or two years you will be exploited very badly with Clerical dump work which french hesitate to do, ideally it will be highly stressful- no meaning for life in work-life concept, then a planned drama to throw you out, if you are good at technical always better not to join because after some time you cannot move any where. Thers is no onshore  concept and travel will be for the max of two weeks that also at the time of joining trick only to attract and join fresh talent to organization
No work from option  so far, and best part- managers will get two promotions in a year and it takes around 3 to 4 years on an average for a normal level 1 employees to get a promotion

Have seen many highly technical guys leaving the organization explaining more or less same info provided

review_title: You'll enjoy if you are not open to change!
employee_history: I worked at Société Générale full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros: Handsome pay, world-class facilities, great brand name with 150 years of legacy, no laptops means no work after office hours, frequent parties
employeer_cons:
No place for folks who want to change the system
Very bureaucratic, slow moving
Hierarchy conscious
French dominated 
Poor hiring decisions - they hire people with less experience and competence and assign them as your manager
Anybody can become anybody - Admin person can become Communications head, finance guy can become quality head, operations professional can become risk head, coo can become internal audit head - they don't value  domain expertise and skills. Tenured people are much valued for their loyalty. If you are more than 5 years+ in this company with zero knowledge of industry best practices you are valued if you just suck up to the right management executives
Very dangerous for pretty women - They are French after all 
Super slow decision making and it is not transparent
Not willing to share credit to the deserving, mid-way in your project, it will be assigned to some old-timer who will finish and get the credit
Meaningless awards are given to undeserving folks - it's a laughing stock
