employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale full-time
employeer_pros:
Almost 100% teams operate on Scrum Agile methodology
Sprints are of short duration and work allocated is at par with the sprint duration. As a result, employees do not feel rushed.
Workplace ambiance is cordial and relaxed
The French are good to work with. Unlike American companies, you feel a distinct difference in their style of working. i guess it is true for most European companies. More laid-back approach. Less cut-throat.
employeer_cons:
The kind of work might seem repetitive and monotonous after 2 years. But then, every job in the world feels monotonous after some years. It is important to move across projects to avoid stagnation. 
SocGen is at a nascent stage as a captive and so, majority of decision-making happens from Paris, its headquarters. The French presence is very palpable and pervasive in almost all the budgetary planning of the company.

review_title: Worst, Junk, Pathetic and what not!!! Commit suicide 10 times but don't even think to Join here
employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale
employeer_pros: None.. you take galilio's original telescope or any super microscope, you'll never find any pros since there are none. Glassdoor forces to choose one star atleast otherwise I would have chosen thousand negative stars. It does not deserve any stars
employeer_cons:
1. Literally illiterate people sit on your head as managers and start screwing you even when they know that they can not even spell "Technical" on their own.

2. Too much of insecurity among the so called "Senior Technical Leads" as they themselves do not know much and when you ask something from them, they will either try to humiliate you or will avoid telling because they know that their bluff will be caught. Simply unaware of any concepts either technically or domain related. They never believe in sharing any sort of information.

3. Managers turn a blind eye to something wrong their so called "Leads" are doing because they are hand in gloves with Leads.

4. Once you try to escalate something, management tries to harass you.

5. You are only expected to nod your head in yes to every crap that comes out of management's mouth.

6. Managers are mere monitors here who would really stoop down to the level of monitoring your loo timings as well. They expect you to be there when they want and leave when they want.

7. For timings, even if you would argue that my work is complete and i have never delayed any delivery, they would say that still you sit in your place and I have been told by a senior manager that He would like to see me on desk only, even if i am browsing e-commerce websites, its okay

8. All Junk (whom they call their "Technical and Senior technical Leads") simply keep on browsing e-commerce websites, some 1000 things you don't know about kind of articles and are good for nothing.

9. You will be evaluated by your managers and so called Leads for every single tiny detail but your opinion or feedback is never asked and even if you are bold enough to escalate to higher management, Managers and Leads will make sure to make your life a living hell. Never Ever your feedback will be asked.

10. All the people here try an judge others while it would be nicer for them to have a look at themselves first.

11. All you will be asked is to work on some ancient legacy projects. Worse than worst service based company. A nightmare for techies.

12. Appraisal discussions are an eyewash.

13. No Innovation. Infact, on the contrary Innovation is discouraged.

14. pathetic, pathetic, pathetic!!!

employee_history: I worked at Société Générale full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: one of the quality banks on the market in Bulgaria; well structured entity (Bulgaria); very clear organization and good internal regulation of processes; overall good environment depending on the department you're positioned in; internal promotions are possible if you managed to exhibit good work and have achieved good results over the years, very nice canteen available for the employees at Varna HQ; good location close to the center of Varna, as well as to the local airport and bus station; relatively secured job in comparison to other competitors on the market; knowing French can open up doors for you - literally.
employeer_cons: some French expats have literally done nothing but spending bank's money, while adding no value to the respective entity/functions; obviously those have been under the umbrella of their friends at Paris HQ;  Bulgarian deputy managers have done much more work for way less salaries and benefits; salaries for Bulgarian entity are below market levels; especially for employees at Varna HQ; recent years proved that you need to have strong connections to become a manager, external candidates for managing roles can be tolerated more in comparison to internal ones, despite of the latter's proven abilities and qualities; HR function is not efficient in its recruiting and development of staff.

employee_history: I worked at Société Générale full-time for less than a year
employeer_pros:
Personal experiences:

- Bright people in technology team although IT infrastructure is incompetent.
- Nice office locations in the City of London.
- Generally a respected and influential bank. 
- Like any other big bank, opportunities for lots of team bonding activities.
employeer_cons:
Personal experiences:

* The environment is not only unsupportive and non-collaborative, but does really get unprofessional, with rude and insulting behaviour from manager and 'senior' colleagues , if they just decide they don't like you. Some people would even say toxic environment. Very moody and child-like behaviour from some seniour members, they will exclude you in team discussions and/or out-of-office networking.

* Good management will often involve communicating clearly firm's objectives , understanding employees longer-term aspirations and try to marry them. Not at this bank. In my 1 year's stint at SGCIB, my manager didn’t have a meaningful conversation about career progression, although it was part of formal appraisal process.

* I won't even get into the regional politics and Paristhrowing it's weight around -- as this is well known in the industry and to a degree expected. What;s interesting is they use word 'global' or 'multinational' quite a lot.

* Very loud French environment. I've heard some obscene use of language by seniors

* Cronyism at it's height, there is no transparency. Agreement on what, when, how things are to be done is not seek within team -- it is told. The actual words of one of managers just on the 2nd week of my starting a new role : 'this is not a democracy' surprised me a little.

I should probably put this in Pros :  more than 35% team left the firm within a year of joining. That includes myself.

review_title: Great place to work, especially for women
employee_history: I worked at Société Générale full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros:
- Great opportunity to learn the various functional areas of Investment Banking.
- Good brand name - one of the oldest and most trusted French bank.
- Good working culture. Good work life balance.
- Company invests heavily in employee trainings and latest processes and technologies - Agile, Continuous Integration, BDD, TDD, Clean Code, Angular JS, HTML5, mobile technologies etc. This is not common in most financial institutions and hence is a great learning opportunity.
- Business travels to Paris. It was nice working with french counterparts and understanding their culture.
- Tab for all employees with wi-fi in office.
- Good benefits. Vacations and time-off are encouraged.
- Good place for women emloyees. Over 25% women in work-force and many in senior leadership roles.
- Beautiful office space and good facilities.
employeer_cons:
- Salary not at par with other investment banks
- Increments and bonuses have come down in recent years
- Too much focus on testing in Business Analyst role
- No work from home policy. Very limited outside access is provided for critical resources based on business need. But in general work from home is not allowed or encouraged.

P.S. Well, not a con but I have seen 'No onsite opportunities' mentioned in several other reviews. I think people should understand that this is a captive and hence work is supposed to be handled from offshore. Those looking for onsite oppotunities should go for service companies. Here, mainly short term business travel opportunities are available and these are mainly for Business Analysts and Technical Leads.

review_title: Bank with better work life balance as compared to its peers
employee_history: I worked at Société Générale full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros: The work life balance and career growth was pretty decent in the initial years but in last 2 years things have changed culture wise and growth wise. On an average it is 9-6 job.  Salary is above average but not a good paymaster like other banks. My project was technically sound and had very good learning experience. They adopt all the latest practices of Agile and are also following Continuous Integration and delivery process like TDD, BDD etc.
employeer_cons:
The team in paris really matters in your experience in the team...if they are feeling insecure as most of them are contractors than be ready for dirty politics. 
Culture is changing in the company and extended hours in office are appreciated. 
Career growth really depends on your account manager and is very average. 
Work recognition is not good and most of my team members were highly demotivated.
No flexible working hours
No work from home option

review_title: Worst company to work. No personal growth....
employee_history: I worked at Société Générale full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
1) Monthly Salary structure. Have only PF and income tax deductions.
2) ESOP plan is good.
employeer_cons:
1) Lot of politics, regionalism and favoritism. Good support to you if you are mallu or tamilian.
2) Agree to Paris and higher management or else you are not valued at all. No value to end user feedback even if they are praising you.
3) Management will keep on saying we expect lot of innovation but once you share something they will not let it go further. 
4) Unrealistic expectations by the management during appraisal and 1:1 discussions. Most of the managers are non-technical in nature and don't understand what the team is trying to explain. Management will argue  just to showcase they know more then you.
5) Old timers in the system think they are the owners of the company. If you mess up with them you will be harassed like anything. Forget your appraisal and bonus if you are not in good books of your manager.
6) Use old legacy software and not ready to change them also easily.
7) HR is not  at all empowered. They are puppet in the hand of higher management and will speak the same language. No value to employees concerns if shared with HR directly.
8) No laptops for people. If you have work you have to stay till late in night.
9) Managers are like watchman and will monitor your login and logout time(though no automatic leave deductions because of less hrs) . You are expected to stay even if you have finished your work and they will point out if you have left early some day saying that we allowed you to leave early as if they have done a special favor.

review_title: A good choice for your work/life balance with competitive benefits.
employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros:
The whole package is very complete.
A lot of days off, so that you can have a life outisde work.
Good atmosphere and friendly collegues (but it certainly depends on where you end up working).
employeer_cons:
There is an old-fashioned management style that is shared by all managers. The boss is not the client. The boss is the boss and everybody has to do what they want. It's very difficult to grow an idea or innovation when you're at the bottom of the pyramid.
Also, it's a very big compagny, so don't expect things to go fast...

employee_role: Part of the Corporate Functions Group
employee_history: I worked at Société Générale
employeer_pros: Salary structure and benefits, lot of employee events and fun club activities
employeer_cons: You will be hired to do a job, but not given the empowerment, tools or resources to do it. Management will override our decisions without logic. There is no emphasis on quality of work, company has no values that guide it and office politics governs everything. There are several dissatisfied employees and there is a lot of negativity towards management.

review_title: Nice place to work if you know your way around the bureaucracy
employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale full-time for more than 8 years
employeer_pros:
Expects loyalty from employees but does give it back, for such a big corporation the workers are well treated as a whole, still holds (in Paris at least) to the old traditions, having the employees hold a relativly important share of the company avoids the common French "Class War" issues and unions are much less political and more useful than in most other french corporations.

BigCorp(TM) bureaucracy if everywhere, but with a little bit of relationship building with stakeholders and flexibility, the French management is much less rules oriented than US Inspired businesses and much more person oriented, the big bureaucracy is there, but it is more a side cost of doing business than a hard obstacle to growth and communication.
employeer_cons:
The salary is below average, it used to be compensated with awesome bonuses in great business years, but there have been none of them for nearly a decade, on the other hand, competitors who do pay better have had much worse layoffs...

While Socgen used to be the place to be for talents in france, it has lost a lot of glamour with the economic crisis and the "Kerviel Show", for managers, recruiting good people has become hard and there is a growing knowledge and motivation gap between the generation who were recruited when the selection was very hard and the new recruits.

review_title: Satisfied to work with this company ...
employee_history: I worked at Société Générale full-time for more than a year
employeer_pros:
1. Employee Policies
2. Pay Structure
3. Perks and benefits
4. Working environment
5. Employee stock option plan (1 : 1 - to a certain limit).
6. Townhall, yearly events
7. Goodies (birthday, festivals etc.)
8. Corporate social responsibility
employeer_cons:
1. Internal trainings - Same trainings repeated every month, barring a few cosmetic changes
2. Technical growth path - Not a great company to grow technically.
3. Opaque opportunities - Available opportunities across the organization (in other teams) are highly opaque, not easy to learn other available opportunities. Worst even positions available through job consultancies are not available for viewing internally. 
4. Work from home

!!! ALERT !!! - If you have negotiated for a notice period buyout, please be AWARE that the notice period buyout amount in SGGSC is paid as part of the next immediate salary cycle and is thus taxable (if applicable). The bottom line is that if your notice period is bought out, you would end up paying tax on an amount from which you haven't earned or derived anything.

review_title: A large French company that needs seriously to improve its policies and reputation
employee_role: Former Employee - Employee In Control Area
employee_history: I worked at Société Générale full-time for more than 3 years
employeer_pros:
Major company in the financial sector
Show recently large benefits
Located in the centre of Luxembourg, close to bus stops.
Many employees (~1000 in 2014) and cultures
Many activities thus many potential projects
Restaurant (managed by Sodexo)
employeer_cons:
Bad reputation due to several major financial scandals
Large benefits do not benefit to employees
Not many control policies in place hence possible biais and frauds
Culture a la francaise that considers its citizens "better" than foreigners, including natives who are considered as "primitive" by some French employees, including by managers !!!
Low salaries compared to other banks of same size.
Old space rooms that need refreshing
Recruiting process slow (2 months),  and in 4 steps (3 interviews including with HR with a RAT psycho test from Hudson, then if you are selected a negociation with the Head of HR for your salary. HR requests your 3 last payslips; I have never saw that !)
Not many or no parking at all

employeer_cons: Less room for innovation. As a developer we need assistance from Arc's regrading crucial decisions. But Arc's do the same work what SE's do. (Now you can understand why its a good company to settle down)

review_title: Senior project manager on Global Capital Markets
employee_history: I worked at Société Générale full-time for more than 5 years
employeer_pros:
Good experience, fast moving company back in the years 2008-2011.
Team work spirit was the motto back in those years. Moreover it is a good learning school, people are proactive willing to go beyond expectations in general. It is an international group so it can give you exposure opportunities with other locations.
employeer_cons:
Work ambiance whanged in 2012 due to financial crisis consequence and a lot of internal reorganization that has generated organization fatigue.
Access to internal training has declined in the years 2011/2012.
Annual employee assessment system implemented in the years 2011 was not that objective mainly a mean to determine the annual benefit and not really assess the quality of the work or if the employee has met the objectives.

Annual compensation reviews are just an eyewash
Average pay for freshers
You cannot expect to be mentored or even get the free time to learn anything on your own
No feedback collected/expected/considered from employee about his opinion of the work which is dumped on him/her

Notice period is 2 months without any salary , and final settlement + relieving letter comes 30-45 days after the day you leave the company

Horrible middle management
Too much of favouritism
Very bad work pushed to Bangalore
The middle management guys AVPs and VPs are frogs in the well literally. They dont know anything that happens in the industry nor they want to know. They are not open to any ideas.. just this is how SG works is their policy. If you butter them well then your life will be smooth else you are doomed. The work pushed to bangalore is of very poor quality so dont expect anything challenging or innovative or even standard.
The company doesnt care for you until u stay for 3 years. The longer ur stay the better the treatment.
There is a hell lot of favouritism and HR doesnt do anything objective to prevent this.

employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale
employeer_pros:
1. Good for people who want to work in banking industry for initial 1-2 yrs and move on.
2. Good people who dont want technical growth and not ambitious
3. Good pay as compared to other companies in bangalore
4. Working for top bank in france so It adds value to your profile If you are looking to continue the career in banking industry
employeer_cons:
1. People in bangalore dont know what they are doing . They just follow what SG Paris says.
2. Exposure to core investment banking domain knowledge is less in bangalore office.
3. Language is big time problem during counter part interaction in paris.
4. Counter part dont reply in proper way. IF you ping now reply will come after 5/6 hours.
5. Most of the core analysis of requirement is done in paris and small peripheral work is given to bangalore team.
6. Managers are useless here. Money oriented only
7. Promotion is based on no of years in comp rather than expertise.
8. NO Role clearity : One team can have many tech leads working as SSE.
9. Be clear on role clearity during interview.
10.C++ people be aware . I would say dont join only.
11.Dont expect onsite as it is cost cutting center.
12.Investment banking business is very less as compared to other I Banks
13.NO proper docs on projects.
14.Very few developement projects
15.HR is horrible and get voilent in exit interview.
16.To many components in salary like Loan subsidy,Medical Insurance. Always ask for fixed CTC and get comp. part cleared before accepting offer.
17.Pathetic VISA process. Work permit takes more than 2 months to process.
18. Sr,PM,AVP,VP are use less like frog in well. They dont care about attrition.
19. Probablity of you becoming critical resource is very less even after long stay ( > 3 yrs) as not much critical work is done here.
20. Some of the BA's are arrogant.

review_title: Is SG a good place to work?
employee_history: I worked at Société Générale
employeer_pros:
Job Security, not a hire and fire culture
Training ground, will help you move to bigger and better things
employeer_cons: Political, bureaucratic, poor management, very french, appalling in terms of diversity, poor prospects for promotion if you don't fit the typical 'french HEC / Grandes Ecoles' background, compensation is poor vs rest of the street, and it is very slow! Slow to implement strategies, slow to recognise talent and slow grow in the right areas.

review_title: A good place to work in Paris
employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale
employeer_pros: Smart people, brings innovation in capital markets, entrepreneurship spirit
employeer_cons: difficult to get promoted if you are not part of the serail of top Engineering schools

review_title: It is full of politics. Very bad place for MBAs. Good for only B.Coms.
employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale
employeer_pros: It provides good package compared to its peers for similar jobs. HR policies are very good. Learning opportunities are good
employeer_cons:
It is not a place for MBAs or highly qualified. In Bangalore, It is not doing anything in Investment Banking. It is back-end process (BPO) here. Simple B.Com is enough for the work getting done here. Even management here do not care for MBAs/ICWAs/CAs. They get the same designation and salary as B.COMs.

The work culture is very pathetic here. It is fill of petty politics here. It is not fun. Even seating arrangements shows managements recognition or lack of it for the employees. There is no cubicle here. Anybody can look at anybody's computers. There is no privacy at all.

They treat employees like cattle. They don't provide access to Internet for BPO employees. It is too hell to work there.

Promotion depends on the years of experience and seniority, no matter how good you are at work.

review_title: Some details about SocGen (in Asia, the place I worked as an Intern in front office)
employee_history: I worked at Société Générale
employeer_pros: Société Générale hires the best French graduates, even though it is generally agreed they pay less than their competitors. The academic level of the employees is quite high (In front office, mostly graduates from Polytechnique et Centrale). This company deliver very complex financial products, has an efficient IT infrastructure and in spite (or because ) of "l'affaire Kerviel" the security systems are quite developed.
employeer_cons: If you are hired as an intern or VIE at SocGen, it might be an interesting experience, but your chances of receiving a permanent offer at the end of your temporary contract are quite low. When I did my internship, in early 2009, maybe 20 percent of the interns were hired, but that was during the crisis. Also, it seems VIE are hired quite often in Front office jobs, a bit less when they work in IT or middle office.

employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale
employeer_pros: normally people can leave office at around 7 or 8 pm
employeer_cons: Too low salary comparing to other similar companies

review_title: Societe Generale - Money oriented NOT People oriented
employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale
employeer_pros:
Good place to get training
Timings are 9-6 job
Very similar  to a Government job
Risk at job is "Zero"
employeer_cons:
Here are things one should know about SGCIB -

1. HR is pathetic. More then HR dept i would say its a good sourcing dept. Screen the resume and get employees.
2. Completely disengaged from employees. Would say there is no HR dept as such. 
3. Sr.PM are useless. Many people are just promoted ........ and they are like a frog in well.
4.  you will find many AVP's and VP's .....which is the most  Funniest part of this company
5. AVP and VP are very Arrogant.
6. HR Policies change as per VP's Advice
7. NOT sure Where and what our MR.CEO is doing.................... WAKE UP!!!!! CEO
8. One advice to new joiner - Think 10times before you join SGCIB
9. Not a people oriented company. Its a clear msg from VP's - they dont care for attrition.

employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale
employeer_pros: leader on equity derivatives products
employeer_cons: working process is too slow

review_title: Be sure of what you are getting in to !!!
employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale
employeer_pros:
Working @ one the premier European investment banks comes with its set of advantages
1) Good compensation and Benefits.
2) Opportunity to gain on the domain knowledge thereby enhancing the value on the resume for people willing to work in the financial industry.
3) Good opportunity to maintain a healthy work-life balance.
4) Opportunity to work with senior folks in France(This is a big take away as in India we often don't get to work with many senior folks)
employeer_cons:
Well for all the advantages listed, SG India comes with its own bag(big one) of disadvantages.
1) Be sure about the kind of work you are getting in to. Majority of the work available in India are long term maintenance projects and there are very few development projects.
2)  Very limited exposure to latest technological trends as banking industry in general tends to go with the tested frameworks and technologies rather than newbies in the market.
3) Incompetent middle level managers incapable any conflict resolution.
4) Most of the decisions are done by Paris teams, and India appears just to be a cost centre rather than a strategic development centre.
5) Poor emphasis on processes.
6) Rigid team structures, timings and overall a very rigid idea about how to get work done.
7) Very lethargic induction program.

employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale
employeer_pros:
Good place to start with. When starting low, good opportunities to move up.
Very well balanced between personal life and work . 5 years is a max in this bank
employeer_cons:
Situation getting worse since 2008. 
Top Management completely short-minded, trying to get employees believing everything's fine.
A mexican army of employees, most of which are powerpoint pros.
Too much people to work on a single simple case, that makes the 1000 emails threshold a minimum
SG becoming a low-tier bank while few years ago the name was respected in the industry.
Completely risk adverse in all and every fields of the bank won't help get the situation better

good work life balance
employeer_cons: No say in technology, things are decided by people at Paris and here at bangalore only need to follow what is said to them,

review_title: Begin there. Don't stay too long if you are ambitious.
employee_history: I worked at Société Générale
employeer_pros: Very good work/life balance. High technical and scientific level. Very good place to learn the ropes. Actually, after starting there, you will be very sought after by more prestigious banks. Then your job is safer in French banks. They seldom fire anybody even if it has changed recently. Very solid bank despite the rogue trading and subprime losses. Their equity and commodities businesses are leader in their respective fields.
employeer_cons: The pay package, much lower than in American banks. If you don't like to share your earnings, you will have a hard time there. At SocGen, you build more a reputation than a bank balance.

employee_history: I worked at Société Générale

employeer_cons: people, culture, lack of opportunity to move sideways, lack of support from management, impersonal working environment.  not a good place to work.

review_title: Good company. Respect for employees. Concerns about career advacement.
employee_history: I worked at Société Générale

employeer_cons: However, at the middle office level at least, it seems that promotions are not so frequent. Not fitting the french "cadre" of a typical employer (usually coming from "grandes ecoles")

review_title: save societe general employees in Egypt- NSGB
employee_history: I have been working at Société Générale
employeer_pros: gaining experience only in order to work in another place that gives it employees a suitable and satisfactory salary to help them living not as this place in which we are very poor if compared with same level of employees in other places in Egypt.
employeer_cons: there is a great shortage in the number of employees which makes it harder on the emplyees making them work for extra hours without any overtime payment, in addition that if any experienced emplyee resigns he is not replaceable and if replaced he is replaced with a fresh graduate, because with this low amount of payment they cannot attract experienced employees.
